PROCTEXT.PARA: Mr SPEAKER (Hon. Harry Jenkins) took the chair at 10 a.m., and read prayers.

PETITION.PRESENTERS: ADERMANN; CADMAN; CAMERON; COWAN; KATTER; MCGAURAN
PETITION.TITLE: Discrimination against Women
PETITION.PARA: The Clerk-Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows and copies will be referred to the appropriate Ministers:
Discrimination against Women

To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that whereas the Government of Australia has signed the United Nations Covenant on Civil and Political Rights which in Article 23 (1) states that ''The family is the natural and fundamental group unit of society and is entitled to the protection by society and the State''. And whereas the terms of the United Nations Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination Against Women would violate the above Article 23 (1).
We humbly pray the Government to refrain from ratifying the Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination Against Women. Believing that its implementation would result in:
(1) Undue cost to the nation at this time.

(2) ''The elimination of any stereotyped concept of roles of men and women at all levels'' as described in Part 3 Article 10 (c), being a disruption of traditional parental roles, is likely to result in emotional disturbances of childhood.

(3) The strong encouragements to mothers to join the workforce, with the provision of networks of creches and child care centres as outlined in Article 11 of the convention is likely to result in maternal deprivation and psychological disturbances among children with an increase in childhood psychiatric illnesses.
(4) The sexual role changing as recommended in Part 3 Article 10 (c) is likely to contribute to further marriage insecurity and breakdown.
And we pray you may be conscious of God's sovereign purpose for our nation.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Adermann,Mr Cadman,Mr Ian Cameron,Mr Cowan,Mr Katter and Mr McGauran.

PETITION.TITLE: Attendant Care Allowance
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth the need for the immediate introduction of an Attendant Care Allowance for Disabled people who need assistance with aspects of daily living.
This allowance will enable disabled people to live in the community.
It should be in the form of a benefit paid directly to the disabled person enabling him/her to employ and train the attendant of his/her own choice.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Proposed Airport at Scheyville, New South Wales
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
1. That an airport in the north-western region (commonly called Scheyville) imposes disastrous economic, environmental and social costs on our community.
2. An airport would destroy 2,000 households and impose upheaval, noise and pollution on one million people presently unaffected.
3. The cost of an airport in the north-western region is greater than the alternatives, whilst fog and close proximity to RAAF Base Richmond would make operations impractical.
4. It would destroy the historic village of Pitt Town, environmentally important wetlands, and their unique adherent wildlife.
5. Your petitioners reject these proposals and call for endorsement of the MANS Committee findings.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Great Barrier Reef: Oil Exploration
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of citizens of the Commonwealth submits:
That offshore oil exploration within the Great Barrier Reef Region constitutes a serious threat to the richest and most varied living system on earth.
Your Petitioners request that your Honourable House will.
1. Prohibit oil exploration within the Great Barrier Reef Region,
2. Declare the entire Great Barrier Reef Region a Marine Park under the Federal Government's Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Act 1975,
3. Provide the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority with the staff and resources for effective management of the Region.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Radford College, Australian Capital Territory
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives of the Commonwealth of Australia in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That we request that the Government take steps to ensure:
(1) The construction programme of Radford College, Bruce proceeds immediately.
(2) Parents freedom of choice in education is fostered by continuing to provide a basic grant for all Australian children.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Broadcasting and Television Act
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That because television and radio:
(a) affect our social and moral environment,
(b) are family media watched and heard by many children at all times, and
(c) present too much explicit violence and sex,
they therefore need stronger control than other media and the existing standards need stricter enforcement in both national A.B.C., and commercial sectors.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray:
That the Australian Government will amend the Broadcasting and Television Act, in relation to both national and commercial broadcasters, to legislate
(a) for adequate and comprehensive programs in the best interests of the general public,
(b) for a ''Dual System of Regulation'' enforced by the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal by internal regulation and external control.
(c) for an independent consumer body to represent the best interests of the general public, and
(d) for immediate and effective penalties to be imposed for breaches of program and advertising standards.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Construction of Railway Overpass, Port Augusta, South Australia
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in the Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That the railway crossing situated approximately 5 kilometres east of Port Augusta on Highway One (the main highway between Adelaide and all northern and western centres of South Australia and continuing through to Western Australia) has once again been the sight of an horrendous accident.
This accident has caused two, possibly three, fatalities.

Previous requests have been made by the city council of Port Augusta for the construction of an overpass, so that this section of the highway no longer presents a danger to the motoring public and those involved in driving trains over this crossing.
Permission for construction of this overpass has previously been refused and the situation has now become critical.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Federal Government will reconsider their previous decision and approve construction of an overpass at this fatally dangerous railway crossing to avoid further loss of life.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Mackay Directory Assistance Centre
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives of the Commonwealth of Australia in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Mackay respectfully showeth:
That the intention of Telecom Australia to close the Mackay Directory Assistance Centre will:
downgrade telephone services to Mackay and district.
deprive customers of a personalised reliable telephone service.
reduce job opportunities in the area.
increase the likelihood of the eventual closure of the exchange.
We the undersigned believe that Telecom Australia has a social responsibility to provide a sound, reliable, personalised telephone system.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that your Honourable House will call on the Government to intervene to stop Telecom's proposed closure of the Mackay Directory Assistance Centre.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Beddall,Dr Everingham and Mr Gayler.

PETITION.TITLE: Advertising of Alcohol
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in the Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the citizens of Western Australia respectfully shows:
Last year, over 3,300 people died on Australian roads;
Alcohol is a factor in 50 per cent of road deaths;
Alcohol advertisements do not show the perils of driving after drinking alcohol ;
Alcohol advertisements are glamorous and increase their effect on teenagers, indicating drinking alcohol as the social pastime;
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Parliament will legislate to ban the advertising of alcohol from commercial television and radio.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Transcontinental (North-South) Railway
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in the Parliament assembled. The petition of certain citizens of the Northern Territory of Australia shows:

1. That the Commonwealth of Australia and the State of South Australia entered into an agreement on 7th December, 1907 requiring the Commonwealth of Australia to construct the transcontinental (North-South) railway from Darwin to South Australia;
2. That the transcontinental (North-South) railway has not yet been constructed ;
3. That the construction of the transcontinental (North-South) railway is the linchpin for the further development of the Northern Territory of Australia;

4. That the transcontinental (North-South) railway will provide employment through construction work, steel production and manufacturing and it will assist in ensuring the defence and security of Northern Australia.
Your petitioners therefore pray that the Commonwealth of Australia commence and complete construction of the transcontinental (North-South) railway at an early date.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: General Motors-Holden's Pty Ltd
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. We the Citizens of the City of Woodville and supported by the citizens of South Australia, being deeply concerned over the threat of closure of the Woodville Plant of General Motors-Holdens, respectfully show:
1. That the management of General Motors-Holden's has failed over a period of more than two (2) years to give any assurances that the Woodville Plant would continue in operation.
2. That a recent statement attributed to the GMH Managing Director, quote:
''The overall objective of our South Australian rationalisation plan has been to eliminate all productive activities on the Woodville site'' end of quote.
This statement has not been refuted.
3. That the elimination of the Woodville Plant will cause enormous social dislocation, hardship and misery to the citizens of Woodville and South Australia.

Your petitioners therefore pray that the Parliament of Australia will condemn this callous disregard for the citizens of Woodville and South Australia, and do all in its power to force General Motors-Holdens to retain its operation at the Woodville Plant.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Anthony The Rt Hon J.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, I wish to make a personal explanation.
—Does the right honourable member claim to have been misrepresented?
—Yes.
—He may proceed.

—There have been a number of media reports of the testimony given to the Stewart Royal Commission of Inquiry into Drug Trafficking yesterday by a Mr Trevor Volkman. One of the claims made by Mr Volkman is that I influenced investigations into the operations of the Nugan Hand Bank. These allegations have been made before. They were denied by me in this House some time ago. I repeat today: Any allegations that I have in any way influenced or attempted to influence any investigations into this matter are utterly without foundation. The allegations made by Mr Volkman were reported last night on the 7 p.m. television news bulletin of the Australian Broadcasting Commission. I fully understand the duty of the ABC to report those allegations. I regret, however- without wanting to be seen to be giving any bipartisan support to the Deputy Prime Minister (Mr Lionel Bowen) or the Minister for Industry and Commerce ( Senator Button)-that the ABC did not report my previous denials of these allegations or ask me to respond to the claims repeated yesterday by Mr Volkman.

SPEECH.PARA: Perhaps I may draw your attention, Mr Speaker, to Hansard of 27 October 1982, page 2600, where it is reported that I said that I had contacted the former member for Riverina, Mr Sullivan, whom Mr Volkman named, and that Mr Sullivan had stated that he had never at any time raised anything of this nature with me. I also said that I was certain that Mr Sullivan had never raised such matters with me, and that I had never made such suggestions to the honourable member for Farrer (Mr Fife). At that time I also reminded the House that Mr Brian Bates had denied that he had been directed by any Minister of the Crown to suppress investigations by the Federal Bureau of Narcotics into the activities of the Nugan Hand banking corporation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fife The Hon W.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, I also claim to have been misrepresented and wish to make a personal explanation.
—The honourable member may proceed.

—The misrepresentations to which I refer also relate to the testimony to the Stewart Royal Commission of Inquiry into Drug Trafficking given by Mr Trevor Volkman and reported in the media yesterday and again today. Mr Volkman was reported to have claimed that I may have taken some kind of action, when Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs, to inhibit in some way the investigation into the affairs of Nugan Hand Ltd which at the time was being carried out by the then Narcotics Bureau, a unit of the Department of Business and Consumer Affairs.

SPEECH.PARA: These allegations have been made previously and have been categorically denied by me previously. In fact, I denied these allegations in this House on 27 October 1982. During the time that I was Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs, I repeatedly sought and obtained assurances that the Department was actively pursuing investigations into the operations of the Nugan Hand Bank. I also sought and obtained assurances that other law enforcement agencies were investigating the activities of Nugan Hand. The allegations concerning me that have been made by Mr Volkman are completely without foundation.

DEBATE.TITLE: MR VALERIY IVANOV AND MR DAVID COMBE

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

PROCTEXT.PARA: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —I have received a letter from the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Peacock) proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the House for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The Government's duplicitous handling of the Ivanov/ Combe affair.
I call upon those members who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of members required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Peacock The Hon A.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yesterday in this House the Leader of the National Party of Australia (Mr Anthony) asked the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) a question regarding the Combe affair. The Prime Minister in his answer hid behind the Royal Commission on Security and Intelligence Agencies . The Prime Minister established this Royal Commission and on that basis he refuses to answer questions in this Parliament. Yet he is prepared to talk his head off outside the Parliament. I have a small sample of the interviews that have been granted to newspapers around the country in the last few days, including an interview published in the Melbourne Herald on Saturday, one on radio on Sunday and one on the Mike Walsh Show on television on Monday. But, interestingly enough, one newspaper report has sought answers to questions which the Prime Minister will not answer. Let me read some excerpts from an article in the Melbourne Age of yesterday, headed:

SPEECH.PARA: I could not have told Combe, says Hawke.
In that report Michelle Grattan, the chief political correspondent, said:
The Prime Minister, Mr Hawke, has claimed that he would have broken the law if he had confronted Mr David Combe with ASIO allegations that his activities were a security risk.

Yesterday Mr Hawke said on the 'Mike Walsh Show' on Channel 9 that he was ' nothing less than amazed at the gratuitous and insane observations' that he should have called Mr Combe in and 'tipped him off'.

Asked last night what law Mr Hawke would have broken by confronting Mr Combe before the Government cut off official contact with him, his office said it was the Crimes Act. The Crimes Act, of course, has provisions against the unauthorised disclosure of confidential information. The Melbourne Age went on to state:
However, what is not clear is:
Why a Prime Minister, or a Cabinet, would not legally authorise such a disclosure of information.
How Mr Combe could later be given a full briefing of the ASIO evidence against him without this being a breach of the law, when Mr Hawke says to have confronted him before would have broken the law.
Senator Evans's office last night referred questions to Mr Hawke's office.
I understand that no answers have been provided from the Prime Minister to those questions. The Melbourne Herald editorialised last night under a heading: 'The indignant Mr Hawke'. It concluded:
No doubt the coming Royal Commission will canvass all these issues--
That is, the issues that the editorial discussed-
and perhaps nothing more should be said until the findings are in. But it is Mr Hawke himself who keeps the affair in public debate. We think he doth protest too much.

The fact is that this Prime Minister will answer questions other than those posed to him by the Age but will not answer questions in this Parliament. As recently as Monday, on a television program, he discussed the matter and referred to laws that he says he would have been breaking-that is, the provisions of the Crimes Act, providing, as the Age reported, against unauthorised disclosure of confidential or classified information. The reality is, of course, that to try to stonewall in here and yet talk out there is one thing. He cannot get away from the law itself. It is always open to a Cabinet to authorise legally such a disclosure of information as referred to in the terms of the Crimes Act. But, of course, Cabinet did not do this, so we understand, because it had not been told the full details, in contrast to a certain Mr Farmer and a certain Mr Butler. But the question also arises how Mr Combe could later be given a briefing of the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation's evidence against him without it being a breach of the law. Is it not classic Hawkespeak-say one thing, do another; this time in the arena of national security. The Prime Minister said:
I couldn't have advised Mr Combe because I'd break the law.

Yet, after his gaffs blew the matter publicly, Mr Combe was then advised. Was the Crimes Act changed? No. Did Cabinet authorise the briefing? We do not know. Was the law broken? Who knows. The Prime Minister knows; the Special Minister of State (Mr Young) certainly knows. As I indicated, the media sought answers. One example, the Melbourne Age, points out that the Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans) simply will not answer the questions.

So the reality is that in the handling of this affair, as the Opposition has put down today, the Government has been duplicitous. Frankly, that is putting it mildly. Quite apart from the lies that have been told about this matter, the Prime Minister has crushed civil liberties. He has tried to have it both ways. He said he would have broken the law, yet, before the statement which was made in Parliament some two weeks ago, allegedly to 'put the matter to rest', he had had Mr Combe briefed. He cannot have it both ways. He cannot say that Mr Combe could not be briefed because that would be breaking the law and also say that he arranged for Mr Combe to have a briefing. But even in that briefing the Prime Minister denied Mr Combe his legal counsel. Honourable members will remember, however, that the Prime Minister tried to establish at a Press conference and in this Parliament that Mr Combe's solicitor was present during that briefing. It was not until that misrepresentation was exploded by the Press that we learnt the truth of the matter.

Mr Combe may be guilty but such presumptions can never be made under our standards of justice and equity in the law without a fair hearing let alone without the charge being made. Furthermore, what of the other unanswered questions in this matter? We know that Mr Farmer and Mr Butler were tipped off. We know that for a fact.

TALK.START.PARA: —How do you know that?

—Mr Farmer has admitted that he was told. Mr Combe indicated publicly that it was Mr Farmer, his prospective partner, who warned him of the matter. We must assume that it came from someone in government. After all, all these people were part of this incestuous Labor scene.

SPEECH.PARA: I have to raise one matter which has been touched upon in questions but not developed. I simply touch upon it. Honourable members should remember that the prospective partners, namely, Farmer, Butler and Combe, were to go into a lobbying business. At the time of discussions about the formation of that business, one Mr Butler had a role in assessing who would serve in ministerial offices. He was overseeing for the Labor Government the placement of staff in ministerial offices. To describe this matter as a conflict of interest is putting it at its lowest. We should think of the consequences of that situation. Was there a declaration of the conflict of interest? If there was, at the time of such a disclosure of a prospective conflict of interest, was Mr Butler informed of what the Government believed of Mr Combe's role in this matter? Who is to know of all the leaking? We know that the Special Minister of State leaked to at least one person. Did he talk to others? Did the recipient of the leak make contact with others? Did the recipient of the leak make contact with Mr Combe? If so, where, when and how?

Yet another aspect is that the statement by the Prime Minister to the House on 11 May, the statement that was to put the matter to rest, was also prima facie misleading. A cursory reading of that document seemed to indicate that Mr Combe had accepted and understood all that had happened. In fact, as he has confirmed, he was accepting only the decision of lack of contact with Ministers, not the Government's handling of the whole matter. The tangled web that was woven by dint of half truths and subterfuge to the Cabinet did not succeed. It was all blown asunder by the Prime Minister's gaff in even discussing the matter in the Caucus and the Parliament. The Royal Commission has been and is welcomed by the Opposition. The fact that the Prime Minister could have cleared the air considerably by expanding on his media statements in this Parliament is what we are on about also. At this stage any further information given to the House would be an advance.

At the moment, to use the words of another, this is a riddle, wrapped in a mystery, inside in enigma. It could be answered by the truth. It could be answered by the facts. It would be answered by an honest Prime Minister. It is not being answered by this Prime Minister, certainly not in this House. The Prime Minister derives his authority, firstly, from the people and through that from this House. Yet he denies this House the truth while talking day after day to sections of the media. I ask honourable members to remember that Ivanov's expulsion was and is fully supported by the Opposition. That has never been in question. What is in question is the apparent denial of civil liberties and the endeavours to mislead this House. On this serious matter let there be no doubt that there is a stench about this Government-a stench of dishonesty, a stench of duplicity, a stench of downright deceit-and honourable members opposite know it. Furthermore, some know the truth while some not knowing the truth suspect it and sit uneasily with those involved in the subterfuge and the cover up.

I say to the Prime Minister: If he can talk on television of his alleged innocence, if he can talk to newspapers and indeed berate them of his subjective propriety, why can he not talk to this House? I repeat: The Opposition supports the Royal Commission but it should never have been necessary. At root, the plain fact is that if truth, propriety and proper standards of conduct had been observed there would never have been a need for a royal commission. The Prime Minister and his mysterious mafia caused the royal commission. They now skirt the truth; they hide the truth; they camouflage the truth, especially from this House. A competent, open and proper Prime Minister would have conducted himself differently. A competent, open and proper Prime Minister would not have sought refuge in subterfuge. But a competent, open and proper Prime Minister is not what we have. He and his Government stand condemned for their duplicity and thereby their misconduct. As a consequence a man was accused, perhaps in due course justly, and during that period he was denied his basic rights. He is left twisting slowly in the wind, but so too is the Government's veracity. The reality is that on this matter it is the Government that is twisting and turning tortuously, albeit slowly, in the wind, and so it should.

The Prime Minister cannot continue a cacophony of accounts outside the House, yet remain silent in the sanctum of the House. Yet that is what the Prime Minister has chosen to do. The choice was his and he and his cronies are now cornered by their cowardice. A responsible Prime Minister would come clean. A responsible Prime Minister would confess. A responsible Prime Minister, in all these circumstances, would recant. No fair-minded Australian can accept the double standards applied to the Cabinet, the Ministry, the Parliament, the nation or Mr Combe. Consequently, this Government stands condemned for both its duplicity and double talk and consequently this Prime Minister stands condemned for his deceitfulness, his double dealing and his downright duplicity.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beazley The Hon K.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Members of the Opposition have been making extraordinarily heavy weather of this issue for the last two weeks. Their propositions on this matter fell as a damp squib during the last week of the Parliament, to their very considerable embarrassment. One of the reasons that they are making very heavy weather of this is that they do not really know what they want from it. They do not really know what they want discussed and they are not welcoming the Royal Commission on Security and Intelligence Agencies as they say they are. They are most reluctant that the matters that the Royal Commission will hear be aired in public because they will go to the very heart of the handling of national security matters by the now Opposition leaders when they were directly responsible for national security. On the one hand, the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Peacock) comes in here demanding frankness and full disclosure of matters which the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) has repeatedly said will be properly before the Royal Commission, when those matters will be thoroughly considered by it. On the other hand, he comes into this place, buttons up his coat, leans on the dispatch box and says: 'A Prime Minister who revealed these matters would be an injudicious Prime Minister. A Prime Minister who revealed these matters would be a Prime Minister who would not be properly mindful of the national security interests of this country. A Prime Minister who discussed these matters would be a Prime Minister not fit to hold office'.

SPEECH.PARA: He cannot have it both ways. He cannot come into this place and demand a degree of frankness on matters that are to be referred to a royal commission and then in another guise come in and say that these matters ought not to be discussed. He is not serious when he says that he supports the terms of reference of the Royal Commission. He does not want that Royal Commission to look into the matters surrounding both this affair and the other matters that will be discussed by it. I refer honourable members to that portion of the terms of reference of the Royal Commission that deal with this. There may be some suspicion, after the constant raising of this matter by questions in the House from the Opposition, that there may not be an opportunity for all matters that ought properly to be considered by the Commission to be considered by it. That would be a reasonable supposition on the part of the general public, having listened to these debates in which the Opposition is constantly raising this matter.

To put that to rest, I will refer to the terms of reference of the Royal Commission that deal precisely with the matters that he has raised. Of course, a number of other matters will be considered and I will get on to them a little later. The terms of reference in part (c) state:

further to the inquiry in relation to paragraphs (a) and (b) above, all the circumstances, including the actions of the Government, surrounding the expulsion from Australia of Mr Valeriy Nicholayevich Ivanov, First Secretary, Embassy of the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics, and the involvement of Mr Harvey David Mathew Combe in those circumstances;

The Opposition, as well as the Government, will be in the box in this Royal Commission. The Government welcomes the opportunity to be in the box on this matter. Opposition members will be able to go there and explain some of their absurd conduct on this matter over the last few weeks. As the saying goes, they will be able to 'explain it all down at city hall' in front of Judge Hope. That is the time when it will be appropriately raised and properly dealt with. It is a pity for the proper conduct of the national security of this country that we have on our hands the Bruce by-election because if we put in front of the Liberal and National parties the smell of an election or a by-election they cannot help themselves on national security matters. They cannot leave these matters for appropriate bipartisan discussions and appropriate briefings. They must attempt to wrap themselves in the flag in such a way as to throw discredit on their opponents and to attempt to claim for themselves a monopoly of patriotism in this country, a monopoly of virtue on national security matters and a monopoly of competence in handling national security matters.

This has produced down the years a series of the most appalling misuses of the Australian defence and security forces. They have been involved in Australian politics in a way in which in no other democratic country they would be involved . Most of the leaders of the Opposition were Ministers at the time of those worst abuses. The security forces have been sooled on to decent, responsible Australian citizens whose only disagreement has been with the policies of the governments of the 1960s and the beginning of the 1970s. That has been their only crime. In the process, the effectiveness of those bodies in protecting our national interests on a range of matters, in protecting the interests of Australians against the activities of terrorist organisations in this country not associated with the ideological Left but associated with the ideological Right, and the entitlement of Australian citizens to be protected from the depredations of those groups, went unconsidered or ill-considered as a result of the misuse of security forces by those governments.

The Royal Commission will provide opportunities for those matters as well to be considered a little further. The Royal Commission will provide opportunities for the security forces of this country to be structured and operated in such a manner that all Australian citizens can have full confidence that their national interest will be protected. We will not tolerate the situation that has existed for a number of years in which the security forces, the defence forces or whatever become an aspect of the political arm of a government of a conservative persuasion. They will become genuinely independent and genuinely protective of the national interest. I will return a little later to have a closer look at this question of duplicity in connection with more recent events and the duplicity of honourable members on the other side of the House on national security matters in years past.

Ever since this Parliament first met we have raised constantly the duplicity involved in the $9.6 billion deficit. I will not go into how flexible forward estimates are. I will not go into the general propositions but, since the Leader of the Opposition is here presenting himself as an honourable man, as an honest man, and is criticising the Prime Minister for alleged breaches and duplicity, certain aspects of this problem should be raised. One thing that can be said for the Deputy Leader of the Opposition, the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard), is that irrespective of whether he agrees that the $9.6 billion was what he said it was, he accepts full responsibility for the fact that that forward estimate was not disclosed during the election campaign. He has taken on himself the full burden of the responsibility of that act of duplicity in relation to the Australian electorate. He ought not to bear that burden alone, though he has been obliged to bear it alone. I find it absolutely inconceivable that any Ministers who had senior responsibility for the management of the economy or industry during the period of the Fraser Government, and particularly during the election campaign, were not themselves apprised of the facts as well. Obviously the Leader of the Opposition knew that. If he did not know, he was an incompetent Minister; if he did know he has permitted his colleague to bear the full political burden of that act of duplicity. That is an act of impropriety in relation to one's colleagues that ought not to be tolerated by the electorate but which has been tolerated by the Liberal Party.

Let us get a little closer to this matter from that particular question of concern though, as I said, if the Opposition is going to fling around terms like duplicity in matters of public importance in this House the flack will fall where it may. I am going instead to go to the way in which the Opposition has dealt with this matter in the House. As I started off by saying, on the one hand there has been this demand for frankness; on the other hand there has been the view that these matters really ought not to be discussed here, that they ought to be left for bipartisan, secret consideration. The Opposition now claims it has a desire to see them properly dealt with by the Royal Commission. As honourable members opposite are so protective of civil liberties, let us take a look at the way in which David Combe's name was raised in this House. I go back to 10 May when three questions, culminating in one from the Deputy Leader of the National Party, the right honourable member for New England (Mr Sinclair) actually naming David Combe, were placed before this Parliament. There can be absolutely no doubt when the content of those questions is read that they were placed before this Parliament in a co-ordinated fashion designed to tease forth that name. There can be no doubt in the mind of anyone who has a rudimentary understanding of the procedures of this House and the politics of this nation that those questions were brought down in such a way as to reveal that name. It is absolute balderdash for honourable members opposite, having been actively engaged in that process, to come into this place and claim somehow innocence of any breach of a person's civil liberties. That balderdash is being inflicted on the people of Australia by the Opposition.

The question arises, of course, as to the way in which the information was garnered by which those questions could be placed before this House. There has been only one explanation from the Deputy Leader of the National Party, that is that he got the information from an Australian Associated Press report and that that information was not in any way relayed to him and confirmed or otherwise by the man who had received the secret briefing and had expressed himself pleased with that briefing. It did not come from him; oh, no, it came from an AAP report . I have those AAP reports. At no point in those reports on 10 May, before the question was raised in this House, was the name David Combe mentioned. A senior Australian Labor Party official was referred to. Around this country there are hundreds of senior ALP officials and ex-senior ALP officials. To be able to isolate a particular name from the vast numbers of ex-ALP officials around the country is not merely a matter of coincidence; it is a matter of having received a briefing from either the Leader of the Opposition or somebody else as to the name of the person involved. It has been claimed that the briefing has been properly respected. However, there is at least a prima facie case to suggest that it was not. If the briefing has been properly respected the Leader of the Opposition will be able to explain that to Mr Justice Hope at the Royal Commission on Security and Intelligence Agencies and no doubt he will be prepared to give Mr Justice Hope a very full, free and frank briefing of the way in which he has handled the material that has been given to him.

I will be followed in this debate by the Leader of the National Country Party ( Mr Anthony) who has always been pretty free over the years with his accusations of treason. I will be interested to hear from him an explanation of a few factors that have come out in this whole national security issue and which have yet to be properly aired in this House. These relate to what purport to be highly classified documents which were stolen, leaked and published in the National Times on 6 May. It is a security scandal of the Fraser Government which the present Government is now obliged to manage in the national interest.

We have the Deputy Leader of the National Party describing the Special Minister of State (Mr Young) as having committed the gravest breach of national security in Australia's history. That charge has been somewhat diminished since then. If we look at those documents-I am not a briefed Minister so I cannot verify their accuracy-we find that they have a serious ring of authenticity about them. If those documents are accurate, they have compromised every single major intelligence agency in this country and they have com- promised our relationships with allies and important neighbours. These people have the hide to walk into this place wrapped in the flag, wrapped in national security and criticise the Special Minister of State for the terrible way in which he handles national security matters when they have handed us this blue duck, this massive compromise of our security, a direct result of their incompetence, with which we must now deal. The Leader of the National Party, the Deputy Leader of the National Party and the former Minister for Foreign Affairs were all on the intelligence committee of the Cabinet at the time when these documents were leaked. That is another matter that they will have an opportunity to explain to the Royal Commission. The Opposition speaks of duplicity. What a hide the Opposition has to introduce questions of duplicity into this debate. This is a shonky matter of public importance raised by an Opposition that is running out of steam and desperate to introduce this element again. As such it ought to be absolutely rejected.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Anthony The Rt Hon J.D.

TALKER.NAME: Mr ANTHONY
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —The duplicitous handling of the Ivanov-Combe affair is raising a lot of questions. The more the Government speaks on the matter the more curious the nation becomes as to the depth of the intrigue and the full extent of the plot behind this whole affair. Why is it that today a matter of such importance to this Parliament and to the nation is being answered and defended by two Ministers, the Minister for Aviation (Mr Beazley) and the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs ( Mr Holding), who were not members of the National and International Security Sub -committee of Cabinet that spoke about this matter, that knew all the details? These are two Ministers who were not informed as to the details until 2 May. Indeed, they were not even given the details. All they were told was that there was not to be any involvement with Mr Combe; that it would be embarrassing to the Government to have people who were closely related to it acting as lobbyists . Yet today both gentlemen come into the House and try to defend their Government. That only raises more questions as to why the Government should put up such insignificant Ministers, who know nothing about the details, to try to fend off problems that the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) is making for himself.

SPEECH.PARA: This is an issue on which the Government has tried to prevent debate taking place; on which it has tried to prevent a parliamentary examination taking place . Instead, it has hidden behind the curtain of national security and of a pending royal commission. Of course, the Prime Minister has not abided by that restriction himself. He has pulled the curtain aside whenever it has been convenient to do so and, as the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Peacock) has said, during the course of the weekend he gave numerous interviews to people when it suited him to do so. In a good many of those interviews, when questions were raised, all they got was a vitriolic reply. In the end, in one interview he said that it would be a crime to talk about it; that it would be a breach of the Crimes Act; that he could not possibly go on talking about it any further. That opens up a lot of questions. Did the Special Minister of State (Mr Young) commit a crime when he erred and said that the Government was about to kick out a Russian? Was that a crime? Is the Prime Minister going to take any action about it? Was it a crime when the Government informed the Chief Minister of the Northern Territory that he must have no further dealings with Mr Combe? Was it a crime that Mr Farmer somehow or other found out, through sources very close to the Government that Mr Combe was involved with Mr Ivanov and, that that was one of the principal reasons for Mr Ivanov being expelled?

Was the Prime Minister's statement to this House itself a crime? He started delivering certain innuendoes as to the activities of Mr Combe, a person who, he said, without any explanation, was compromised, who was a national risk- allegations that have already been denied by Mr Combe. Was that a crime? These are all very curious affairs. First, the Prime Minister hides behind national security. Secondly, he hides behind a pending royal commission. Thirdly, he now says that it would be a breach of the Crimes Act. Obviously the Government is trying to cover up. It is not good enough. This is an important matter and the Opposition demands that it be given more attention, and be made the subject of more honest replies, than is the case at the moment. There have been leaks from the very highest levels of government. In fact, the way that this matter has been handled goes to the very credibility and integrity of the Government and the Prime Minister.

We expressed our concerns that the terms of reference of the inquiry were not satisfactory and evidence is now showing that they are not satisfactory. Of course, the manner in which this inquiry came forth is a laughable affair. It was not until it was brought up in this chamber that Mr Combe was not being given natural justice, was not being given a chance to defend himself, whether he was right or wrong, that the Prime Minister hastily then-to the embarrassment of the Minister for Industry and Commerce (Senator Button) and the Deputy Prime Minister (Mr Lionel Bowen) who only just a few hours prior to that had said that that would be the last thing one would want to do if one wanted to help Mr Combe -announced a royal commission. He announced the terms of reference to the stunned silence of all his front bench with whom he had not consulted. Cabinet knew nothing of it. This whole affair has been one mystery after another. Many facts are emerging that require very close examination. We know that the sub- committee of Cabinet met on 21 April. It decided to expel Mr Ivanov and was told of the relationship between Mr Ivanov and Mr Combe. It decided on a cover story. It needed a cover story, obviously, to protect a former Labor Party figure. Mr Ivanov was expelled on 22 April. But before announcing that decision, we know the story of what the special Minister for long lunches did. He blurted it out. He could not keep the secret. By the time Mr Cameron left that lunch and after speaking with Mr Combe-he says the Special Minister of State said no more and we will just have to accept that-Mr Combe, back at the National Press Club, fully understood that he was somehow involved with the expulsion of Mr Ivanov. Cabinet met on 23 and 24 April and honourable members then moved to Adelaide to attend the Constitutional Convention. It was during that Convention that the Chief Minister of the Northern Territory was informed. I have no quibble with that briefing. He had been closely involved with Mr Combe in his lobbying business. What does concern me, however, is the statement on 12 May on the Australian Broadcasting Commission radio program PM by Mr Richard Hall, formerly a staff member of the Whitlam Labor Government. Mr Hall said, on 12 May, that a State non-Labor politician had had a briefing on the matter. We know now that Mr Hall was right, and that the Chief Minister was that person. But this event was another closely guarded secret, according to the Prime Minister. He did not announce, until 20 May-there are some aspects of that announcement--

TALK.START.PARA: —How did Hall know?

—Mr Hall, of course, was very close to the Government. Yesterday I asked the Prime Minister a very important question. I asked the Prime Minister whether Mr Bill Butler had approached the Prime Minister to ask whether he and his business partner, Mr Richard Farmer, a person who had been very closely involved with the 1983 Labor election campaign, and who was planning to enter a lobbying business with Mr Combe, would be in difficulties if that occurred. Mr Farmer said later that he knew, of course, that Mr Combe had been involved with Mr Ivanov. My question was fended off with the answer that it was a matter of security. The first thing I asked the Prime Minister was:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . whether he or anyone instructed, authorised, or employed by him briefed any other person in relation to this matter; and secondly, whether following an approach by Mr Farmer's business partner, Mr Bill Butler, a member of the Government's ministerial staff advisory panel, about a possible conflict of interest if Mr Farmer and Mr Butler entered into a business arrangement with Mr Combe, the Prime Minister personally briefed Mr Farmer about Mr Combe's relationship with Ivanov, on or about the weekend of 23 and 24 April.

All these questions have to be answered. But yesterday the Prime Minister took the opportunity of again saying that he could not answer them because of the pending Royal Commission. But when he goes out into the public arena and is interviewed by people, he has no qualms at all about opening up and expressing points of view on this matter. But he will not tell this Parliament. The fact that two junior Ministers have come into the Parliament today to defend the decision raises greater questions.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Holding The Hon A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is an odd experience to be lectured, as we were, by the Leader of the National Party ( Mr Anthony) on civil liberties and the rights of citizens to be protected from allegations as the Opposition launched yet again a series of names and floated them across this Parliament without regard to the truth or accuracy of the allegations. There is one simple answer to the allegations made by the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Peacock) and the Leader of the National Party. It is that the Government has appointed a Royal Commission on Security and Intelligence Agencies. No member of this House could seriously entertain any doubts about the integrity or the honour of the man chosen to lead that Royal Commission.

SPEECH.PARA: The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) has indicated to this House that if any member or citizen has any allegation that he wants to put about the propriety of the actions of the Prime Minister, the Government or any honourable member, the Royal Commission is there and is open to them. I say to the Leader of the Opposition that there is not one single allegation that he made in this House today that, if he had the political courage and a greater vocabulary, he could not have put to the Royal Commission. But he chooses to launch what can be described only as this Bruce by-election stunt, dredged up by an ailing and failing Opposition and a Leader of the Opposition whose only contribution to this debate seemed to me to be restoring the credibility of the former Treasurer . He was the only member of the Opposition who looked at all happy with the performance of the Leader of the Opposition.

Let us consider that performance. In the last three minutes of the speech of the Leader of the Opposition I made a note of the terminology he used. He used words such as 'subterfuge, duplicity, misconduct, cowardice, incompetence, secretiveness, double talk, deceitfulness, double dealing' and, again, ' duplicity'. He threw all those words out. What is the basis of the allegations made by the Opposition? It is that the Prime Minister answered some questions asked by some journalist. According to the Leader of the Opposition, he should not do that; that is sinful. He says this despite the fact that he knows as we all do that the Prime Minister has reserved the rights of the Royal Commission ultimately to make decisions on this matter. I say to the Leader of the Opposition that the Prime Minister is not the only person in Australia who has recently been talking to the Press about this matter. Lots of people--

TALK.START.PARA: —But he won't talk to the Parliament.

—When he talks to the Parliament, he makes a damn sight better sense than the Leader of the Opposition. The Prime Minister is not the only one who feels the need to answer certain questions in respect of this matter. I refer the Leader of the National Party and the Leader of the Opposition to the statement made on a public broadcast on Monday, 23 May, by their own political colleague, Mr Everingham, who was asked what he knew about the matter. I do not have time to deal with all of his allegations, but he was defending himself, as he was entitled to defend himself, against the allegation that he might have been the source of the leak. I defend his right to do that. Let me quote, in order to defend Mr Everingham--
—Don't do that.
—Oh no, he is entitled to have his case put. He went on to say:

SPEECH.PARA: I say categorically that I have had no dealings with the Opposition on this matter-
Listen to this; I repeat it:
I have had no dealing with the Opposition on this matter whatsoever, and any approches from them have been rebuffed by me, and there has only been one approach anyway.

I repeat: 'There has only been one approach anyway'. Perhaps the Leader of the Opposition would like to tell us whether it was the Leader of the National Party , or which member of the Opposition chose to approach the Leader of the Government in the Northern Territory in order to get him to disclose personal briefings that he had had in respect of this matter, because that is a statement from one of the Opposition's political colleagues. These are the men who come in and talk about security matters.

Let us look at the history of the Ivanov affair and get it into its historical context. The last people in this Parliament to lecture the Australian people about security, the appropriate use of the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation and a proper relationship in respect of ASIO are the members opposite, because when they were in government and members of past conservative governments, ASIO was subject to continual leaking and involvement in the internal domestic political affairs of this country. How can this be for this highly principled Leader of the Opposition or the Leader of the National Party? It has been a matter of public knowledge. I cannot quote it all; I do not have the time. However, I refer them to page 183 of the only authoritative book written on the history of ASIO, which says that not only were those items leaked and ASIO used for internal political processes; but also they were used to help to decide the internal leadership of this party, when Opposition members were members of a political party that allowed a former Prime Minister in his candidacy to lead this Opposition, as it now is, this rump Opposition--
Opposition members interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Security-it is not a matter of concern; oh, no. The allegation was that a former Prime Minister, a member of this Parliament, a member of the Opposition party, a former leader, could have had his house burgled. The serious allegation is that while the Opposition was in office and assuring the people of Australia that they were safe and secure and assuring members of this House that they had nothing to fear, as part of the internal clawing and backstabbing which had featured in their political organisation, ASIO was used to burgle the house of a former leader and former Prime Minister. Were these men who now talk about duplicity moved by that? Did they regard that as a serious allegation? Did the Leader of the Opposition come in here and raise the matter?
—You are not a member of the security committee. You are not even in the Cabinet. Why don't you tone it down?
—Why does the honourable member not stop acting like the cheap larrikin that he has always been?
—You have not even been--
—One of the flowers of the back benches. The honourable member's own dog would not even use him.
—Order! The Minister will resume his seat. I ask the House to come to order. The honourable member for Hume has been interrupting, and I ask him to conform with the requirements of the House.

—The record of the gentlemen who raised this matter in terms of their responsibilities when they were in government and were responsible for the proper and effective administration of security services is a national disgrace. If they were fair dinkum in their allegations in this Parliament today, if they were the two men of integrity--
—You would not even know.

—If they were the men of integrity that they claim to be, the allegations could be made to the Hope Royal Commission. One does not have to be a prophet to say there will be none of these allegations. They will not go to the Royal Commission. They will find a dozen reasons not to do so while they continue to waste the time of this Parliament. The real issue before this Parliament is the mess that the former Government made of the economy. It is the responsibility of this Government to clean it up. The Opposition should not waste the time of this Parliament on these kinds of puerile and nonsensical matters. I condemn the matter and I condemn the shallow and baseless allegations made by the Leader of the Opposition and his henchman, the Leader of the National Party.
—The discussion is concluded.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Young The Hon M.J.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: LEADER OF THE HOUSE; SPECIAL MINISTER OF STATE

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this House authorises Mr Speaker to have installed closed circuit television facilities which will enable the proceedings in the House of Representatives Chamber to be monitored in the offices of the Whips and at certain other locations within Parliament House as approved by Mr Speaker.

TALK.START.PARA: —ASIO headquarters.

—The terms of the motion are self-explanatory, although I would not think we would want to see the honourable member for Denison too often on television. As some honourable members will be aware, on 27 November 1981 the Senate agreed to the installation of closed circuit television cameras in the Senate chamber and associated monitors in the offices of the party Whips. I understand that the installation was suggested by the Whips and has proved to be of assistance to them in carrying out their duties. The installation of similar facilities in the House of Representatives was raised by the then Government Whip in this House during the debate on the 1982-83 appropriations for the Parliament. Mr Speaker's predecessor indicated that he saw considerable merit in the proposal. I understand that following Mr Speaker's election he asked the Whips to take up the matter with members of their parties. He has now received advice that all parties have agreed to the proposal. This motion seeks the authority of the House for the Speaker to proceed with the installation.

SPEECH.PARA: It is intended that monitors be provided in the offices of each of the three Whips. However, if agreed to, the motion will permit the Speaker to approve the installation of monitors in other offices in Parliament House if the Speaker is satisfied that there is a need to do so. The estimated cost of installing the system of six cameras and three monitoring positions is $23,000. Additional monitoring positions would cost approximately $3,000 each. I commend the motion to the House.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition does not object to the closed circuit television system that this motion seeks to establish. It is intended to facilitate the functioning of the Parliament. For that reason we believe it is well worth while. The one matter of concern to honourable members in this place is that if we move to the next stage of having our proceedings televised, the lights that would necessarily be included as part of that system will be very disruptive to normal debating processes in the chamber. I understand the closed circuit television system does not require any additional lighting and, therefore, it in no way will intrude on the debating function of this place. But is is important that honourable members within this chamber are able to pursue their roles without any undue intrusion as, unfortunately, tends to be the result of the very hot and fairly brilliant light that television arc lights normally impose. Having seen some chambers in which proceedings are televised, that is the one real reservation I have on the proposal to televise proceedings in this place. The Opposition does not object to the motion of the Leader of the House (Mr Young) and supports it.

—A few minutes ago I spoke to the Leader of the House (Mr Young) on this very aspect. Therefore, I ask whether he will reply to what I have to say. We have had full televising of the events in the Parliament only during the Joint Sitting of Parliament and on other brief occasions. The television lights were very dazzling and harmful to the eyes and it was extremely hot. I understand that the Senate has closed circuit television. I have not been in there recently but I understand that the brilliant lights may not be needed for closed circuit television monitors. I think this chamber is not appropriate for full televising. I have no problem with the motion apart from the question of lights. I think it is a good idea and it will facilitate the functioning of Parliament. Can the Minister in his reply elaborate a little on the lighting because that is the real worry I have on the matter?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Young The Hon M.J.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: LEADER OF THE HOUSE; SPECIAL MINISTER OF STATE

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-I assure the honourable member for Fisher (Mr Adermann) that it is my understanding that no lights are required for the monitoring cameras that would be put in for the purposes of the Whips being able to follow the proceedings of the House. I must say that it might not be a bad idea to put a monitor into the office of the Leader of the House, too, seeing I have a vested interest in this place. I understand fully the honourable member's concern and the concern of the right honourable member for New England (Mr Sinclair) about the lights. We experienced those lights during the Joint Sitting. We also had that experience recently when the proceedings of the National Economic Summit Conference were televised for a full week in this chamber. I sat through those proceedings under those lights. Some people outside this place thought that on occasions I was asleep but I was really closing my eyes to the lights because they were so glary. I know that it would be absolutely impossible to operate in this chamber with those lights on all the time.

SPEECH.PARA: I think the role of the Joint Committee on the Broadcasting of Parliamentary Proceedings was to consider whether there were some aspects of parliamentary proceedings that ought to be televised, such as Question Time or a particular debate. I do not think that that Committee has ever seriously looked at the complete televising of all parliamentary proceedings. That would present other difficulties as well. It did receive a reference during the last Parliament. It is the intention of the Government on this occasion for the Committee to complete that reference.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I seek your indulgence to pick up one point made by the Leader of the House.
—Indulgence is granted.

—As the Leader of the House (Mr Young) is considering the placement of closed circuit television monitors in his office, as Leader of the House, I suggest that it might be appropriate that his counterpart on the Opposition benches might also enjoy that facility. I think we have an equal interest in knowing what goes on in the House at any time. Perhaps an extension of this facility could be reciprocated.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr Young

TALK.START.PARA: —I think we should have one on each other, too.

INTERJECT.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: FA18 HORNET FACILITIES, ROYAL AUSTRALIAN AIR FORCE BASE, WILLIAMTOWN, NEW SOUTH WALES

PROCTEXT.PARA: Approval of Work: Public Works Committee Act

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hurford The Hon C.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That, in accordance with the provisions of the Public Works Committee Act 1969 and by reason of the urgent nature of the work, it is expedient that the following proposed work be carried out without having been referred to the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works: Royal Australian Air Force Base Williamtown, N.S.W.-F/A18 Hornet facilities development tactical fighter- time critical facilities.

The Parliament deserves an explanation as to why I have moved this motion. The proposal is for the provision of time-critical facilities at the Royal Australian Air Force Base Williamtown to ensure that the first three FA18 fighter aircraft and a FA18 flight simulator can be maintained and kept operational during the first phase of the FA18s introduction into Australia. The new facilities comprise only those that are critical for the effective continuation of pilot training and commencement of operations following the initial FA18 delivery to Williamtown in April 1985. Early commencement is also required to avoid serious aircraft noise exposure of workers employed on subsequent construction activities.

The proposal comprises the following elements: Simulator building for pilot training; avionics facilities to be fitted out with complex test equipment essential for aircraft support; relocation of engine run up essential to avoid excessive noise to construction site; extension of central store; relocation of dog complex to clear site for other works; and ancillary services including security, electrical, roads and stormwater.

I have had a look at the plans and models relating to this matter in the Sydney offices of my Department. The estimated cost of the work is $15m out of a total of $105.75m to be spent on facilities proposed at Williamtown. There will still be plenty of work for the Public Works Committee in examining this project.

The time critical works are those for which contracts have to be arranged during the period to August 1983. Failure to provide the proposed facilities in time for the scheduled introduction of the fighter aircraft would cause irrevocable delays in pilot training and other phases of introduction. Other effects would be to reduce the planned 1983-84 expenditure on the Williamtown project and delay the engagement of about 100 of those who would be employed on the project. In view of the tight construction timetable it is not feasible for the ugent works to be referred to the Public Works Committee for consideration and report. I regret this.

I value very much the work of the Public Works Committee. I understand the usual courtesies have been carried out, namely, that the Public Works Committee has been informed. The Chairman of the Committee has agreed to the move that I am making. I am very pleased that the Opposition shadow Minister, the honourable member for Farrer (Mr Fife), who I gather is the Deputy Chairman of the Committee, is in the House. I hope that the Opposition has thus been informed through the communications with the Public Works Committee. If the House agrees to support this motion, and I trust it will, detailed planning and construction can proceed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cowan Mr D.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —As a member of the Public Works Committee may I say that the Opposition agrees entirely with the proposal placed before the House today by the Minister for Housing and Construction (Mr Hurford). We appreciate the fact that this work has a time limit for actual completion and that it is necessary to call for tenders as early as practicable. I concur with the Minister when he said that the Public Works Committee had been consulted. We are very much aware of the nature of the work to be undertaken. As the Minister said , some $15m worth of work is involved. We think it is essential for this work to proceed. I think the Minister may have omitted to mention that the delay was caused primarily by the Federal election. This caused the Public Works Committee to be re-formed. We are now sitting as a committee. From our discussions the other day with the departments, it is our understanding that we will have an opportunity of probing some of the works that will be undertaken within this first contract. At the moment it is anticipated that further works be placed before the Committee. A hearing will be held at the base inside the next two or three months.

SPEECH.PARA: The Williamtown Royal Australian Air Force Base is certainly a very important part of my electorate of Lyne. It is a very important part of the Port Stephens shire area. In fact, it is an important part of the Newcastle district. The work to be undertaken, as outlined by the Minister, will create employment for many people in an area in which there is a lot of unemployment at present. We welcome the opportunity that work will be available to many of these people. Naturally, there has been some concern from the local community as to the noise factor that is involved, not only with the Mirage aircraft but also with the introduction of the FA18s. I thank the Minister and the Minister for Defence (Mr Scholes) for doing everything I believe they can to acquaint the local people, who are concerned about the noise and pollution problems surrounding the base, of the situation. The Minister for Defence has agreed that there should be a public meeting in the area. I think it is to be held on Wednesday night, 1 June. Anybody who has not been informed of the situation will certainly be informed. The Opposition has no qualms with this proposal. We welcome the fact that the work is proceeding and wish to co-operate.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: CONSTRUCTION OF NEW FACILITIES AND UPGRADING OF FACILITIES FOR NEW TACTICAL FIGHTER PROJECT, AVALON, VICTORIA

PROCTEXT.PARA: Approval of Work: Public Works Committee Act

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hurford The Hon C.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That, in accordance with the provisions of the Public Works Committee Act 1969 and by reason of the urgent nature of the work, it is expedient that the following proposed work be carried out without having been referred to the Parliament Standing Committee on Public Works: Avalon, Victoria-Construction of new works and upgrading of existing facilities for the new tactical fighter project-stage 2.

I think the House deserves an explanation. I do not enjoy moving these motions because I value very much the work done by the Public Works Committee, on behalf of the Parliament, in its scrutiny of these proposals. This proposal is for a package of 14 new works and upgrading projects at the Government Aircraft Factories, Avalon airfield to enable final assembly and flight test of the FA18 new tactical fighter aircraft. Under arrangements entered into between the Commonwealth, the United States Government and the McDonnell Douglas Corporation , the Government Aircraft Factories will be the subcontractor to McDonnell Douglas for final assembly and flight test of the aircraft.

The Government Aircraft Factories is contractually committed to a final assembly and test program at Avalon commencing with the receipt of major aircraft assemblies in May 1984. Test flying of the first completed aircraft is due to commence in November 1984. To meet its contractual obligations the Government Aircraft Factories requires the progressive completion of the 14 new works and upgrading projects within a tight time scale which requires first tenders to be called in June 1983 and contractual commitments to be entered into in July 1983.

I will tell the House of the proposal. It comprises a project office and data processing accommodation; an extension to the flight test centre; a flammable materials store; modifications to the explosives store; a liquid oxygen facility ; an ejection seat build-up and storage area; a flight test preparation shelter; the upgrading of floors; special power reticulation; services for aircraft arrestor system; taxiway upgrading; an engine run-up bay; upgrading of fire protection facilities and security upgrading. The estimated cost of the work is $9.6m.

Failure to implement the proposed works in time to meet the scheduled commencement of production operations at Avalon would result in late delivery of the first aircraft to the Royal Australian Air Force base at Williamtown. There would also be the implication of the Commonwealth's inability to honour its commitments to the United States to provide the necessary production infrastructure.

In view of the tight construction timetable and aircraft production schedule, it is not feasible, regrettably, for the project to be referred to the Public Works Committee for consideration and report.

I am grateful for the words of the honourable member for Lyne (Mr Cowan) on behalf of the Opposition in relation to the other project. Once again, I trust that the usual courtesies have been carried out and that the Opposition, as well as the Public Works Committee, has been informed. I have had word that the Chairman of the Public Works Committee agrees with this move I am making today. If the House agrees to support this motion, tendering action and construction can proceed in accordance with the critical timetable.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fife The Hon W.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition supports the motion. Of course, the work contained in that motion flows from decisions taken by the former Government. We are fully informed on what is proposed and it has our very warm support. As Vice -Chairman of the Public Works Committee I need to say that the Committee has been provided with details of this proposed work by officers of the Department of Defence Support and the Department of Housing and Construction and the Committee understands the reasons why the Government has sought exemption from scrutiny on the grounds of urgency. However, it has been brought to my attention that the former Chairman of the Public Works Committee, Mr Mel Bungey, has commented in the past that exemptions on the grounds of urgency have been rare. In fact, there were no works at all exempt on the grounds of urgency between 1974 and 1980. There has been a number of such exemptions since 1980 and I understand that the Committee can expect several more in the near future. Whilst the Committee recognises that there are special circumstances pertaining to certain projects, it is concerned that an increasing number of projects are going ahead without the very important review process inherent in examination of a work by the Public Works Committee.

SPEECH.PARA: With reference to the project at hand, this is the third exemption of works in the overall program to provide facilities for the new tactical fighter project. In between these exemptions one further work in the program was examined by the Committee in August 1982. The Committee's report on this work was very critical of certain aspects of the project and this highlights the value of scrutiny by the Public Works Committee. The Committee is aware of the very tight schedule and that the non-existence of a Committee between February and May this year was a contributing factor. Therefore, in this case the Committee does not object to the exemption now proposed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hurford The Hon C.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-In closing the debate I assure the honourable member for Farrer (Mr Fife)-I ask him , as Deputy Chairman, to pass on this message to the Standing Committee on Public Works-that it is only in the most urgent circumstances that I will be seeking exemptions of this sort. I have already stated how much I appreciate the scrutiny carried out by the Public Works Committee. Certainly it is of valuable assistance to any Minister who is unable to undertake the scrutiny in the same detail. I have been impressed, too, by the fact that officers of my Department are also very supportive of the work of the Public Works Committee.
—They are very co-operative with the Committee.

—I am glad to hear that. I am not surprised because they too value that extra scrutiny that the Committee can give to the work. Honourable members will understand that these exemptions are due mainly to the fact that we had a premature election. We had a delay between the old Committee ceasing its work and the new Committee commencing its work. I regret that this will necessitate a couple more urgent exemptions being brought before the Parliament tomorrow, but I hope that from there onwards we will be able to take most if not all of the great construction works of this country to the Public Works Committee for its scrutiny.
