DEBATE.TITLE: JOINT STANDING COMMITTEE ON THE NEW PARLIAMENT HOUSE

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Uren The Hon T.

TALKER.NAME: Mr UREN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Territories and Local Government)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) That the resolution of appointment of the Joint Standing Committee on the New Parliament House be amended by inserting after paragraph 3 the following new paragraph:
'(3A) That the committee consider and report on the use of the provisional Parliament House after it is vacated by Parliament.'.
(2) That a message be sent to the Senate acquainting it of this resolution and requesting its concurrence.

The purpose of this motion is to amend the terms of reference for the Joint Standing Committee on the New Parliament House to require that the Committee consider and report on the use of the provisional Parliament House after the building is vacated by Parliament. It is clear that a decision on the future use of the provisional House is an essential step not only in developing an overall plan for the parliamentary zone but also in determining which items of historical or artistic merit should be incorporated in the new Parliament House. In June 1982 the National Capital Development Commission published its Parliamentary Zone Development Plan. The Commission made the following point:
In the absence of any decisions about the use of the provisional Parliament House after it is vacated in 1988, it has been assumed that it will remain in its present form.

Obviously a clear decision about the building is required. It should also be recognised that detailed planning for the interior of the new Parliament House will be affected by any decisions to incorporate material from the provisional House and that, sensibly, such decisions should not be taken until the future use of the provisional House has been determined.

Perhaps the major reason for uncertainty about the provisional House is the fact that no obvious procedure exists for determining the matter. Under the Parliament Act 1974, all buildings and works within the parliamentary zone must be approved by Parliament. This motion proposes that Parliament take the initiative and establish arrangements now which will provide for a proper consideration of the future use of the provisional House and lead to an early decision being taken.

As honourable members will know, between 1972 and 1975 the Whitlam Labor Government set up an inquiry into the National Estate and later introduced the Australian Heritage Commission. It is my personal view that the building which we now occupy, particularly the part built in 1927, forms a very important part of the National Estate. I commend the motion to the House. I believe that it is a part of our national heritage. I hope-I am expressing a personal view-that in due time this building will return to its original state in 1927 and will become a proud part of our national heritage and of our National Estate. I commend the motion to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ruddock Mr P.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I signify to the Parliament the Opposition's concurrence with the motion. I understand that the Joint Standing Committee on the New Parliament House is aware of the intention to amend its resolution of appointment in this way. Obviously some flexibility has been shown by the Minister for Territories and Local Government (Mr Uren) and the Government in respect of the Committee's terms of reference. I think flexibility is important because it has been envisaged that the Committee will principally be involved in the development of the new building on the Capital Hill site. Obviously, there are some important areas-the present building is one-which are not on the Capital Hill site but the very nature of the Capital Hill development will be affected by decisions taken in respect of the wider area of the Parliamentary Triangle to which the Minister has referred.

SPEECH.PARA: I think that the original plans that were produced for the new Parliament House were widely supported because they envisaged the retention of the present building. It was thought that the new building would provide a very attractive backdrop with the present building being retained. Whilst that is not necessarily a determined view, I think it would find wide support in this place. I think the Minister has indicated his support for such a proposition by his references to the importance of the National Estate and the Heritage Commission in the previous inquiries in which he has been involved. We must have been thinking alike in a sense because when the Minister mentioned the importance of the National Estate my mind went to South Australia where the old parliament building has been maintained and developed as an important constitutional museum in which a great deal of material relevant to the development of that State and Australia has been maintained. It has been designed to provide the means by which people might become very much aware of our Constitution, our constitutional structure and, in my view, the importance of the Federation.

I welcome the flexibility in relation to extending the resolution of appointment of the Committee because inquiry into other matters by the Committee may well need to be widened. One matter that was mentioned at a meeting recently in which I was involved was the possibility of parking requirements for the new Parliament House having to be examined in a wider context than that of the actual site itself. Obviously, there are other areas of the environs of Capital Hill that might well have to be taken into account in planning for the effective use of the new Parliament House itself. I hope that the Minister will show the same flexibility in relation to any requests for a further extension of the resolution of appointment if other matters need to be looked at. I note that the Minister is on the Joint Standing Committee on the New Parliament House and no doubt he will be able to give force to his views on the way in which this matter might be examined. I certainly indicate that, for my own part as an individual, I will be very much behind him in his efforts to ensure that this building still has a proper place.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Lionel Bowen, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bowen The Hon L.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

The purpose of this Bill is to amend the Racial Discrimination Act 1975 to remedy a situation which has arisen as a result of a High Court decision which was handed down last week, on 19 May. The case arose from a complaint made under the racial discrimination provisions of the New South Wales Anti-Discrimination Act. The issue for decision by the Court was whether the racial discrimination provisions of the New South Wales Anti-Discrimination Act 1977, which is known as the State Act, were inconsistent with those of the Commonwealth Racial Discrimination Act 1975, which is known as the Commonwealth Act, and were accordingly invalid by reason of section 109 of the Constitution. In a joint judgment all five justices hearing the case unanimously held the State Act to be inconsistent with the Commonwealth Act. The Court noted that the Commonwealth Act, in dealing with the subject of racial discrimination, was doing so for the purpose of giving effect to the International Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Racial Discrimination which required the parties to the Convention to undertake to prohibit and to eliminate racial discrimination in all its forms .

The Court took the view that the Commonwealth's Racial Discrimination Act was intended to cover the whole area of racial discrimination prohibition in Australia, and therefore it was not possible for the State legislation to operate in the same field. The Court adopted the dicta of Mr Justice Dixon in the case of the State of Victoria and others v. the Commonwealth and others, which is reported in 1937, 58 Commonwealth Law Reports 618. Specific reference to his views is made at page 630 thereof.

The Government takes the view that constructive developments have taken place in some States in the field of anti-discrimination law and that Federal measures should not impinge upon those developments. The High Court decision has meant that the constructive New South Wales racial discrimination provisions are no longer effective. The New South Wales Government has asked that urgent action be taken to overcome the effect of the court decision, and the Government agrees that it is desirable to do so.

This Bill makes it clear that State and Territory legislation which furthers the objects of the Racial Discrimination Convention can stand alongside the Commonwealth legislation. The States of course will need to ensure that their legislation does further those objects and is in a form in which it is able to operate concurrently with the Commonwealth Act.

In New South Wales there were a large number of complaints in various stages of investigation when the Court decision was announced. The Bill has been drafted in such a way as to allow those cases to continue under the State legislation.

As it will be possible in many cases for a person to pursue a remedy under either Commonwealth or State law, provisions have been included to prevent a person from taking action under both laws in respect of the same matter and also to prevent the difficulty presented by double penalties. I commend this Bill to the House and express the hope that it will have an urgent passage.

TALK.START.PARA: — We on this side of the House are not opposed in principle to the Wheat Marketing Amendment Bill 1983. But I believe that in this important debate on the wheat industry it is appropriate to talk about matters of general interest and concern to that industry, particularly as it was affected by the mini-Budget on Thursday night. It is not very well known, particularly on the Government side of the House, that the Australian wheat farmer is a very efficient producer. He labours under enormous difficulties such as strike activity and the inability of the servicing sector of the industry to contain its costs.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to let Australia know how productive the average wheat farmer is. His output is enough to look after the requirements of 70 people, whereas the average American farmer feeds only about 50, the European farmer feeds 13 and the average world farmer feeds 5.5 to 6 people. Quite obviously, by any test whatsoever, the Australian farmer is very efficient and cognisance needs to be taken of that efficiency. It is a matter of very great regret indeed that the cost of wheat from the farm gate to the consumer in another part of the world and on an average basis in Australia is of the same order as it costs the farmer to produce his wheat.

A similar set of circumstances applies in the meat industry. I was a guest at the annual meeting of the Cattle Council of Australia. Its incoming president indicated to all and sundry that a beast that is worth $240 to the farmer costs a similar amount to get from the farm gate to the consumer's plate. Quite obviously, the farmer has to operate in enormously difficult areas. Similarly, we find that the farmer is grossly disadvantaged by strike activity.

I will give the House an instance of what happens in the wheat industry when strike action is taken. Taking the latest figures, those available in late 1982, we find that the cost of maintaining a ship of 24,000 tonnes was $8,000 a day. If, as we have had in many instances, there is strike activity which causes ships to lie idle in a harbour, the extra cost works out at $7 a tonne. In addition, as the payment for the wheat in such an instance was delayed by three weeks, the interest forgone was $1.75 a tonne. Quite obviously, these costs are not borne by the waterside labourer.

A report given to the annual meeting of the Cattle Council last week said that the waterside worker was subsidised by the Australian consumer by $70,000 a year . So the loss did not come from his pocket; it came from the farmer's pocket. Strikes alone last year deducted an average of $2 to $3 a tonne from the price received by the grower at the farm gate. Quite obviously, when we are talking about such an important piece of legislation as the Wheat Marketing Amendment Bill, we cannot dismiss it or sweep it under the carpet by saying that it is a simple piece of legislation, because matters of finance are of paramount importance.

Farmers, like everyone else, do not live by bread alone. I was disappointed, therefore, to find that a rather cavalier attitude was adopted by the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin) in his introduction of this legislation. I do not want to be critical of him; I just want to indicate the ad hoc approach that your Government, Mr Deputy Speaker, advances to primary industry. We were asked on Thursday night last whether we would co-operate this week in getting various pieces of legislation through the Parliament. Members of the Government are not good business managers; they are not practical people and do not understand. Quite rightly, we agreed that we would co-operate on an important piece of legislation. It was promised that I would have the Bill in my office on Monday morning. We are reasonably affable, easy-going people. Perhaps the Government is unable to understand even the time, because I got that Bill at 10.25 a.m. on Tuesday. I find that that indicates that the Government is not concerned, and nor is it interested in what happens in the wheat industry.

I acknowledge that this piece of legislation is supported by the industry. The Australian Wheat Growers Federation and the Australian Wheat Board itself are of the view that the ability to borrow off-shore will enhance the industry's competitive capability in the international market-place. Additionally, the previous Minister was supportive of the general concept of enabling the Wheat Board to borrow overseas. The concept is very much in line with Liberal Party and National Party philosophy of giving greater commercial freedom to organisations such as the Wheat Board provided that their accountability to the Parliament is maintained and that it is in the interests of the industry that they represent.

We have some reservations, however, which should be noted and, I hope, taken on board by the Government. Although this is essentially a straightforward piece of amending legislation, its ramifications could be quite far-reaching. For example , the scene could now be set for similar overseas borrowing powers to be given to the Australian Wool Corporation and other marketing authorities to enable those authorities to finance the various stockpiles held in Australia. Presumably, in the case of the Australian Wool Corporation such a facility would amount to a useful cost saving to the wool industry. But of more direct and immediate concern is the paucity of supportive information provided by the Government and the looseness of the drafting of the Bill. We have been told that the new arrangements will mean a saving to the Commonwealth of $19.8m in 1983-84 and about $30m in subsequent years. Presumably those estimates are based on past borrowings and projected crop yields. But we are talking about fairly large sums of money, and the Government should provide more precise details as to just how those estimates have been arrived at.

I hope that the Minister at the table, the Minister for Primary Industry, will answer the following query and give an explanation to the ordinary Australian farmer. The interest subsidy is to cease from 1 July. However, the Board will not be entering into any new borrowing arrangements until towards the end of the year. This means, therefore, that for some five months or so the Board will have to pay the full interest on any borrowings that it currently has. In my view-it is a practical and honest view-the Government should have at least expressed some concern about the fact that we are just coming out of a drought, that farmers have enormous debts to pay and that their plant has become run down, with buildings, fences et cetera badly in need of repair. Surely the Government could have shown a little sensitivity and could have timed the phasing out of the interest subsidy in such a way that it worked in more realistically with the Board's financial arrangements, rather than dropping it for the sake of bureaucratic tidiness at the start of the new financial year.

It has been fairly difficult for us to obtain adequate figures as to the sum involved in this forgoing of interest subsidy for a period of four or five months, until the Wheat Board is in a position to borrow overseas. The most reliable figures to which we have obtained access indicate that the Australian wheat growers will be forgoing a subsidy of about $10m. That is a very important point. I hope that the Minister will give us a clear and explicit explanation as to the reason why the subsidy arrangements will cease from 30 June this year, as stated in his amendment to section 46 of the Wheat Marketing Act. We want an explanation. We want him to come clean and let us know why his Government, very early in its life, is discriminating against farmers.

The Treasurer (Mr Keating) has told us that with the Board being able to borrow overseas there is no further need for the interest subsidy. I wonder whether the Treasurer has really thought this matter through. I can understand that he has not had the advantage of discussing it with the Minister for Primary Industry. I have had great difficulty in tracking the Minister down. He seems to be a phantom Minister. He was away for such a long time. He did not seem to do much good with his 'gentle, gentle, catchum monkey' approach in Geneva towards the sugar industry. The Treasurer may not have had advice on this 'gentle, gentle, catchum monkey' approach from the Minister. We know that at the present time the Australian Wheat Board is able to borrow within Australia through syndicated borrowings and through the issue of its own commercial Australian Wheat Board bills at a rate of interest which is below that prevailing under the Rural Credits Department of the Reserve Bank of Australia. I am concerned about whether the Treasurer and presumably the Minister, if he was here in time, really understood that the prevailing situation might not be the same in a few months time. In other words, what the Treasurer said last Thursday night-he has not contradicted it-and what he is continuing to say is that from now on, ad infinitum, the Australian Wheat Board will be able to secure finance at interest rates that are at least equivalent to or below those being charged by the Rural Credits Department of the Reserve Bank. However, the Government has given no guarantee-I think it should do so here and now-that if at any time in the future commercial interest rates in Australia and overseas are above those being charged by the RCD, the Wheat Board will have guaranteed access to those RCD funds.

On behalf of the wheatgrowers I seek the assurance of the Government that that will be so. It is absolutely essential to us that such an assurance be cemented into the legislation. It will be my intention to move an amendment in the Committee stage to ensure that what has been the right of the wheatgrowers of Australia from time immemorial will be cemented into the legislation so that there is absolutely no doubt that if, due to the inability of those who occupy the Treasury benches at present to control inflation and interest rates, interest rates rise here and overseas-we will not blame the Government for what happens overseas-the wheatgrowers of Australia will not lose that very great help that they have had. In our view the amendment is relatively simple. It appears to us that the Bill has been far too loosely drafted, even in the very few lines that it has taken the Government so many days to present to us. I understand that the reason I am speaking early in this debate today is that the Government has been unable to get its Bills printed and delivered in time, indicating that it is a government that is in tatters and does not really know how to operate the system. The Bill, as we said, does not adequately protect the interests of the industry. In due course I will move an amendment in the Committee stage. The Government seems to be unable to grasp the simple proposition that wheat growers are part and parcel of the general Australian farming community. There was absolutely no indication about the drought and post -drought aid in the statement last Thursday night. It is true that the Government moved quickly on drought aid. It included pumpkins and certain citrus products.

TALK.START.PARA: —Not apples.

—I do not know about apples but certainly pumpkins were included as eligible in respect of the fodder subsidy. The Government did not indicate whether that subsidy would be increased to cover such animals as goats. It did not indicate how long the drought assistance programs would continue. I would like to let the Government know that, notwithstanding the information it might be getting from television and radio, several areas continue to be drought affected. In case it does not realise and does not understand, the fact that it has rained does not indicate when farmers will receive incomes. It may be six months or it may be 12 months before they receive incomes. Irrespective of the amount of income they receive, they will have an enormous number of bills to pay . We hoped-surely we could have expected-that in a statement called a mini- Budget some announcement would be made about drought assistance.

We have heard nothing more about these promises. Farmers are, quite naturally, becoming increasingly concerned as to precisely what future assistance they can expect, especially in the post-drought period. I think that this is an area where the Government should have moved-

—I ask the Prime Minister: Will the Hawke Government be following the practice of its predecessor and having Australia's views put to participants in the Williamsburg Summit? What is the relevance of the Summit to Australia?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for Moore for his question. When these summits arose I believe the previous Government, sensibly, took the opportunity of briefing participants as to the view of the Australian Government in terms of trying to see that the interests of this country were protected. That practice was sensible. We applaud it and indeed this Government has followed it. Yesterday I had the opportunity of having a useful discussion with the Japanese Ambassador. As the Leader of the Opposition will recall, in the past the Japanese Government has been very useful to the Australian Government in this respect. I followed the practice of the previous Government on this matter and conveyed to His Excellency the considerations which, in our judgment, are of paramount importance in terms of protecting the interests of this country. In brief, the interests of this country which I conveyed to His Excellency and asked that he ensure were in the minds of the participants were these: I said that the fundamental concern of the Australian Government is that action should be taken to see that there is a sustained global economic recovery without rekindling inflation, particularly in the United States of America and in other major countries. I pointed out to His Excellency that such a recovery holds the key not only to improved employment prospects but also to virtually all the other issues that would be discussed at the Summit. As far as this country is concerned the fundamental issue is the question of a sustained global economic recovery.

ANSWER.PARA: I went with His Excellency to the point that the continued high level of real interest rates around the world and the related question of persistent large fiscal deficits is a matter for serious concern, certainly to this Government. Those factors have the potential to choke off any recovery that might take place . They have certainly increased the debt burdens of developing countries. They have increased also protectionist tendencies within developed countries. These matters are fundamental to the economic and social welfare of this country. I hope that honourable members opposite understand that, as I am sure the Leader of the Opposition does. I said to His Excellency quite directly-I do not think there is any room in these matters for beating around the bush-that we have a concern that at such meetings of the major economic industrialised countries there be no cosy bilateral deals done which, while perceivably in the interests of the countries concerned, can operate against the interests of Australia. I put that consideration quite directly to him.

We pointed out our concern with the interests of the developing countries. The major interest of the developing countries is that there should be a sustained global economic recovery, which would give those developing countries access to the markets of the developed countries. In that same context we put that there should be at least a sustenance in real terms of the level of developmental assistance to these countries. Finally, having conveyed those matters of fundamental concern to the interests of Australia, on my overseas visit in the near future I look forward to the opportunity of following up those issues with relevant leaders.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Prime Minister. He will remember that in Opposition the then Leader of the Opposition, Mr Hayden, the then Leader of the Opposition in the Senate, Senator Button, and a number of other senior Australian Labor Party spokesmen asserted that when Labor came to office it would abolish the Government Information Unit and the State information directors, which they said were a scandalous waste of money. Is it a fact that journalists will be appointed to the unit in the States? Is it a fact that the Australian Broadcasting Commission journalist, Mr Gary Scully, has been appointed to take over this unit? Finally, what is the difference between this new media unit and the Government Information Unit?
—This matter is being handled by the Special Minister of State.

—I thank the honourable member for Bass for his questions. He asked a number of questions and I will try to answer them all. The difference between the new National Media Liaison Service and the former Government Information Unit is that the new unit will work for the Government, not for the Australian Labor Party as the former one worked for the Liberal Party of Australia. There will be a very big difference.
—I raise a point of order, Mr Speaker. Will the Minister please explain whether Miss Linda Hornsey is working for the Labor Party--
—Order! There is no point of order.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr YOUNG

TALK.START.PARA: —All governments take very seriously the issue of providing information to the Australian community. The way in which the Government Information Unit was manipulated for political purposes under the former Government did great disgrace to the way in which governments ought to utilise these facilities. We said in Opposition that we were unhappy with the way in which these things were manipulated. Immediately on taking office, we said to those people who had been employed as ministerial appointees that their services were no longer required. We then proceeded to look at the best way to recreate what ought to be a proper unit to provide information to the Australian people. We have been very fortunate in obtaining the services of a very reputable journalist, Gary Scully, who is being employed as the director of the unit and to whom I have given the power to seek out other people who may be available to work in the States to provide the information that the people throughout Australia should have. He will not be employing political apparatchiks as the former Government did. It is not the purpose of this Government to spend money in that way.

INTERJECT.PARA: I also tell honourable members that, when the farmer from Nareen was running the Government of this country, during the election campaign-I am doing a little exercise on this-many hundreds of thousands of dollars was spent through the Government Information Unit, using a 40,000-name mailing list at Government expense to send out Liberal Party propaganda. Who do honourable members think paid for all that? It was the taxpayers of Australia. The then Government was not able to increase the unemployment benefit but it could spend millions at the behest of the headquarters of the Liberal Party. I will tell honourable members who was running the Government Information Unit under the former Government: It was not the Government, but Tony Eggleton. He was the person in charge. Many documents we went looking for after the election had gone missing in toing and froing between the director of the Liberal Party and the Government Information Unit.

The honourable member for Bass has asked a question about the unit and I invite him to follow the procedure that will be adopted by the unit in future because it will all be above board. We will answer any of the questions about it asked by the Opposition. It will be set up for the purposes for which it ought to have operated under the former Government, and will provide proper information, from professional people properly employed, to the people of Australia. People will be appointed in each of the--

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, I raise a point of order. Under the Standing Orders Ministers are supposed to be at least almost relevant. I know that Government members might enjoy this diatribe but we would like the Minister to answer the question.
—The honourable member has been here long enough to know the problem in regard to relevance. Perhaps the Special Minister of State is winding up.

—No, Mr Speaker; the honourable member's question encompassed many matters. Honourable members will recall that while we were in opposition we raised a matter which was never denied-that members of the GIU were attending campaign meetings of the Liberal Party. They were all being paid. The Unit was using more than a couple of million dollars of taxpayers' money at the behest of the Liberal Party, not of the Government of the day to do the job that ought to have been done. I can tell honourable members two things: Firstly, we will not follow the mistakes the Opposition made in wasting taxpayers' money; secondly, the Opposition will know that its Unit was a failure-ours will not be.

—Does the Minister for Health see any inconsistency between the claim of the private health insurance funds that the Government's decision to give the Health Insurance Commission primary responsibility for Medicare will result in net job loss in the overall health insurance field and their claim that they would be able to run Medicare at a lower cost than could the Health Insurance Commission?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Blewett The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for Sydney for pointing out quite clearly the discrepancy in the argument of the health insurance funds concerning the number of their employees and their ability to produce this service much more cheaply than could the public fund. Indeed, the honourable member for Mackellar, in light of the days when he claimed to be a man of some managerial expertise, should also see the discrepancy, but he seems to be blinded now by notions of socialist monsters. I say quite clearly that it is possible that in the short run the private funds could produce a costing somewhat lower than that of the public fund because they could rely on their reserves. That is possible in the very first instance. But following the running down of those reserves clearly the more cost efficient public fund would produce distinct cost advantages. I have not the slightest doubt that in the long run the public fund will produce those advantages. We had to make decisions not just for the short term but also for the long run because we are producing a health scheme which, unlike the Liberal health schemes, is designed to last. Therefore the judgments we made in the last fortnight or three weeks were related to the long term benefits to the Australian people.

ANSWER.PARA: Let me take the issue of employment. The figure of 5,000 jobs lost has been regularly cited. On all the statistics we have, that is an exaggerated figure. But let us say 5,000 jobs are potentially threatened. When one considers, firstly, that a further 3,000 jobs will be provided in the Medicare organisation itself and we have requested the Health Insurance Commission to give preference to employees of private funds in filling these 3,000 jobs and, secondly, that there is a staff turnover rate of nearly 20 per cent a year in the private funds , one understands that there is a natural run-down in those funds. Thirdly, one should notice that the Minister for Health in New South Wales has already offered to work with us in also providing preferential employment in similar clerical occupations. We have put together a quite effective employment scheme in relation to this problem. Given the statements of some of the representatives of the private funds since the decision was taken, it seems that the funds are quite likely to be prepared to co-operate with us. Unlike the honourable member for Mackellar, they have made reasoned and constructive statements on what was for the Government a difficult and tough decision.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Treasurer. Will widows, on the death of their husbands, be forced to pay the lump sum tax on superannuation payments? Will only registered redundancy payments not be taxed? Will forced retirees through serious accident-for example, a person who becomes a paraplegic-be forced to pay the lump sum tax? Will workers who by dint of their vocation are itinerant or mobile be forced to pay the tax? Can the Treasurer indicate how the Government's decision will operate in these cases, or is it a fact, as Mr Crean has said, that the whole decision is still negotiable?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —First of all, let me correct the last point by saying that Mr Crean never at any stage said or tried to indicate that the decision is still negotiable. What the Government did last week, which the former Government, of course, failed to do for seven years, was deal with the major distortion in the tax system in respect of the tax on 5 per cent of lump sum superannuation payments so that over time we will get back to the original intent and purpose of the Commowealth's subsidy in respect of retirement income which will amount to roughly $2,000m this year. We took that in principle decision which was announced last Thursday and we indicated that there would be no retrospective element of the decision.

ANSWER.PARA: The Government, of course, could have finalised all details by last Thursday but that would have been very unfair to all of the people concerned, including the categories of persons nominated by the honourable member for Mitchell and particularly the life assurance and superannuation industries. A meeting on some of these matters was held yesterday between officers of my Department, the Department of Finance and the Australian Taxation Office and representatives of the superannuation and life assurance industries. A number of matters, including some of those referred to today by the honourable member for Mitchell, were discussed. The meeting discussed such things as the formula for determining how much the pre-announcement entitlements would be, how to make annuities more attractive and questions relating to portability. The Government will be considering the results of that meeting later in the week, the matter will be put before Cabinet probably next Monday and a comprehensive statement will be made thereafter. I also intend to release the report of the task force on superannuation commissioned by the former Government, which was presented to it in January. That report, which will be released for public consumption later this day or tomorrow, indicates the views which were put by the task force established by the former Government and upon which it, of course, failed to act .

I also make the point that Mr Crean this morning on the radio program AM referred to some questions which the Australian Council of Trade Unions had about the scheme. He referred principally to the question of portability. I indicated last Thursday night that there will be a portability factor, that people who shift from one area of employment to another within a short space of time will have portability maintained though the general question of portability for a more extended period is, again, subject to discussion at the moment. Last Friday the ACTU indicated that it would like to have a meeting with the Government on these matters. We have indicated that we will have such a meeting. We will probably have it later this week or early next week. I make a point of saying, in respect of some other comments that were passed by the Secretary of the Labor Council of New South Wales, that they will be taken into account also. I might just indicate that the Government has no intention of being pilloried by any section of the community, including the Labor Council of New South Wales, on this issue. We made a decision to see the ACTU before Mr Unsworth made any comments about superannuation and we will be seeing the ACTU. Unlike the former Government, when a statement on a final package is determined by all interest groups it will stand as an important, substantial and comprehensive change to the tax laws of Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —I draw the attention of the Minister for Health to a report that over the last 20 years approximately 200,000 tons of potentially radioactive sand has been distributed to householders and builders in South East Queensland and ask: Is he aware that the Queensland Health Department has now notified over 100 Brisbane householders that they have filled their yards with sand which has a level of radioactivity which exceeds National Health and Medical Research Council safety levels? Is he further aware that these and many other householders are suffering stress as a result of (a) the Queensland Government's direction that they pay for removal of the sand; and (b) long delays in having their sand tested for radioactivity? Also, will he draw the attention of his State counterpart to the need for the Queensland Government to meet its responsibilities to Queenslanders who are exposed to this health hazard?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Blewett The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for Lilley for her question. The Government is concerned about what appears to be an abrogation of public health responsibilities by the Queensland Government. People who have found that their yards are filled with radioactive sand are being charged between $8,000 and $22, 000 to have that sand removed. For many this is a burden that they cannot bear. It does seem to be a very clear area of State responsibility. One could argue, quite clearly, that the Queensland Government should have been monitoring these sands, or tailings, from Moreton Island and the Gold Coast. Such monitoring has taken place in other States since the 1960s, so there seems to have been a failure on the part of the Queensland Government in that respect.

ANSWER.PARA: Moreover, now that it is known that people have unknowingly used this sand to fill their backyards, there seems to be a clear responsibility on the part of the Queensland Government to make up for this neglect in monitoring and identifying the problem in previous years. Public health is very much a State matter and I would urge the Queensland Minister for Health to have the matter fully investigated and to take action to help those who have unwittingly become victims of this problem.

In relation to one other point made by the honourable member, I say that I am disturbed by the long delays that are occurring in responding to applications for testing of the backyards of the people concerned. I know of at least one case in which application was made on 27 October last and the tests have still not taken place. Therefore, despite some of the assertions that have been made by the Queensland Minister for Health, there do seem to be very long delays in having these tests carried out, which suggests that a very large number of people are very much concerned.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: DEFENCE FORCE RETIREMENT AND DEATH BENEFITS SCHEME

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister for Defence whether he recalls saying to Mr William Pinwell of the Australian newspaper, on or about 4 March 1983, that the Australian Labor Party has no proposals to change the Defence Force Retirement and Death Benefits Scheme 'to the disadvantage of service personnel'? Will the announcement by his colleague the Treasurer last Thursday mean that lump sum payments made under the DFRDB Scheme for service after 19 May will be subject to taxation at the standard tax rate of 30 per cent? For example, will this mean that a chief petty officer of the Royal Australian Navy, or his equivalent in the Australian Army or the Royal Australian Air Force, who would now be entitled to receive approximately $36,000 after 20 years service, will retain only $24, 000 of such an entitlement for service which takes place after 19 May? In what way does he reconcile this consequence with his undertaking of 4 March?

—I am surprised that the honourable member does not know the difference between the conditions of a superannuation retirement scheme and taxation provisions which apply to the general community. There has been no alteration in the DFRDB Scheme.
—I ask the Minister for Housing and Construction whether he can inform the House of the response to the Government's new housing assistance program?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hurford The Hon C.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am very pleased to inform the honourable member for Chisholm and the House that the response to the Hawke Labor Government's housing package has been magnificent. The only exception has been the mean, contradictory and inadequate response of the Opposition.

ANSWER.PARA: Opposition members interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The House will come to order.

—It so happens, perchance, that I have with me a copy of some of the Press releases that have been issued. I will quote from the Press releases of the Housing Industry Association; the Australian Association of Permanent Building Societies; National Shelter, that wonderful organisation that looks after the housing consumers; the Real Estate Institute of Australia; and Jennings Industries Ltd. All of these Press releases are indicative of the universal support that the Government has received for its housing package. I know that the House will want me to quote from some of these Press releases. I start with the Press release from the Housing Industry Association. It states:

ANSWER.PARA: . . . the Government has set the scene for sustainable recovery in the housing industry and the creation of many thousands of new jobs.

Moreover, the substantial increase in the allocation of funds for public housing programs will give real hope to many disadvantaged families in our community who are in urgent need of housing assistance.

In taking what must be seen as a series of difficult decisions, the Government has substantially improved prospects for lower interest rates, which is good news for both the industry and home seekers.
Government members-More.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank honourable members. I note that they want more. I will oblige. I quote from the Press release of the Australian Association of Permanent Building Societies. It states:

ANSWER.PARA: In essence the decisions mean that many thousands of young homeseekers will not have to defer their decision to buy their own home. The scheme is flexible and well targeted. The introduction of means testing for all on-going housing assistance schemes is a responsible solution to a difficult problem.
Mr Tony Dalton of National Shelter says:
. . . the Labor Government had, within the context of a general redistribution, moved towards a more equitable housing policy.
I welcome in particular . . . to the increase in the chances to those on lower incomes to move into public housing where they experience a real level of security.
I will not-well, I will.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I suggest to the Minister that he not change his mind midstream. I invite him to wind up his answer.

—I do that only in deference to you, Mr Speaker. I think I will be disappointing many people; nevertheless I will point out that in order to ensure that the public could be fully informed about the new proposals, I instructed my Department to operate a number of hotlines in each of the major cities across the country. I am indebted to honourable members, at least on my side of the House, for referring many housing inquiries to those hotlines. I want to say to the House that the response has been--
—Mr Speaker, I raise a point of order. I think we have had enough of this answer.
—That interjection is just one more example of the Opposition not being interested in the housing of this nation.
—Mr Speaker, I raise a point of order. I am wondering whether the Minister could advise the interested members of this House of the phone numbers of the hot lines.
—Yes, I could, but I will not do so now.
—I do not know whether the honourable member for Cook wants that counted as a question. I invite the Minister to wind up his reply.

—I will wind up by saying that the response to 11 o'clock this morning was that 6,835 inquiries had been put to those hotlines. That is an indication of how magnificent the Government's housing package is.

—My question is directed to the Treasurer. Are recent Press reports correct in saying that the Treasury has increased its early March forecast of gross domestic product growth next financial year from 0.5 per cent to more than 4 per cent and for non-farm GDP from 1.5 per cent to more than 3 per cent? If so , why did the Treasurer conceal these figures from the nation in his economic statement? Finally, if that is not the case, what are the latest growth forecasts available to the Government?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The former Treasurer well knows and understands that there is no obligation on me, as there was not on him, to give a monthly forecast of the state of the economy in the ensuing year. I indicated in the Summit scenarios, and particularly in the illustrative scenario which I took in respect of the speech I gave to the Summit, that the projection was an average of 2.1 per cent in 1983-84, based upon that particular scenario.
—That is the forecast, is it?

—No, that was in respect of that scenario, given certain wage and deficit assumptions. In respect of more general ongoing assessments and forecasts which the Treasury does from time to time, they are being done at the moment and will be in my hands at some time, understandably before the next Budget. Therefore, I just do not see the point of the honourable gentleman's question. I noticed in his speech yesterday that the former Treasurer was trying to make a fairly weak case for the $9.6 billion blowout of the Budget deficit.

ANSWER.PARA: Mr Speaker, you may remember that last week in a speech I gave in relation to the Summit, I asked the Opposition to indicate what it would do in respect of the fiscal position we face. I tell the House, for the benefit of those who did not listen yesterday, that neither the Leader of the Opposition nor the former Treasurer attempted to indicate or quantify in any way precisely what he would do with the fiscal position. There was no comment made about the specific measures undertaken by the Government, except condemnatory ones. I just observe that the former Treasurer indicated that as far as he was concerned-this was the only inkling I got from his speech- he would give effect to his statement after the election that the Opposition would not tolerate, if it had won the election, a $9.6 billion deficit, and that he would remove the tax cut which his Government gave. In other words, he virtually confirmed yesterday that we were to have a re-run of 1977 all over again. People could ring up to find out how much the tax cut was and then find it was taken away the following May.

I indicate also that, in respect of the cost cutting exercise to which references were made yesterday, the former Government took six months to come to a long term saving of $560m as compared with the longer term savings of the proposals by the Government last Thursday of $2,000m. I also indicate that outlays as a proportion of gross domestic product by the former Government-given the fact that that was the Government that was going to rein in Labor's extravagances, pull back the size of the public sector and do all these things- were 30.1 per cent in 1975, when that Government came to power, and they remain at 30.2 per cent. So much for the vigour of the former Government in dealing with the fiscal position. I conclude on this issue: I do not mind being asked questions which seek information, on the basis that honourable members are entitled to be given it at a certain point in time, but the former Treasurer well understands and knows that there was never any requirement on him or attempt by him to provide monthly forecasts on the economy, and I do not intend to start doing that now.

TALK.START.PARA: —Will the Special Minister of State advise whether the electoral offices had sufficient funds to carry out all their duties leading up to and during the last Federal elections?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Young The Hon M.J.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: LEADER OF THE HOUSE; SPECIAL MINISTER OF STATE

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for Hindmarsh. As the Opposition and people throughout Australia would know, we place great significance on the electoral laws and their operation in this country, and that means the proper operation of the Australian Electoral Office itself. As honourable members are more than aware at present, because of the operations of the Commonwealth Electoral Act and its sections affecting a redistribution, if the population trends continue this year as they were given in the latest statistics in the next redistribution Victoria will lose one division and Queensland will gain one . Under another section of the Act, wherever there is a State in which more than a quarter of the seats are outside the 10 per cent tolerance that also requires a redistribution; so Western Australia, New South Wales and Queensland, under that section of the Act, are also required to have a redistribution. So if there is to be a total redistribution of the electorates of this country, the necessity for the Electoral Office to carry out a thoroughgoing and complete habitation review is in the interests of everyone in this country.

ANSWER.PARA: What happened under the previous Government, which aroused so much suspicion, was that it gave the Electoral Office only sufficient funds to do about a 50 per cent habitation review. One has the thought that perhaps it was directed at what may be the more beneficial aspects of the review that would have assisted the Liberal Party and the National Party rather than the democratic processes of Australia. If a habitation review is to be done before a complete electoral redistribution, it must be done everywhere for everyone. It cannot be done in sections of the country so that it arouses suspicion that it was done to the advantage of one group against another.

The other significant feature about the last election was the disgraceful way in which it was called, which gave only 24 hours for people to get their names on the roll. In those 24 hours, 55,000 people throughout this country enrolled. In 1980, when a longer period of about a week was available for people to get their names on the roll after the election was announced, 260,000 people enrolled. So there can be no doubt that the former Prime Minister deliberately closed the rolls early so that, as he thought, between 250,000 and 300,000 people would be denied the right to vote on 5 March. There is also no doubt that the former Prime Minister and perhaps his Ministers-we do not know to what extent his Ministers were involved in this decision making process-must have reached the conclusion that many of those people, who were young, unemployed, had just left school, and so forth, would not have been terribly sympathetic to the fortunes of the Liberal Party and the National Party at that election on 5 March. So the action was taken deliberately to see that the rolls were closed quickly so that these people would be denied the right to vote. None of those practices will be tolerated in future. Everyone will have plenty of advice.
Opposition members interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —The boundaries are another thing, and they are subject to the electoral commissioners. No Minister of this Government will interfere with the electoral commissioners, unlike a Minister of the previous Government.

ANSWER.PARA: Opposition members interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —If the electoral commissioners in Victoria decide that the division of Kooyong is to go, it is to go.
—Order! I invite the Special Minister of State to reply to the question and not to supplementary questions he is receiving.

—It is the desire of this Government to see that all the practices of the Electoral Office, and the laws affecting its operations, are carried out on behalf of all Australians and not individual political parties. I hope that, when the Parliament agrees to the change, the people will get no less than seven days notice of the closing of the rolls. There will be a complete habitation review and the Government will make the resources available to the Electoral Office to see that this is done. Extra teams will be made available to see that Aboriginal enrolment is properly carried out throughout this country, not like under the former Government when insufficient resources were made available for these things. The Electoral Office, which is so important to the proper operations of this Parliament, will return to its traditional role of seeing that all Australians have a say in the proper running of their country.

—Can the Minister for Science and Technology advise the House of the latest developments in that exciting breakthrough for the deaf, colloquially known as the bionic ear? Is surgery now being undertaken on Australian patients and, if so, where is that surgery taking place?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Jones The Hon B.O.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for Fisher for his question without notice. By a strange coincidence I happen to have a bionic ear with me, although it would not do much to improve the audibility of some of the honourable members opposite. It is a remarkable Australian breakthrough from a very interesting co- operative venture between an innovative Australian firm, Nucleus Ltd in Sydney, and the research team at Melbourne University under Professor Graeme Clark. Part of the mastoid bone is excised and in the hollow underneath the bionic ear is inserted. It uses the very latest technology. It is estimated that the worldwide market value of this will be of the order of $500m per annum. It is the greatest technique for dealing with the problems of the profoundly deaf anywhere in the world and it is a great Australian breakthrough.

ANSWER.PARA: I pay tribute to what has been done under the Australian Industrial Research and Development Incentives Scheme. I must pay tribute to the contribution of the former Minister, but we have upgraded the project. We are now in phase four. Six operations have already been carried out in Melbourne. We hope that, as the project is upgraded and we are able to obtain world markets, the unit cost will fall considerably. The bionic ear will present an entirely new life to people who have suffered from profound nerve deafness. I think we, as a parliament, ought to be extremely proud of this leading edge technology that has been developed by first class research people and a first class industrial enterprise in Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is also directed to the Minister for Science and Technology. Is it a fact that a contract has been signed between a research team at the Howard Florey Institute and the Australian National University and the American firm Genentech for the production of the human birth hormone, relaxin? If that is so, why was a contract not signed with an Australian biotechnology firm?

—The point raised by the honourable member for Grey is absolutely correct. It illustrates the bad side of what was done in the field of science and technology by the previous Government. The previous Government did contribute to certain areas. It deserves some recognition for the work it promoted on the bionic ear. But, in many ways, the research capacity of much of Australian industry was wound down. The fact is that our universities had to look elsewhere for funding because they had to work under unacceptable staff ceilings, because they were deprived of funds. The good news that the honourable member's question draws attention to is that it is a remarkable world breakthrough. Dr Hugh Niall's team at the Howard Florey Institute and John Shine 's team at the Australian National University won, in a sense, a great international race to be the first to produce the human birth hormone, relaxin. Relaxin enables an expansion of the birth canal so that children can be born without the use of instruments and so on. It is potentially of enormous significance throughout the world. It is a fact that no Australian firms were technologically capable of taking up the development and production of relaxin in a commercial way. There are six elements--
—Will you mention the $400,000 grant?

—Of course there was, but the honourable member will have his opportunity to reply later. His Government has been judged already by the people of Australia for what it failed to do. At this stage in Australia we do not have the scientific base which would enable us to have this drug developed economically and put on the market. Six elements are needed to do this: Gene synthesis, cloning, computer-controlled fermentation, isolation techniques, micro-sequencing and biological testing. We have several of those elements in some firms but not all six. We have had to obtain funds from overseas for a whole number of first rate projects. Agrigenetics Research Associated Ltd of the United States has invested $2m in developing nitrogen-fixing plants in Australia . We could not find the money in this country. We could not find the money from the previous Government. It is good that the project is going out to the world. It is a tragedy that, at this stage of development, the project had to go to American firms to be developed. I hope this is a precedent that in the future is honoured in the breach and not in the observance.

TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Territories and Local Government)
