SPEECH.SPEAKER: Newman The Hon K.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, I wish to make a personal explanation.
—Does the honourable member claim to have been misrepresented?
—Yes, I do.
—The honourable member may proceed.

—Today in answering two questions the Special Minister of State (Mr Young) made extremely serious allegations which reflected on my administration of two areas: Firstly, the Government Information Unit and, secondly, the Australian Electoral Office. In the first case the Special Minister of State alleged two serious things: Firstly, he said that Tony Eggleton, the Federal Director of the Liberal Party, ran the Government Information Unit. If I heard him correctly he said that there was documentation to prove that case. That is a disgraceful allegation which is completely untrue. I challenge the Minister to bring in the documentation to show us. Secondly, the Minister said that members of the Government Information Unit were involved in Liberal Party campaigns. Such an allegation was made but was refuted completely. Since the election I have had correspondence with the Minister for Industry and Commerce, Senator Button, pointing out that allegations which were made in the Senate at that time were wrong. I went to great lengths to show that a member of the Government Information Unit, a very reputable journalist, was being maligned. I am quite happy to table the correspondence I had with Senator Button. On those two issues I have geen grievously maligned. The Minister has used disgraceful tactics in this place and, in fact, has misrepresented the case completely.

SPEECH.PARA: There is another and probably even more important matter. The Minister, in the answer regarding the Australian Electoral Office, made allegations of quite serious dimensions. He will have to prove the case or apologise. He said that habitation reviews had been jacked, that the former Government had gone to the Australian Electoral Office and had used the habitation reviews in a selective way. It was implicit in that that we had directed the Australian Electoral Office to go to certain divisions to somehow conduct reviews which would favour us.

TALK.START.PARA: —That would be right.

—If that is correct I ask the Minister to prove the point; otherwise he should apologise. It is a very serious charge. As the Minister who was in charge of the Electoral Office I deny it completely. As I have said: Let the Minister either prove the case or come into this place and apologise. There is a further point. The Minister said that the former Prime Minister had arranged things so that 18-year-olds and others on the electoral lists would be excluded from voting. That is also totally false. I ask him to produce the proof that would show that that had happened. The reality is that a time was fixed for an election which meant that the Electoral Office, working backwards, had to close the roll to make the election happen.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Young The Hon M.J.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: LEADER OF THE HOUSE; SPECIAL MINISTER OF STATE

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, I wish to make a personal explanation.
—Does the Minister claim to have been misrepresented?
—Yes.
—He may proceed.

—I do not think the honourable member for Bass (Mr Newman) was listening to what I said. I will try to go through my remarks again. I did not cast aspersion on his administration. I cast aspersion on his Government's policy of handling these matters. If the Australian Electoral Office is denied funds to carry out a complete habitation review, it is the policy of the Government under which the honourable member served which is to blame. It would have been the honourable member's desire, I would have hoped, to see that the Electoral Office had the resources that it required. It did not have them. I did not say that the honourable member went to the Electoral Office and said: 'Do a selective habitation review'. What I said was that because it was less than a full habitation review it aroused suspicions about why it was less than a full habitation review.

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable member raised another matter concerning documents. I did not say that there were documents to prove the allegation of the involvement of the Liberal Party, but what I do say is this: Stories came to us in the then Opposition that documents were available in the Government Information Unit which showed a direct link between the Federal Director of the Liberal Party and the Government Information Unit. We do not seem to be able to find any such documentation. That is what I said. Nevertheless, the accusations which were made by the Minister for Industry and Commerce, Senator Button-as honourable members are well aware-about GIU people attending Liberal Party campaign committees were made some months prior to the election.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, I wish to make a personal explanation. It is on a further misrepresentation by the Special Minister of State.
—I will allow the honourable member to proceed but I remind honourable members that personal explanations must be to correct any misrepresentation.
—This is in relation to a direct misrepresentation, Mr Speaker.
—The honourable member may proceed.

—In the explanation which the Minister just gave he said that during my administration I did not provide enough money for proper habitation reviews. I am speaking from memory and this may need correction but I am almost certain that what I am about to say is 100 per cent correct. In fact, last year the Australian Electoral Office was given sufficient funds for a comprehensive habitation review. The reason why it was not completed was simply that there was an election called on 5 March before it was completed.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Report and Ministerial Statement

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beazley The Hon K.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the report of the Chairman of the Board of Accident Inquiry on an accident of a Beech Super King Air 200 aircraft VH-AAV at Mascot, New South Wales, on 21 February 1980.

SPEECH.PARA: Motion (by Mr Beazley)-by leave-agreed to:

That this House, in accordance with the provisions of the Parliamentary Papers Act 1908, authorises the publication of the Report of the Chairman of the Board of Accident Inquiry on an Accident to Beech Super King Air 200 Aircraft VH-AAV at Mascot, New South Wales, on 21 February 1980.
Sitting suspended from 12.57 to 2.15 p.m.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-As honourable members may recall, on the evening of 21 February 1980 the Beech Super King Air 200 aircraft registered VH-AAV, operated by Advance Airlines of Australia, crashed soon after take-off from Sydney Airport on a commuter flight to Temora and the 13 people on board were killed. The Air Safety Investigation Branch of the then Department of Transport carried out an investigation into the circumstances of the accident.

SPEECH.PARA: On 22 September 1981, the then Minister for Transport tabled in the Parliament the investigator's report relating to the accident. My colleague the Minister for Transport (Mr Peter Morris), who was of course at that time the Opposition spokesman on transport, called for a royal commission to investigate all the circumstances of the accident. On 24 September 1981 the then Minister for Transport accounced that, in the public interest, a Board of Accident Inquiry would be convened to inquire into the causes of the crash. Consequently, a three -man Board of Accident inquiry was appointed on 14 October 1981 with Sir Sydney Frost, Q.C., as Chairman.

The Board presented its report to my predecessor in office on 25 February 1983. I am aware that the then Minister for Aviation expressed to the Chairman of the Board and to the assessors his Government's appreciation of the painstaking manner in which they carried out their examination of the circumstances of this tragic accident. Honourable members will find, after reading the report of the Board of Accident Inquiry, that the Board's conclusions are consistent with those reached in the Air Safety Investigation Branch report and the Board has stated that it was greatly assisted by the investigator's report and that it is satisfied that all relevant aspects of the accident were considered.

The Board, in this report, finds that there were a number of factors which, in combination, and on the balance of probabilities, contributed to the accident to VH-AAV. Those factors included the use of reduced take-off power, the failure of the left engine due to fuel contamination, high pilot work load and the fact that the auto propeller feathering and auto engine ignition systems were not armed. The Board also indicated that there were errors on the part of the pilot but, in the Board's opinion, the errors were not culpable because of the combination of adverse circumstances which the pilot faced during the emergency, which required a standard of skill beyond that of the average pilot.

The Board has observed, too, that the operator of the aircraft, Advance Airlines, had included in its operations manual the use of a technique involving reduced power for take-off. The Board also observed that the departmental examiner of airmen responsible for the surveillance of the company's operations was aware of this practice and had committed an error of judgement in not reporting the matter to his superior officers because in his opinion there could be no objection to it.

Although the Board has commented that it was most unfortunate that the Department did not act earlier on the matter of reduced take-off power, a practice which appeared to have been introduced by some operators without departmental approval, I must say that when the circumstances of this accident became known it is clear that the Department took swift action to ensure that the reduced power take-off technique was restricted only to those types of aircraft for which the appropriate procedure had been approved.

The Board has also drawn attention to what it considered to be a surprising design feature of the Beech Super King Air nacelle tank fuel strainer, and I can assure the House that my Department is pursuing this matter with the manufacturer of the aircraft. Investigation to date does not indicate the need for any modification of the strainer. The Board has, however, emphasised the need for meticulous attention to regular fuel drains of the sump of the nacelle tank of this type of aircraft and my Department is again reminding operators that regular fuel drains from all drain points in aircraft fuel systems are a requirement essential to flight safety.

The Board has made a number of recommendations relating to the crew complement of commuter aircraft, the auto ignition and auto feathering systems, asymmetric flight training and flight recorders. As to the crew complement of commuter aircraft, the Board has recommended that a minimum crew of two pilots be required on aircraft which are pressurised or have normal cruise speeds in excess of 250 knots true airspeed and operate into primary airports.

Honourable members may be aware that supplementary airline licences have recently been introduced for commuter operations following a review of domestic air transport policy. This supplementary airline licence requires compliance with operating standards which were upgraded after a detailed study of commuter operations commenced in 1979. This study examined the circumstances of significant accidents and incidents which had occurred in those operations. The revised standards embrace a number of amendments suggested by the industry in consultations which commenced in 1980. Arising from this study one of the measures taken by the Secretary to my Department earlier this year was to issue an air navigation order requiring all aircraft licensed to carry 10 passengers or more in supplementary airline services to be crewed by two pilots as from 1 July 1983.

The Board's proposal, however, suggests different criteria which I do not believe would achieve the safety objective implicit in the criteria adopted by my Department. Commuter operations now carry almost one million passengers a year and many routes previously served by the major airlines are now served by commuter operators. While it is extremely important that air services to these communities be maintained, there is also a need to ensure that passengers are afforded a safety level as close to airline standards as it is possible to achieve with this class of aircraft.

I am mindful that the introduction of two-pilot crews to supplementary airline operations from 1 July 1983 will impose a cost penalty on those operators directly affected by it. A number of those operators, however, will receive benefit by the easing of the requirement for the carriage of cabin attendants from a complement of 16 passengers to a complement of 19 passengers where the additional pilot is carried. Additionally, my Department has agreed to reduce fuel reserve requirements in some circumstances and it is expected that this assistance will be available before 1 July. Again, the matter of the availability of lower take-off minima where aircraft are equipped with an auto feather system is being examined on an individual operator basis and this may be approved in some circumstances.

Another matter of concern to operators is that the United States of America in recent years introduced a new class of aircraft certification entitled Special Federal Aviation Regulation-SFAR-41 which permits an increase in the operating weights of some commuter aircraft. As a result of submissions by the industry, my Department is currently reviewing this complex technical matter. An officer is about to go overseas to obtain first hand knowledge from other regulatory authorities as to the reasons for their acceptance or rejection of this aircraft certification role adopted by the USA. The outcome of this review will be made known to industry as soon as possible. Having made these points and being very conscious of the commuter industry's present economic situation, I am nevertheless of the opinion that the Department's requirement for two pilot crews on aircraft licensed to carry 10 passengers or more is necessary and this is to be introduced from 1 July 1983.

Turning to other recommendations of the Board, my Department is studying the implications of the Board's recommendations that an auto feather system be required to be fitted where it is available at the time of purchase of the aircraft and it has already acted on the recommendation that King Air 200 operators include in the 'on take-off role' section of their cockpit check lists a check that the auto ignition system is armed and operating. The Board, in its recommendations, also draws attention to the training and checking of pilots in asymmetric procedures following an engine failure immediately after take-off.

The handling of the aircraft immediately following take-off was, the Board considers, a factor of major importance in this accident. While my Department already has training requirements and an educational program to ensure asymmetric flying proficiency, the matter is being looked at again in the light of the Board's recommendation. The Board has recommended that asymmetric training in light twin engine aircraft should be carried out at a simulated take -off weight rather than in an empty aircraft.

For the information of honourable members, to simulate flight at maximum take- off weight power on the live, or operating engine, is reduced. I am informed that, while this practice can be satisfactory for asymmetric training in transport category aircraft, my Department is of the view that it should be approached with great caution in respect of the aircraft being used in commuter operations. My Department would be most reluctant to introduce such a requirement as it could, in some circumstances, introduce a real hazard into the training operation in the types of aircraft used in commuter operations.

The Board has also commented on the need for commuter aircraft to carry flight recorders-both cockpit voice recorders and flight data recorders-and has recommended that the search for lightweight, inexpensive recording equipment, suitable for light aircraft use should continue so that it may be required to be installed in commuter aircraft when feasible. As the Board points out, there was no means of ascertaining precisely the sequence of events on VH-AAV's fatal flight. No doubt the length of this inquiry could have been shortened significantly if there had been available some flight recording of the sequence of events. As the Board notes, flight recorders have long been recognised by aviation authorities throughout the world as valuable aids to accident investigation and my Department will continue its quest for suitable recording equipment for light aircraft. When such equipment is developed, and available, consultations will be held with the aviation industry before implementing requirements for its carriage in commuter and other general aviation aircraft.

Turning to the Board's remarks on airworthiness surveillance, the report recommends a system of surprise checks of maintenance organisations which have attracted criticism in routine surveillance reports by airworthiness surveyors. While my Department accepts the need for follow-up checks to ensure that deficiencies have been corrected, it does not believe that unannounced inspections are necessarily the best means of achieving the Board's aim. My Department, however, is considering the introduction of a system of formal acquittal of reported deficiencies. I am taking steps to ensure that necessary manpower resources are available to my Department to provide an adequate surveillance of the aviation industry.

Whilst this tragic accident, which claimed 13 lives, has blemished our high safety record, it must be remembered that commuter operations are the fastest growing element of this nation's aviation industry and, as I have already mentioned, they now carry almost one million passengers a year. I am sure that honourable members will agree, after reading the Board's report, that the Board has not only thoroughly discharged its terms of reference but also has focused attention on a number of matters of significance to aviation safety. I present the following paper:
Aircraft Accident-Report and Ministerial Statement, 25 May 1983.
Motion (by Mr West) proposed:
That the House take note of the papers.
Debate (on motion by Mr Fife) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: PROTECTION OF THE SEA (PREVENTION OF POLLUTION FROM SHIPS) BILL 1983

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill received from the Senate, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Morris The Hon P.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

I am pleased to introduce into the House this package of two Bills concerning the protection of Australia's marine environment against pollution. The purpose of the Bills is to give effect to the 1973 International Convention for the Prevention of Pollution from Ships as modified by the 1978 protocol. The Convention is widely referred to as the MARPOL 1973-78 Convention. The Bills currently before the House are essentially the same as those introduced by the previous Government on 21 October 1982. As the House is aware, the Government views very seriously the need for Australia to accede to and honour international conventions, not only in the transport field, which is my responsibility, but also in other affected areas such as the environment. Our national transport policy states explicitly that we will promote the conclusion, ratification and application of transport conventions under the auspices of the United Nations and its specialised agencies.

The particular subject of attention by this Bill is, of course, basically environmental in its origins and effects, and I believe it is important to note the way in which concern for the marine environment has been incorporated so effectively. Australia has an extensive coastline and spread of territorial waters. It is fundamentally important that we be able to demonstrate to ourselves and the international community that we take our responsibility for this national and global resource seriously, and that we are committed to its protection.

The MARPOL Convention is a departure from previous pollution conventions in that it addresses all the various forms of ship-sourced pollution in one treaty. The Convention contains five annexes which deal respectively with pollution by oil, noxious liquid substances carried in bulk form, noxious substances carried in packaged form, sewage and garbage. Initially, Australia will implement only the compulsory annexes I and II of MARPOL 1973-78-that is, those dealing with oil and bulk noxious liquids. In addition we will defer the operation of Annex II for the three years permitted by Article II of the 1978 protocol to ensure that adequate reception facilities for the discharge of tank washings and sludge are provided at Australian ports.

The Commonwealth, States and Northern Territory are examining, in the forum of the Marine and Ports Council of Australia, the provisions of annexes III, IV and VB in order to arrive at a recommendation concerning their acceptance by Australia. The findings of this examination may well make it necessary to amend, in due course, the legislation currently before the House. The construction of the Commonwealth Bills is based on the jurisdictional arrangement recommended by the Marine and Ports Council of Australia which requires that complementary Commonwealth, State and Northern Territory legislation be enacted before Australia can ratify MARPOL 1973-78. The proposal is therefore in accordance with current arrangements between the Commonwealth, States and Northern Territory. The MARPOL Convention will be applied legislatively in Australia by two Commonwealth Acts and by State and Territory legislation. Implementation by two Commonwealth Acts continues the traditional way of giving effect to pollution control legislation.

The Protection of the Sea (Prevention of Pollution from Ships) Bill 1983 will, upon proclamation, repeal and replace the Protection of the Sea (Discharge of Oil from Ships) Act 1981 which applies the provisions of the 1954 International Convention for the Prevention of Pollution of the Sea by Oil known as OILPOL. The Bill also contains provisions imposing discharge prohibitions, the obligation to carry and maintain oil and cargo record books on ships and to report any discharges. Matters pertaining to the construction, survey and certificate requirements of ships will be given effect in the Navigation Act. This method of giving effect to MARPOL 1973-78 has been adopted for simplicity of administration and understanding by the industry. This Bill introduces new and improved provisions for oil pollution prevention and control including special arrangements for protection of the Great Barrier Reef. This particular issue was included in the 1981 Protection of the Sea (Discharge of Oil from Ships) Act which provides Australia with the enabling legislation to implement provisions of the 1954 OILPOL Convention which are not yet in force internationally. Following notification late in 1982 that MARPOL will enter into force on 2 October 1983, the MARPOL 1973-78 Great Barrier Reef protection measures will now enter into force earlier than the OILPOL provisions.

The Bill also introduces new controls on the operation of ships carrying noxious liquid substances in bulk. Specifically, provision is made concerning prohibition of discharges of noxious liquid substances into the sea, cargo record book requirements and cleaning of cargo tanks following discharge of cargoes. The protection of the Great Barrier Reef will be maintained in relation to noxious liquid substances by imposing outright prohibition or special discharge rules when ships are within particular distances from the outer edge of the reef. Differing rules are applied depending on the categorisation of the substance and its strength in the mixture being discharged. In many cases discharge into the sea is prohibited entirely.

The implementation of the MARPOL Convention in Australia will introduce stricter control of ship-sourced oil pollution combined with compulsory ship construction and operational requirements which are designed to reduce the incidence of pollution at sea and in port. The Convention requires that ports themselves provide adequate shore reception facilities to receive ship-generated wastes. The Convention and the legislation to implement it is a marked improvement of existing arrangements and will place Australia in the international forefront in the field of marine pollution convention implementation. I commend the Bill to the House.
Debate (on motion by Mr Carlton) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: NAVIGATION (PROTECTION OF THE SEA) AMENDMENT BILL 1983

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill received from the Senate, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Morris The Hon P.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

This Bill is the second of two important steps in applying the provisions of the MARPOL 1973-78 Convention. In this Bill, Division 12, inserted by the Navigation (Protection of the Sea) Amendment Act 1981, is repealed. The existing Division 12 has not yet come into force because it was included in the legislation to enable Australia to implement the 1971 ship construction provisions of the 1954 International Convention for the Prevention of Pollution from Ships. Those provisions have not yet attracted sufficient signatures for them to have come into force internationally. The MARPOL 1973-78 Convention supersedes the 1954 Convention and therefore new requirements will be incorporated in the Navigation Act 1912.

This Bill inserts a new Division 12, relating to ships carrying or using oil, and a new Division 12A making provision concerning ships carrying noxious liquid substances in bulk. These Divisions will incorporate in the Navigation Act 1912 provisions relating to ship construction, equipment, survey and certification for ships covered by the respective Divisions. I mentioned in my second reading speech for the Protection of the Sea (Prevention of Pollution from Ships) Bill that all matters relating to construction, safety and survey of ships are incorporated in the Navigation Act. For simplicity of administration and understanding by the industry, MARPOL Convention requirements will be included in the Act now being amended by this Bill, in accordance with usual practice. I commend this Bill to the House.
Debate (on motion by Mr Carlton) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill received from the Senate, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bowen The Hon L.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

This Bill continues the practice developed during the last Parliament of introducing an omnibus Bill into each sitting of the Parliament to make a large number of what are called non-contentious amendments to a number of measures that are already on the statute book.

Whilst in Opposition we supported such legislation but were always concerned that too often substantive amendments of major policy importance could be ' tucked away' in these Bills and that the details of such amendments were not readily available to the legal profession and the public.

On the former point the Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans) has approved procedures in relation to such Bills. The principal feature of those procedures is the criteria of the nature of matters which might be included in the Bill. I now inform the House of those criteria: Firstly, only matters which genuinely deal with tidying up, correction and updating, routine administrative changes or are of minor policy significance, may be included; secondly, no matter that is contentious, or is closely related to a contentious matter, may be included; thirdly, matters that involve lengthy and complex drafting, particularly of a kind that may hold up the Bill, should generally not be included; fourthly, matters that involve substantial policy issues-including legal policy issues- should generally not be included; fifthly, no matter that would constitute a change to the National Companies and Securities legislation may be included; sixthly, no matter that imposes, abolishes or varies a tax or varies the incidence of a tax may be included; and seventhly, no matter involving an appropriation may be included-except the repeal of a 'spent' appropriation power .

Where, upon examination of the details of the proposed amendment the Attorney- General's Department or the Office of Parliamentary Counsel considers that a proposal does not satisfy those criteria, they will draw the matter to the attention of the Attorney-General for the consideration of the Legislation Committee.

The Attorney-General's Department is considering what further steps can be taken with the reprinting of Commonwealth Acts program to have amendments made by these Bills incorporated in the parent Acts as quickly as possible. To assist the dissemination of the contents of this Bill, the Attorney-General's Department has now forwarded copies of the Bill and explanatory material to the Law Council of Australia so that that body can inform the profession through its member State bodies.

I should mention that this Bill differs in format in a substantial way from its predecessors. Previously each amendment was a separate clause of the Bill. Under the new format most of the substantive amendments are contained in the Schedule to the Bill with no separate clauses for each amendment. The changed format allows for easier drafting and will overcome the inevitable errors that seem to have occurred in past Bills because of the late rearrangement of the material resulting from the inclusion or deletion of provisions with the many consequential changes to clause numbering, cross-references, et cetera. The proposed amendment in this Bill of section 182 of the Statute Law (Miscellaneous Amendments) Act (No. 1) 1982 falls into the latter category.

On 18 May, in the Senate, the Attorney-General incorporated in Hansard a supplementary statement explaining in detail the changes to the various Acts that are to be made by this Bill. A revised supplementary statement has now been circulated for the attention of honourable members of this House and accordingly I need not read it. The statement does not include reference to minor amendments of a drafting nature. In some cases a number of amendments of a similar nature are made to a number of different Acts. In those cases the amendments are described in detail in relation to only the first relevant Act which appears in the Schedule. The change from the supplementary statement that was incorporated in Hansard relates to the omission by the Senate of the proposed amendment to the Honey Industry Act 1962 because that amendment went much wider than was necessary for the particular purpose for which it was required. I now give notice that at the Committee stage I will move a narrower amendment of the Honey Industry Act that will comply with the Senate's objections. I might say that that Act will relate to the fact that the Australian Honey Board has power to make advances to owners of honey on the security of the honey. The advances are made from a loan by the Reserve Bank which is guaranteed by the Government. If the owner of the honey gets into financial difficulties, the Government may not have adequate security vis-a-vis other creditors, and so public funds are not fully protected. To obtain effective security over the honey, quite impractical arrangements have had to be adopted. The proposed amendment would enable the Board to make advances to owners of honey on different forms of security and thus ensure that the Commonwealth is a secured creditor in relation to the advance. The amendment which will be discussed in Committee tomorrow in respect of paragraph 18 (1) (c) of the Honey Industry Act states:
Omit 'on the security of the honey', substitute 'on such security as the Board considers adequate'.

In addition to the Honey Industry Act there will also be an amendment to the World Heritage Properties Conservation Act. That again would need to be dealt with in the Committee stage of the legislation which we hope to have discussed tomorrow. The amendment to the World Heritage Properties Conservation Act relates to this: The World Heritage Properties Conservation Act 1983 establishes a procedure for ascertaining the amount of compensation payable in respect of any acquisition of property as a result of the operation of the Act. There is a provision for the appointment of a commission of inquiry to inquire into this matter and if the property is within a State, the Premier of the State is entitled to nominate one of the three members of the Commission. The purpose of the amendment now to be put forward in the Committee stage is to put the Northern Territory in a similar position in this respect; that is, the Chief Minister of the Northern Territory will be entitled to nominate one member of the Commission where the property acquired is within the Northern Territory. In respect of the World Heritage Properties Conservation Act 1983 I now give notice of intention to move tomorrow the following amendments to Schedule 1:
Paragraph 17 (9) (a)-After 'State', insert 'or in the Northern Territory'.
Paragraph 17 (9) (b)-After 'State', insert 'or the Chief Minister of the Northern Territory, as the case may be'.

I expressly draw the attention of the House to proposals contained in this Bill regarding the furnishing and tabling of annual reports of departments and authorities. This is a matter with which the Parliament has been concerned for some time. In particular, the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations has made detailed recommendations for an annual reports Act containing detailed reporting criteria. More recently the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs has commented adversely on the contents of annual reports. Following interdepartmental committee considerations of the recommendations of the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations an amendment to the Acts Interpretation Act 1901 has been drafted which would require all bodies which do not have a specific period within which to furnish a report to the Minister to do so within six months of the close of the reporting period. The Minister would then have 15 sitting days within which to table the report in the Parliament. Where the report is not furnished to the Minister within the six month period a written explanation is required and an extension may be granted. Both the letter of explanation and the reasons for the grant of extension are to be tabled in the Parliament.

Those provisions, although not implementing the recommendations of the Senate Standing Committee, are a marked improvement on the present situation. Accordingly, the Government has decided to go ahead with the proposed amendments as an interim measure. Consistent with its election commitment, as part of a wider review of its overall approach to statutory authorities the Senate Standing Committee recommendations will be further considered by Government as a matter of priority. The proposed provisions of this Bill, as it relates to the furnishing of annual reports, specifically exclude the need for compliance with them by the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation and the Office of National Assessments. The question of the tabling of annual reports by these bodies will be considered in the context of the larger question of the public accountability of the intelligence organisations. I commend the Bill to the House.
Debate (on motion by Mr McVeigh) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McVeigh The Hon D.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —Prior to the debate being interrupted for Question Time, I was indicating to the House that the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin) cannot absolve himself from blame in relation to the Government's policies in imposing impossible burdens on primary industry by indicating that there was only one set of decisions, namely, the wheat marketing decisions, which were under his direct control. I was in the process of indicating that it is wrong for him to adopt a mere academic approach because other matters, even though they are outside his portfolio responsibility as such , do impinge on the position of primary producers. I intimated some of those matters, such as the removal of the petroleum storage installation taxation deduction, and the matter of increased fuel prices for avgas, with particular reference to an impost on aerial spraying, which is very applicable at the present time following the record flood rains we have had and the prolific weed growth because of which farmers are using aerial sprayers to a marked extent. I referred to the savage impost, the increased depreciation life and consequent reduced amounts which may be written off each year, the increased telephone charges and so on, and indicated that these were part and parcel of rural life. The Minister just cannot issue Press releases indicating that there were no matters under his control in Cabinet in which a decision was taken which was inimical to the interests of farmers. That is just not true. As any practical person knows, all those other matters do affect primary industry life, and if the Minister were in Cabinet he could have been present at all of those discussions and he could have had an input. If he was present in Cabinet, quite obviously it was an ineffective presence.

—Mr Deputy Speaker, I raise a point of order. The issue we are debating here consists of the removal of two lines from the Wheat Marketing Act. If the honourable member for Darling Downs wants a debate on all the rural matters in the economic statement, so be it. But we are talking about the Wheat Marketing Act.
—I will ask the honourable member for Darling Downs to come back closer to the central theme of the Bill.

—I accept your ruling, Mr Deputy Speaker, which quite obviously is far different from that of previous occupants of the Chair who, on so many occasions when honourable members from your side of the Parliament where challenged by honourable members from our side of the Parliament, indicated that the second reading speech is a wide ranging debate. That is an established rule of Speakers here.
—Order! The honourable member is not taking a point of order and I ask him not to question the ruling of the Chair in that way.

—I was just making the point, and I accept that it was wrong of me to question your wisdom, that certain precedents have been established here and I believe that you have transgressed those precedents.
—Order! I ask the honourable gentleman not to proceed along those lines. He has no prerogative to challenge the ruling of the Chair. I ask him to resume the debate.

—I will resume the debate. We are talking about the interest rate arrangements that have been made by the Government. I want to make this point, that it needs to be clearly understood that there is an implicit message that the Government is putting in this measure. By, in effect, scrapping the interest subsidy, the Government is basically saying it will be cheaper forever for the Board to borrow overseas than in Australia. I think that is quite pertinent to the matter under consideration. In other words, what the Government means, but it does not have the intestinal fortitide to say directly, is that interest rates in Australia are to remain higher than those interest rates overseas because, quite obviously, if interest rates in Australia were below interest rates overseas, there would be no reason to borrow overseas and obviously there would be no reason for an interest subsidy.

SPEECH.PARA: So by scrapping the interest subsidy, by giving the Australian Wheat Board power to borrow overseas, in effect what the Minister should be saying honestly to the Australian people is this: As far as we can see down the track, interest rates in Australia will be very high. They will be higher than the Rural Credits Department interest rates-even though they are lower at the present time-but they will be much higher than overseas interest rates. The difficulty I have, bearing in mind that I am talking about interest rates and subsidies, which are the very core of the measures proposed in this Bill, is that, in effect, in the Government's decision in introducing legislation, they will remain very high. I hope, Mr Deputy Speaker, that you do not pull me up on the point I am about to make, because it is very pertinent. During the Bruce by-election campaign the Minister for Housing and Construction (Mr Hurford) spread the word around that interest rates will come down. How can he, for his part as a Cabinet Minister, say that interest rates will come down, when the Minister for Primary Industry basically at the same time says with regard to this Bill, in effect-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Simmons Mr D.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The measures outlined in the statement of the Treasurer (Mr Keating) to this House last Thursday night are designed to restore balance and growth to the Australian economy. The package represents a reorientation of Government spending priorities and a shift in the composition of tax liabilities within Australia. The package also indicates the Government's firm intention of attacking the structural component of the Budget deficit; in other words, that part of the Budget deficit that will not automatically disappear when the Government manages to return the economy to its normal growth path. The structural component of the estimated Budget deficit of $9.6 billion is projected to be about 55 per cent, or over $5 billion. Many of the measures announced by the Treasurer will yield savings which will become substantial over time. Total savings on current program expenditures are expected to increase from $985m in 1983-84 to $2,036m in 1984-85 and $2,190m in 1985-86.

SPEECH.PARA: In my speech to the House today I want to discuss the impact on Australia's primary producers of the measures announced by the Treasurer. A number of the measures will have a direct impact on primary producers. But by far the major impact will come through the contribution of all the individual measures working together to restore balance and growth to an economy ravaged by over seven years of mismanagement by a government soundly rejected by Australians on 5 March. One of the most enthusiastically greeted components of the May statement is the Government's decision to grant the Australian Wheat Board the facility to borrow overseas. With Loan Council approval, the Australian Wheat Board can source 50 per cent of its net borrowing requirements from overseas. For borrowings exceeding 50 per cent of net requirements, the approval of the Minister for Primary Industry and the Treasurer will be required. Within the established borrowing limit, the Australian Wheat Board is free to choose the timing, size, currencies and terms of individual raisings. The Australian Wheat Board and the Australian Wheatgrowers Federation have been pushing for this facility for some time. Just 10 weeks after the election of a Labor Government, the Wheat Board has been given a flexibility in its borrowing activities that has the potential to save the wheat industry hundreds of millions of dollars each year. These savings will be passed back to wheat growers.

The May statement also contained details of a new scheme, the income stabilisation scheme, designed to encourage producers to take the necessary steps to help stabilise their incomes. This is the first time that Australian primary producers have had access to a scheme specifically designed to stabilise incomes. The existing income equalisation deposit scheme is characterised by the remarkable feature that, in conjuction with unlimited in-out averaging, it actually encourages primary producers to destabilise their incomes in order to maximise the benefits of participation. The income stabilisation scheme will operate from 1 September 1983. It will pay a rate of interest on deposits that is two percentage points higher than the ruling two-year Commonwealth bond rate. The scheme has been designed in such a way that all depositors will receive the same return on deposits and the nominal interest rate will also be the effective interest rate.

Unlike the income equalisation deposit scheme, it is anticipated that the income stabilisation scheme will prove to be an attractive investment and hence also an attractive income stabilisation device for all primary producers. The income equalisation deposit scheme has been used by only a small proportion of primary producers, with the level of funds currently invested totalling $161m. Producers with funds invested in the income equalisation deposit scheme will continue to receive an interest rate of 9.5 per cent.

—I take it that the honourable member for Calare is proposing to return to the central theme of the Bill, as I had previously requested the honourable member for Darling Downs to do. The honourable member may proceed.

—Mr Deputy Speaker, I was taking the opportunity, as the honourable member for Darling Downs had been rather wide-ranging in his comments, to make some points in response to some of his comments. But, Mr Deputy Speaker, I will certainly respect your ruling. The major impact of the May statement on primary producers will come through the contribution that the measures announced by the Treasurer will make to restoring balance and growth to the Australian economy. The measures that relate to borrowing by the Australian Wheat Board in particular are certainly central to that point. The erosion of primary producers ' competitiveness as Australia's rate of inflation has exceeded that of our trading partners has been an influential factor reducing the prosperity of primary industries. Restoration of balance and growth to the economy should be of prime concern to all primary producers.

SPEECH.PARA: The measures announced in the May statement will contribute towards a more favourable economic climate over the longer term by reducing the structural deficit, the rate of monetary growth, inflation and inflationary expectations, and, most importantly, interest rates. Primary producers are net beneficiaries from the May statement. Granting the Australian Wheat Board the facility to borrow overseas has the potential to save the wheat industry hundreds of millions of dollars. Under the income stabilisation scheme and other measures announced by the Government in the May economic statement, primary producers are given the opportunity to stabilise their income through investment yielding a return of two percentage points above equivalent investments open to other members of the community. In concluding, we believe that strengthening the domestic economy is to the advantage of all primary producers. It will help them in regaining competitiveness and restoring profitability as Australia, hopefully , comes out of the worst drought in 100 years.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tuckey Mr C.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition welcomes the principles behind the Wheat Marketing Amendment Bill. The proposal originated in submissions to the Fraser Government. Our Government had no opposition to the proposal and was proceeding to the legislation that appears before us today. The history of the Australian Wheat Board's borrowing to fund the guaranteed minimum price and, more particularly, the first advance guaranteed under the original legislation was originally that all funding was provided through the Rural Credits Department of the Reserve Bank of Australia, commonly referred to as the RCD. The interest rates charged by the RCD were generally below the commercial rates available in Australia at any time.

SPEECH.PARA: The procedure was a form of printing money. The annual first advance injected a large amount of new money into the Australian economy. To further support its monetary policy, the Fraser Government announced in 1978 that the Wheat Board must raise a percentage of its requirements on the domestic money markets. To further establish that the principle was one of monetary control and not one of adding a further financial burden to the rural sector, the Government offered a subsidy on the differential between the RCD interest rate and the prevailing commercial rate.

Since this scheme has operated, the following amounts have been raised annually from the local market and from the RCD. In 1978-79 the RCD provided $1,400m, of which some $484m was subsequently refinanced through commercial borrowings. In 1979-80, the RCD provided $700m and the commercial sector provided $800m, for a total of $1,500m. In 1980-81, the RCD raised $200m and the commercial sector provided $1,100m, for a total of $1,300m. In 1981-82, all of the funds required, some $2,000m, were raised on the commercial markets. In 1982-83, some $1,200m, all that was required, was also raised on the commercial markets. The approximate cost to the Government of the subsidy related to the interest rate differential has been: In 1979-80 $7.7m, in 1980-81 $23.2m, and in 1981-82 $22. 2m. The figures relating to the current year are not really known, but my advice is that the $19.8m suggested in the mini-Budget would be fairly close to the mark.

The new proposal before us today recognises two factors: First, that interest rates are now cheaper on the international commercial markets; and, secondly, that the Wheat Board conducts nearly all its business off-shore, and consequently that such borrowings, if raised in currencies similar to those used for the making of sales, are automatically hedged by the wheat stocks to be sold during the year and used to repay those loans. A great problem could arise in some other areas of off-shore financing where the funds are made available for capital assets-and this has been experienced in the wheat marketing arena in my own State-when currency fluctuation that goes in the wrong direction can add substantially to the interest burden and make such borrowings extremely expensive. However, it would not appear to me that this particular arrangement will create that problem. But should the matter be expanded in other directions, which on the present interest rates would be of great assistance, the Board could in future years find itself paying substantial amounts because of currency fluctuation.

This, plus the Fraser Government decision to allow the Wheat Board to operate an international wheat futures market, will give the Board the degree of flexibility that it has long needed to best represent the wheat growers, for whom it is the virtual agent. The Australian Wheat Growers Federation consequently saw this great improvement as so worthwhile as to happily accept a trade-off and forgo the Government subsidy on excessive interest charges, and this Bill removes that from the present legislation, as an amendment. Whilst commending the Government on proceeding with the previous Government's initiatives, I must express my regret that it has seen necessary-presumably to boost the apparent savings of its mini-Budget-to remove the right of the interest rate subsidy.

Naturally, if the Wheat Board exercises its new right to borrow overseas and takes advantage of the rates now applying, there would be no need to pay a subsidy on interest and no cost would accrue to the Government. Overseas rates are now much lower than those of the RCD. I am advised that because of the excellent borrowing status of the Wheat Board, rates as low as 9.5 per cent could be obtained on borrowings by the Board in the United States. This compares with the current RCD rate of 14.5 per cent, and, of course, as we know, some money market rates higher than that. So quite considerable borrowings-some hundreds of millions of dollars, in fact-could be available to the Board by obtaining this provision.

When requirement for commercial borrowing by the Board was introduced, it is my recollection that interest rates applying overseas were higher than the rates within Australia, and at that time the Australian Government felt constrained to pay a subsidy. There can be no doubt that such circumstances could occur again. This Bill removes the right of Australian farmers, through their Wheat Board, to seek this level of support in times of high interest rate regimes. The Opposition amendment foreshadowed by the honourable member for Darling Downs (Mr McVeigh) is in my opinion, therefore, the minimum that wheat growers can expect. However, this amendment does not address itself to the situation that previously existed; that is, when, for economic reasons, the Government of the day may not wish to increase money supply by means of obtaining funds from the RCD. In other words, it could then send the Wheat Board back on to the Australian commercial market, which would be cheaper than the overseas market but substantially more expensive than what one would expect from the RCD.

The question might be asked as to why wheat growers should be offered some insulation from high interest rates. The rural communities are locked into an economic scenario that requires that they sell their products on fluctuating international markets, yet they must conduct their business within an atmosphere of strictly structural levels of remuneration and prices in all other industry sectors. This cost structure has been set most particularly by the wage setting procedures within Australia, which take no cognisance of the financial return to sellers on overseas markets. An example of the burden that the wage and condition setting procedures impose upon the rural sector is an extract from the Primary Industry Newsletter of 23 May 1983 under the headline: 'Massive Farmer Subsidies to ANL and its Employees, says Report by NFF'. The two items of interest to me state:

. . . but the general theme will be especially important in the next few months as the Government negotiates with the Australian National Line and maritime unions on the 'revitalisation' of the coastal shipping business recommended by the Crawford Committee last year.
It goes on to say:
Mr Lane said that ANL seamen were being subsidised by Australian farmers to the tune of $73,000 a year each.
Further on Mr Lane is reported to have said:
The freight differential between ANL and competitive tonnage--
He is referring here to the carting of rock phosphate, the basis of every grain of wheat that is grown in Australia--
is around $17 a tonne.
That is, by the way, a rate which exceeds the government subsidy that is paid on superphosphate.

An even more classic example exists within the wheat handling system within Western Australia, where the Waterside Workers Federation, in a blatant attempt to increase its own revenues, has stolen some members of the dominant union in the Western Australian grain handling industry and must now deliver the benefits that it promised to convince those people to turn on the union that had maintained an excellent standard of representation for them. In the future the resultant leapfrogging will become another burden that the wheatgrowers of Western Australia in particular must carry. It will cause an increase in handling costs of up to $4 a tonne just to accommodate the avarice of a certain union leadership.

In all, there seems to be no redress for wheatgrowers other than direct support from government, particularly this Government, which is prepared to concede further wage increases in the tertiary and secondary sector which, by their very names, are the constant passengers of the primary sector. It is therefore inequitable to remove another area of support from that sector of industry which is crippled by the burdens of support that government gives by one means or another to those other sectors I have just mentioned, namely, the secondary and tertiary industries. All this is said understanding that at present the borrowing requirements of the Board will not place a burden on government. However, the protection that this arrangement has provided should remain. At least this must be shown by the retention of access to the Rural Credits Department.

The explanatory memorandum that was delivered with this Bill refers to certain specific conditions by which these funds may be borrowed overseas. The proposed amendments and the other documents do not exactly tell us what the specific conditions are. Government members are obviously better informed on that than the Opposition. So is the Primary Industry Newsletter. In regard to overseas borrowing by the Wheat Board the Newsletter states:
It will be free to borrow 50 percent of its prospective net borrowing requirements overseas, and more with the agreement of the Treasurer and Minister for Primary Industry.

The previous speaker made some reference to that too. I am not sure whether that is a commitment of government or whether that is the situation today. When one refers to certain specific conditions one wonders what the wheatgrowers of Australia have in fact achieved. It is not unusual to have those sorts of conditions. Obviously, the Government would want to know something about what people were doing. It becomes very clear that the conditions relate to the amount of money that may be borrowed overseas. I wonder to what extent these specific conditions will be used to interfere in the commercial judgments of the Wheat Board, particularly to accommodate future government monetary policy. There is no difficulty to the Government at present. It is desperate to attract the maximum of overseas capital inflow. However, how will it view these levels of borrowing in the future when its inflationary wages policy has recreated levels of M3 that will create massive levels of general inflation in Australia. Will the wheat farmer again be called on to become the monetary instrument but this time without the protection of an Act of parliament that guarantees him an interest rate at the bottom of the scale, which was the position that our Government took on that issue?

This Government should have the courage to back its rhetoric regarding economic recovery and a stable currency and it should state that it will leave the interest subsidy in place, secure in the knowledge that it will not be needed. I do not think there is much difficulty with that argument. It is quite clear that with a good and sound economy, under these new arrangements high interest rates will not occur in a manner that will damage the Wheat Board. The Government need not concern itself. Its mini-Budget promise that it will save nearly $20m, can stay in place. It is up to the Government. But if it takes out the subsidy, it shows to me that the Government lacks the courage of the fine words its Ministers say at the despatch box as to how their Government will create this wonderful economy. I hope that when the honourable member for Darling Downs presents his amendment, the Government can accept it, secure in the knowledge that it will not mean anything to it. It is just a guarantee to the farming community that it will not be used as an instrument of monetary policy without compensation in the future.

There are other great problems confronting farmers concerning borrowing. Drought has been common to the Australian rural industry in recent years. The financial burdens of the types I mentioned earlier which have inflated farmers' costs by annual rates approximately double the rise in the consumer price index, leave no margin for drought. Farmers can no longer save for a rainy day. Of course, it is not the rainy day they need to save for, it is the dry day, the dry season and, as in recent times, the dry years. Nor, in my opinion, will farmers be able to survive in continuous bumper years unless some financial burdens are removed. Again, I am able to congratulate the Government for removing one financial burden if only, as we know it, in the short term. It is obvious that this Government will not reduce the inflationary burden. It has shown very clearly, by accepting the proposition--

TALK.START.PARA: —Rubbish!
—The honourable member has not been here even long enough to know, so I do not think he should be interjecting.
—We will see who is right.

—The honourable member is just encouraging me to use up the whole 20 minutes allotted to me. In recent years my office has been host to a steady stream of farmers seeking assistance to survive on their land. Just two years ago all of these people had extremely low gearing. Their debt asset ratios were good. Nevertheless the lending institutions were already expressing concern that the cash flow of these farmers could not support further borrowing. After I had argued their cases with their lenders most received funding. Last year most experienced a reasonable season in my electorate. However, as the lenders predicted, the farmers have completed the year owing more money than they did at the beginning. One gentleman who, with his father before him, had farmed a property for 30 years, has seen his debt gearing grow from practically nil to 70 per cent of the deemed value of his property over the last four years. Of course , when circumstances like that apply, the deemed value is very notional indeed. Were he to be forced to sell his property as result of another drought he would not get anything like the value which would be put on it in better times.

SPEECH.PARA: The Primary Industry Association of Western Australia Inc. recently issued a paper entitled: 'Assistance for Post Drought Recovery'. I recommend it to the Minister and others for reading. I think the interesting things are the recommendations, and I refer them to the Minister in closing my contribution to this debate. The paper recommended:

That funds be provided for debt reconstruction to assist producers in post- drought recovery where such reconstruction will improve the long-term prospects of financial viability for the individual producer.

That the PIBA provide $10 million as debt reconstruction finance to Western Australia; comprising $5 million provided by the Commonwealth Government and $5 million raised by PIBA through market operations.

That one per cent of funds held in Statutory Reserve Deposits should be conditionally released to the trading banks. The release to be conditional upon the trading banks directing those funds to assisting primary producers recover from the effect of drought-
And most importantly--
That debt-reconstruction loans should be for periods of not less than 30 years.
That the interest subsidy scheme recently announced by the Commonwealth Government--
of course, that is the Fraser Government--
be extended for a post-drought period of equal duration to the period of drought .

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kerin The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-I thank the honourable members who participated in this debate, particularly the honourable member for Calare (Mr Simmons) and the honourable member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey ), who seems to have a far greater grasp of the issues than the shadow Minister. He set out very sensibly the reasons for the interest rate subsidy that had applied and the reasons for the past Government moving that way in 1978. As he has pointed out, this is a progression from that course.

SPEECH.PARA: I will respond very directly to some of the points and the wild and woolly charges raised by the honourable member for Darling Downs (Mr McVeigh). First of all, I am sorry that he did not get this very simple Bill, the Wheat Marketing Amendment Bill-it consists of only two lines-at the time I promised him he would . There was some problem in getting it out of my office. I did not want it to go to him before it went to the members of the Caucus. Somehow, in that arrangement , he failed to get it on time. I assure him that I will treat him exactly as his predecessor treated me. I had one briefing with the Department. I requested one other and it was refused.

The speech by the Treasurer (Mr Keating) set out exactly what we are doing in this regard. Only two lines in the Act are being changed. I understand that the shadow Minister for Primary Industry, the honourable member for Darling Downs, wanted a full briefing on it. He has acted in a confused way. On the Thursday night, in the House, he charged that it would 'cost Australian wheatgrowers $20m in 1983-84 by removing the subsidy payable to the Australian Wheat Board'. It was pretty obvious by Sunday night that somebody obviously had had a word in his ear about the fact that the industry welcomed the move because he then put out another release acknowledging the removal of the subsidy with the corollary of the freedom to go off-shore for financing the Guaranteed Minimum Price. So, he changed his mind. As a man who describes himself as a leading wheat grower, it seems that he is strangely out of touch with the long standing request of the industry. The Australian Wheat Growers Federation, the Australian Wheat Board and, of course, the National Farmers Federation, the umbrella organisation of the farmers, have welcomed this move.

As the honourable member for O'Connor said, in 1978 the Federal Government required the Wheat Board to go on to the commercial market rather than fund up to $2 billion worth of wheat through the Rural Credits Department of the Reserve Bank of Australia. It paid a differential in the interest rates. The past Government in its infamous razor gang decision, cut that interest rate subsidy by one per cent. This was regarded as a betrayal by the wheat growers because there is no offset. We are now giving the Wheat Board massive commercial flexibility. The most important value of this is that it is giving it the freedom to hedge on the exchange markets. It stands to make a packet if its members use their heads in the right way. There are hundreds of millions of dollars to be saved by this measure. This can be proved. The Wheat Board has been given one of the greatest bonanzas of all time. It is a great reform.

The honourable member for Darling Downs wanted me to give some calculations. I must say that it is absolutely impossible to give exact calculations on this matter. The amount that the Government will save next year will be something in the order of about $19.6m or $20m. But there is the offset of allowing the Board to go on to the international market. The calculations depend on the interest rates here and abroad, on how big the wheat crop will be and on a range of matters. One cannot calculate into the future. All one can do is a cold precise calculation, which is the sort of thing that the Department of Finance has to do and about which it has no choice in terms of extrapolating figures ahead. So it depends very much on the situation of the commercial market.

Going back to the razor gang decisions, we tried to work out what the subsidy calculations would cost the industry. Again it was near impossible to work it out because it is not a calculation based on the cost for a full year. The Rural Credits Department rate is one level and the commercial rate is another. Of course, it would depend on when the Wheat Board actually goes on to the commercial market to make the loan and it is doing it then in terms of a basket of currencies. That basket at the time was compared with the RCD rate. There is then a calculation at the end of the year. So no calculation for a year ahead is possible. If we look at the RCD rate and the gap between a full year-again I say it is not a very precise calculation-in 1981 the gap between the Rural Credits Department interest rate and the commercial interest rate was about 2.4 per cent . Now it is between half of one per cent and one per cent. In other words, the value of the subsidy was rapidly tapering away but it need not have. It depends on the interest rates on the commercial market and the variation with the RCD. Of course, the amount being financed in a drought year is smaller than usual.

If we go through the figures at present, I think the Wheat Board could currently borrow in the United States of America at a rate something of the order of 9.5 per cent as against a current domestic commercial rate of 13.5 per cent. Let us calculate what the tonnage could be in the year ahead. If there are 17 million tonnes of wheat-that is quite feasible-at $150 a tonne GNP, there would be approximately $2.5 billion of borrowings. If that 4 per cent is applied there is a saving of $40m and if 5 per cent is applied there is a saving of something like $50m. In other words there is the potential to save hundreds of millions of dollars. The Australian Wheat Board can now automatically borrow up to $1,250m, on this calculation, overseas at an interest rate differential. So it is very hard to calculate but the potential is there for massive savings and massive gains for the Australian wheat growers.

The honourable member for O'Connor set out exactly the same figures as I have set out in terms of the value of the subsidy in the past. But he was good enough and sensible enough to point out why we are doing that we are doing. It is because there is no longer the need for the interest subsidy because we are going a further step and allowing the Wheat Board to have full commercial flexibility. In terms of the Australian Labor Party's policy on statutory marketing authorities, that is the way we want to move. We want these big marketing organisations to be controlled by the farmers in terms of policy, but for the marketing arm of those bodies to have full commercial flexibility and stand in the market place and get on with the job of selling the crop or the wool or whatever. I think our big marketing organisations are moving that way. The Wheat Board and the Australian Wool Corporation in particular are moving that way.

In some other elements of his speech, the honourable member for Darling Downs carried on with his critical sniggering and sneering because I went to Geneva. I want to know what he has got against the sugar industry. No Minister has gone to a meeting as important as the International Sugar Agreement Meeting in Geneva and stayed for six days. I was there with the Queensland Minister for Primary Industry, Mr Ahern. We worked together. We worked with the Sugar Board, the Australian Sugar Producers Association, the Australian Canegrowers Council and the Proprietory Mill Owners Association, CSR Ltd, Queensland departmental officials, and Commonwealth Department of Trade officials. We worked as one in the interests of the sugar industry. Nothing is more important to the sugar industry than getting the European Economic Community into the next international sugar agreement.

The honourable member can sneer all he likes but I was there six days and I was proud of it. No Minister has been there that long. It was essential. While I was there I took up the questions of the common agricultural policy relating to beef , cheese, dairy products, apples, deciduous canning fruits, dried vine fruits, wheat and wine and the possibility of a trade war between the EEC and the United States. I stressed Australia's anger, alarm and dismay at the way the EEC is continuing with its common agricultural policy. Of course, the honourable member is not sniggering and sneering because I was over there fighting for Australia's primary industries; he said that I was not head kicking enough. I make it quite plain that we made our anger known to the EEC about what it is doing, but we will not indulge in public abuse. Great Britain is a member of the EEC. We used to trade with Great Britain. Honourable members opposite carry on about royalty and the monarchy but want this Government to go over there and head kick the British people who are basically responsible for our institutions. It is not sensible to conduct trade by abuse. The former Minister or Primary Industry accused the EEC of being like Ned Kelly at an international forum. Ned Kelly was hanged. That is marvellous. There are cheers back home and the farmers love it but what runs did the Opposition get on the board with the EEC by engaging in abuse and head kicking? It got nowhere. Today we deal in trade negotiations by diplomacy, not by abuse. There are no gains from indulging in abuse.

The honourable member for Darling Downs brought up the nonsense he is running around the bush with, that because the Primary Industry portfolio is not included in Cabinet there are problems. I will put that straight once and for all. I know that the honourable member will say this forever and a day, regardless of the number of times I explain to people. We are not comparing this Ministry with an inner and outer Cabinet as occurs under conservative governments. The Australian Labor Party has a caucus system. Members and senators are not kept in the dark. We do not have a Ministry that carries on-

—I raise a point of order, Mr Deputy Speaker. I do not mind your giving the Minister a wide range-

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable member for Darling Downs said also that I was not prepared to take the blame or responsibility, whatever it was, for some of the other measures that were announced in the economic statement and that were not technically part of the Department of Primary Industry. I take the view that I accept the credit or the blame for the lot. I believe in Cabinet government, as do all members of the Hawke Ministry. If the honourable member wants me to direct my attention to the other three or four matters that could be seen to be affecting primary producers, I will go through them. We are talking about one of those matters. Let us look at tax averaging. The system of tax averaging is to remain, but we have wiped out something to which the Balderstone Committee pointed. By people using the automatic in-out provisions of the primary producer tax averaging system and also the income equalisation deposit scheme, whereby people on a very high marginal tax with high incomes can transform a 9.5 per cent flat rate into a 23.5 per cent gain, the system is being rorted and is able to be used only by a handful of high income producing farmers.

We are trying to retain tax averaging so that people can make their own decisions as to whether they will be in it or out of it. Most of them will be in it. We are providing a system of income equalisation deposits and paying a decent interest rate which is 2 per cent above the long term two-year bond rate. That scheme will be fine tuned so that it does meet the purposes for which the last Government set it up. I think that is a far more sensible approach than the nonsense we had before where a handful of people could rort the system. We are after a system whereby small and medium income earning farmers can have something to put away for a dry day. As the honourable member for O'Connor rightly pointed out, we are not worried about rainy days, except when they cause floods.

I now deal with the depreciation allowance. The former Treasurer, the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard), on behalf of the Government, introduced this in July 1982. We followed on with that proposal. It was a substantial move down for primary industry from 20 per cent to 33 1/3 per cent. We implemented that legislation. We are keeping it on for one year to get primary industry on the same level as all other aspects of secondary industry depreciation rates. If one takes into account that the investment allowance is 18 per cent and there is now a 20 per cent depreciation allowance-38 per cent in the first year if one is sensible enough to buy in about June-one will see that the situation is not too bad. All we are trying to do here is get back to some sort of equality with the rest of the industry.

The other matter one can mention is the Petroleum Products Freight Subsidy Scheme. Honourable members on the other side of the House should be the last people to criticise us. The former Government put up the cost of distillate used for off-road purposes, brought in this iniquitous rebate system and wiped out the certification system. I understand there were rorts in that system. I know that problems existed, but members of the Opposition cannot criticise us for what we did. The former Government put up the cost of fuel. The cost of fuel trebled in the seven years of office of the Fraser Government from something like 14c a litre to 42c a litre. Members of the Opposition then have the gall to come in here and criticise us because we have moved the freight equalisation component up by one-tenth of one cent. Those were the people who increased the price of fuel three times in seven years. The honourable member for Darling Downs talked a lot of nonsense about the drought.

There is one extra point I wish to raise on the economic statement. The economic statement, as a macroeconomic policy document, has more potential for gain in the primary inustry sector than the three or four single nitpicking issues. We intend to do something about the structural deficit-the rate of monetary growth-and to try to bring down inflation and interest rates. In other words, all Budgets should be regarded primarily as macroeconomic documents. The National Farmers Federation and the big farm organisations know that it is in the macroeconomic area that the fortune or failure of farmers will be decided, not in nitpicking little commodity issues. This statement is very important. We should all hope that it will work and that it will get Australia back on the track.

Finally, there has been a bit of nonsense about the drought and how the relief scheme has not been extended. I think that some people do not understand the scheme. The fodder subsidy will continue; it is on. The trouble is that the States will pull off the declaration in some areas because it has rained. This is not under our control. I cannot force people to buy fodder. The scheme continues. I have expanded it in certain areas. Leasing is now in. I have examined the problem for share farmers, but we found that the administrative arrangements were too difficult. A couple of items regarding fodder increases were included. A few extensions have been made at the request of the States. The scheme continues and it is administered by the States.

Mr Deputy Speaker, I thank you for your indulgence. I have wandered a bit far from the mark. The honourable member for Darling Downs sees this as an opportunity to score points against the Government because he is stuck with a basic fact that what we are giving the wheat industry is the potential to save hundreds of millions of dollars. This is something which the former Government did not have the sense to do. I commend the Bill to honourable members.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

PROCTEXT.PARA: The Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McVeigh The Hon D.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —I formally move an amendment to clause 3 of the Wheat Marketing Amendment Bill. I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Clause 3, page 1, omit proposed sub-section (5A), substitute the following sub- section:

'' '(5A) The powers of the Board under sub-sections (3) and (5) may be exercised both within and outside Australia, and in a case where interest rates within and outside Australia are higher than the current rates of the Rural Credits Department of the Reserve Bank, the Board is guaranteed access to the Rural Credits Department for such amounts as approved by the Treasurer and the Minister for Primary Industry.'.''.
