The Opposition proposes this amendment for the simple and fundamental reason that we believe that our wheat industry needs to be offered some guarantee of absolute security. The Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin) in his summation , which he readily admitted was a bit of a Cook's tour, and a wide and rambling one, talked a lot about potential. I do not know whether anyone has ever been able to exist on potential before except in the Minister's mind. Whilst it is all right to talk about these arrangements which give the Australian Wheat Board a great deal of potential to make-I think he started off by saying 'tens of millions' and ended up saying 'hundreds of millions'-a deal of money, I think those of us who have had some experience in the practical side of life know of many instances in which potential has never been realised. I am most grateful to the Minister for publicly admitting in his speech that these initiatives give the Wheat Board wonderful potential. I suggest that the Minister give consideration to recalling in his mind how many wonderfully potential things he has seen that have failed. It is with added assurance, after that rambling speech of the Minister wherein he seemed to talk about potential, that we move this amendment because this amendment has nothing to do with potential; it has to do with the practical appreciation of security. We believe it is in the national interest that this be the case.

As other speakers have said, and I guess from practical experience we all know, the Australian Wheat Board has done a great job on behalf of the Australian wheat industry and, of course, the persons to whom it is ultimately responsible, the Australian wheat growers. It appears to us that the Board and the industry are entitled to that knowledge of security, no matter what happens in the future . The Minister talked about potential. He even admitted in his rambling speech that he could not accurately give figures. He admitted that he could not accurately project whether the figure would be $19.6m or $30m. The Treasurer (Mr Keating) cited those figures. But on the one hand we have the Minister believing in this wonderful potential and in the same speech, on the other hand, indicating that he cannot accurately define what will happen. Consistent with the logic that he adopted in his speech on this issue, I hope he follows that logic through and accepts this amendment for the simple reasons that one cannot rely on potential and one does not know accurately what interest rates might be in three months or six months time.

I am indebted to the Minister for his practical exposition in those two matters -that potential in effect can amount to nought and we cannot accurately reflect what interest rates will or will not be. The aim of the amendment is simple. We seek assurance from the Minister that, if the worst possible situation occurs- namely, internal and overseas interest rates higher than the current rates of the Rural Credits Department of the Reserve Bank of Australia-and given the Minister's argument, his logic, his doubt about the future, the Board will be guaranteed access to the RCD finance. It is all very well for the Minister to get up and say that what we are asking for is implicit in the legislation; that it is understood. Madam Deputy Chairman, you will know from your vast experience that occasionally-maybe far too often-things which are implicitly understood are not always the things which are legally binding on the participating parties. It is for that reason that the Opposition seeks to amend clause 3 of the Wheat Marketing Amendment Bill. We submit that instead of the Government's amendment to the Act the amendment to sub-section 5 (A) as circulated in my name should be the one included.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kerin The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government rejects the Opposition's suggested amendment to clause 3 of the Wheat Marketing Amendment Bill. The honourable member for Darling Downs (Mr McVeigh) talked a lot about potential in some semantic sense. I point out that the word survives on its own without much definition. People know what the word means. The only reason I am not able to define whether the wheat growers will save tens of millions or hundreds of millions of dollars is one of simple arithmetic and depends on whether one multiplies by one year, two years or three years. If the honourable member can calculate what interest rates overseas will be in the future, as a basket of currencies, or how much wheat will be traded on the world market, or how much wheat will be grown in Australia, he is a better man than I am. That is why I am simply saying that the calculations in the speech of the Treasurer (Mr Keating) relate to the usual method, the only method available to the Department of Finance and the Department of the Treasury; they must simply extrapolate figures forward. I am sure all honourable members realise that we cannot make estimates of what interest rates, cropping rates or production will be in the years ahead. But they can clearly understand that this Bill offers the potential for the wheat industry to save tens of millions of dollars-in the short term-or hundreds of millions of dollars.

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable member's amendment tries to have a little bit both ways. I point out that there is absolutely nothing to stop the wheat industry or the Australian Wheat Board coming back to the Government with a request to go to the Rural Credits Department if a situation is so bad. Again, I think the honourable member does not really understand the potential, the real benefit of this, to the Wheat Board. It will be able to get into currency hedging. Quite simply, the amendment to the principal Act proposed by the Government allows the Wheat Board to choose where it will borrow. It can borrow overseas if that is the most profitable course or it can borrow domestically if that is the most profitable course. Due to the mess that we inherited, and the record high interest rates, in the short term it is quite obvious that it will be much more profitable to borrow overseas. As I pointed out in my second reading speech, there is a 4 per cent to 5 per cent gain available right now. We are talking about the ability of the Wheat Board to get into these markets, to currency hedge in terms of the countries to which we sell the wheat. This increases absolutely its commercial flexibility and profitability. It is this ability to get into currency hedging and to go forward, seeing it is now into futures contracts for wheat, that gives the Wheat Board and the wheat industry new massive capacity. I commend the Bill as originally printed and reject the amendment as moved by the honourable member for Darling Downs.
Amendment negatived.
Bill agreed to.
Bill reported without amendment; report adopted.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill (on motion by Mr Kerin)-by leave-read a third time.

DEBATE.TITLE: TAXATION (UNPAID COMPANY TAX) ASSESSMENT AMENDMENT BILL 1983

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 18 May, on motion by Mr Dawkins:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, may I have your indulgence to suggest that the House have a general debate covering this Bill and the Taxation (Unpaid Income Tax-Dividends) Bill 1983, the Income Tax Assessment Amendment Bill 1983, the Income Tax Assessment Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1983, the Income Tax (Rates) Amendment Bill 1983, the Income Tax (Individuals) Amendment Bill 1983, the Income Tax (Companies, Corporate Unit Trusts and Superannuation Funds) Amendment Bill 1983 and the Income Tax (Payments for Work) (Consequential Amendments) Bill 1983 as they are associated measures. Separate questions will, of course, be put on each of the Bills at the conclusion of the debate.
—Is it the wish of the House to have a general debate covering these eight measures? There being no objection, I will allow that course to be followed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —This batch of Bills falls naturally into two categories. There are those dealing with the extension of the recoupment legislation passed last year by the former Government and those dealing with the introduction of a deduction system for cash payments affecting certain industries. I shall address both groups of Bills in my remarks. The first group of Bills-those dealing with a purported extension of the recoupment legislation passed last year by this Parliament at the instigation of the former Government- is by any measure a very important group of Bills. The Bills are important not only in their own right but also because they represent the first offering of the new Hawke Labor Government in the area of anti-tax avoidance legislation. For that reason they deserve not only the attention of this House but also the very careful scrutiny of not just the Opposition but the wider community as well .

SPEECH.PARA: It is through this legislation and what this legislation attempts to do that we in the Opposition and others in the community can try to answer a number of questions. It is first of all a demonstration of how genuine were the criticisms of the anti-tax avoidance record of the former Government by the then Labor Opposition because it is now in government and has the opportunity to demonstrate that the things it said about us, the things that it said we were leaving undone in the anti-tax avoidance area, can be put right. In preparing my remarks for this afternoon I had a look at the records of some of the debates in this Parliament of September and October last year. We will all remember the figures that were thrown around. The former Leader of the Opposition, the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) said that $15,000m was there for the plucking, to be recouped from the tax avoidance industry, if only the Fraser Government would act. An amount equivalent to $35 a week from every taxpayer in Australia could be recouped and returned to those long-suffering pay-as-you-earn taxpayers if only the Fraser Government would act, he said.

Of course the Minister for Finance (Mr Dawkins) was not backward in coming forward on the subject of taking stern action against tax avoiders so naturally everybody, including the Opposition and those long-suffering PAYE taxpayers, have waited with breathless anticipation for this first offering from the Hawke Labor Government in the anti-tax avoidance area. We have looked forward to seeing legislation to recoup that $7,000m, to seeing that $35 a week recouped. When it was not in the mini-Budget last Thursday night I thought: 'Oh, I know, Dawkins is holding it up for the taxation legislation debate and he will unveil in that debate precisely what the Hawke Labor Government is going to do in this area'. But what do we find? We find a miserable $500m to $600m. To recoup that, what has the Hawke Labor Government done? It has broken yet another of the promises it made during the election campaign-the promise not to introduce a capital gains tax. Although the Minister for Finance did not tell us, this batch of Bills contains the introduction, retrospectively, of a capital gains tax. I invite the Minister for Finance to disprove that charge during this debate.

We will all remember that during the election campaign the then Leader of the Opposition, the present Prime Minister, went to the Australian people and said: 'There's one thing that you people have to be absolutely clear about-in no way would a Labor government introduce a capital gains tax'. I express my absolute astonishment at the fact that, given the opportunity to recoup that $7,000m a year that we were allowing to slip through our fingers when we were in government, we now have the Government offering a miserable $500m or $600m a year and in order to do that it has to introduce a retrospective capital gains tax. The most important thing that that demonstrates, above everything else, is that the charges of dereliction of duty, of being soft about the tax avoidance industry and of being friends of the tax avoidance industry made against the former Liberal-National Country Party Government were absolutely groundless. The inability of the new Labor Government, with the great majority that it has in this place, to bring forward legislation to recoup that $7,000m it said we were not collecting demonstrates that above everything else.

The second thing I want to say about this group of Bills is that they have as much in common with the original recoupment legislation passed last year as do Barry Unsworth's views on superannuation with the views of the Treasurer (Mr Keating). This legislation goes far beyond the recoupment concept contained in last year's legislation and it will not be supported by the Opposition parties in this place or elsewhere. The legislation is not a mere toughening up of the recoupment legislation that passed through the Parliament last year. It not only retrospectively imposes a capital gains tax but also seeks to collect a new tax which has never been the subject of an illegal evasion, which was the single distinguishing point about the legislation introduced by the former Government and supported by the then Labor Opposition last year.

In expressing the Opposition's attitude, let me say at the outset that we are not in any way being inconsistent with the stance that we took last year. I know that already some people, both here and in another place, have tried to say that in opposing these Bills the Liberal and National Parties are behaving differently from the way in which they behaved last year. I make it very plain to the House that every single item in these Bills either reverses amendments that were specifically inserted by the former Government into the legislation passed last year or, alternatively, proposes changes that were specifically raised by the Labor Opposition last year but were rejected for the reasons then given by the Government. So in no way is our stance today and the stance that we will adopt later in another place at odds or inconsistent with the stance that we took when the legislation was debated last year. I make that clear right from the outset and put at rest any suggestion, any lie, that may be around that we have changed our stance and that in some way we are behaving inconsistently and differently from the way in which we behaved last year.

The next point I make-it is fundamental to an understanding of this debate-is that these are not Budget Bills. Unless the Government has decided to fund its deficit through confiscation, they are not normal revenue-raising items. Therefore any claim by the Government that the Opposition, in opposing this legislation, is in some way frustrating the Budget-cutting desires of the new Government, the economic rationalist zeal of the new Government, is totally in error. In no sense are these Bills revenue-raising measures. They go far beyond the concept of anything previously before this Parliament. The Bills are retrospective, with a capital R, in their intent, in the novelty of the tax imposed and in the reach and breadth of the provisions contained in them. They seek retrospectively to create a liability for tax which has never previously existed. In fact, had the companies concerned gone on trading it would never conceivably, for all practical purposes, have arisen. As I mentioned earlier, the Bills do not recoup the proceeds of a fraudulent evasion of tax.

In the long debate that went on last year the one central proposition that was important to the case that the Government then argued-sometimes against opposition from different quarters of the community-was that all we were seeking by that legislation was to recoup to the Commonwealth Treasury tax that was then due and payable, which had been rendered incapable of collection because of an illegal act and therefore ought to be recouped to the Treasury. We were not seeking to create a new tax liability; rather, we were seeking to redeem an existing tax liability by looking to those who had benefited in a financial way from the profits of illegal evasion in order to collect that tax. That is a far narrower and more central proposition than that which underlies this legislation . The tax imposed by this legislation is in every sense of the word a new tax. The legislation will not recoup tax which has been the subject of an illegal evasion. As I understand it, it will tax both the accumulated profits and the capital reserves of a company. Therefore, the accumulated profits will previously have borne company tax at the rate of 46c in the dollar, undistributed profits tax at the rate specified by the Act and now, on top of that, under this Bill there will be a further tax of 60c in the dollar. So effectively we will be looking at a tax rate of 78 per cent to 85 per cent.

Extraordinarily enough, deceitfully enough because it was not made clear in the legislation, this legislation contains for the first time, as I understand it, in Australia's taxation history the imposition retrospectively of a capital gains tax. That is in defiance, if I may say so, of the promise given a number of times by the Prime Minister and others during the last election campaign that the Labor Party would not introduce a capital gains tax. So this legislation has those quite unique features. It imposes a capital gains tax, it imposes it retrospectively and it is utterly unlike and goes far beyond the legislation that was brought in last year.

These Bills specifically overturn a decision of the High Court of Australia in respect of a whole group of companies and specifically render totally illegal with penal taxation consequences acts done many years ago. Profits earned and on which tax in the normal sense of the word was paid will now years after be rendered liable for tax. In that sense it is quite unlike the recoupment legislation last year because there we were talking about the collection of taxation that was due and payable at the time the transactions took place. There was never any doubt in the case of the companies we were dealing with last year that a liability for company tax would have existed at the end of the financial year in question. What we were seeking to do in those cases was to say to people who gained from illegal evasion: 'You got the benefit of it; if you had not got the benefit of it the tax would have been paid and the Commonwealth Treasury would not have been robbed.' But that is not the case in this situation. Under this legislation we will be able to say to a company which has operated in the normal fashion, paid company tax and Division 7 tax on its profits and put those profits into some kind of revenue reserve: 'On top of that we will add 60 per cent in respect of antecedent transactions.' Yet the Minister for Finance will come into this House and say: 'Oh, this is just some toughening of the orginal bottom-of-the-harbour legislation.' It has nothing to do with bottom-of-the- harbour legislation. It is a totally new excursion into completely unchartered waters so far as taxation legislation is concerned. It shows the bankruptcy of the claims made against the former Government of dereliction in this area because the best the Government can do to recoup all this tax that we were letting slip through our fingers is to bring forward this kind of shonky, irrational and economically destabilising proposition.

This Government over the last few days has been preening itself because of some newspaper editorials about its economic rationality, about how responsible it is and about how it can take all of these tough decisions. I put it to the House that these Bills represent not tough decisions; they represent totally illiterate decisions by the Government in the area of taxation. The legislation seeks to impose taxation liabilities of the kind I have described on companies and give them only 30 days in which to meet those liabilities. They will not have 30 days to pay up something that should have been paid years ago. That might in a commercial sense be a little unrealistic. But perhaps in a moral sense the Government might say it is justified, that these companies should have paid many years ago, they did not, they knew they were getting a benefit by not paying and it is therefore fair enough that they be asked to cough up, and cough up quickly. But we are not talking about that set of circumstances here. We are talking about a set of circumstances where people and companies have in fact borne tax according to the law that existed at the time. The Government comes along to them years later and says: 'We are going to put this tax on you and you are going to pay it within 30 days'. It then runs outside and says: 'All we are doing is toughening up the legislation that the former Liberal Government introduced.' To say, 'We are a group of economic rationalists, we are all thoroughly reasonable people and the business community should feel totally safe and secure with us, is really to stretch logic a long way.

I believe that the proposal to remove the 12-month period is nothing other than a stupid act of spite by the new Government. The 12 months' amnesty or grace period that was introduced by the former Government was implemented for a very practical reason. Whatever the merits may have been of these transactions, it was considered that the game being up and people having received assessments to pay their recoupment tax in respect of the proceeds of an illegal evasion, those people should be told: 'Well, if you can organise to pay within a period of 12 months we will allow you to do so'. I know for a fact that in many cases companies have gone to the Commissioner of Taxation and said: 'Right, we accept we have to pay this money, it should have been paid in the first instance but in the interests of not dislocating our business, in the interests of our not having to sack or retrench people, at a time of recession, will you give us a period in which to pay off the tax?' Anybody would surely accept that in today's economic circumstances, and against the whole background of this legislation, that this is a reasonable proposition. But no, that is not good enough for the Hawke Labor Government. That is not turning the screws tightly enough; that is not putting enough squeeze on the profitability of the companies concerned. The Government says: 'We will take that 12 months away from them. We will not only take it away from them in respect of the unpaid company tax that was the subject of the Fraser Government's legislation but also we will deny it to them in respect of the retrospective capital gains tax that we are imposing by this legislation.' If I may say so, that is not a bad effort for the first anti-tax avoidance offering, or should I say the first tax confiscation offering, of the new Labor Government.

In case the Minister or anybody else in this House thinks that what I have been saying is mere rhetoric and bears absolutely no relationship to the facts, I will describe an example that has been brought to my attention and probably to the attention of many members of this House because it is absolutely fundamental . The example is a 100 per cent Australian owned manufacturing company employing 400 people with sales of over $20m a year, exports of $1m and an import replacement of $10m. I understand from the managing director of the company and its accountants that if this legislation goes through the company will quite simply be forced into liquidation and that the new tax in that event will not be able to be fully recovered. In June 1980 a sale of the operating company's structure brought a benefit only in respect of current year profits. Of course, the law passed last year collects the tax in respect of those current year profits.

That sale, which will also be affected by this new legislation, brought no cash benefit whatsoever. The company's book reserves totalled $6.9m of which $2.2m were tax free capital reserves which would never have been taxable even if distributed by way of a capital issue to shareholders and $4.7m were revenue reserves which would have been taxable only in the event of a wind-up. These reserves are being fully used to finance-sin of all sins-the continued operation of the business and therefore the continued employment of 400 people. Those reserves, which are being used to keep the business going during difficult economic times and which are keeping those 400 people employed, will bear the jackboot of this legislation. The Government now plans to tax the non-existent alleged benefit of the book sales of those reserves of $6.9m at the penal rate of 60 per cent. The Government is not mucking around. The rate is not 10 per cent, 15 per cent or 20 per cent, but 60 per cent. The Government is creating a tax liability of $4m which will totally wipe out the present net worth of the business. That is an example of how this legislation will affect one 100 per cent Australian owned company. I invite the Minister for Finance to demonstrate in his reply where that example is wrong.

Surely we are not here talking about blatant, artificial and contrived tax avoidance. What can be blatant, artificial or contrived about the circumstances that I have described? What is so wrong with what that company has done that it should have visited upon it the effects of this legislation in all its savage operation? I speak as one who brought before this Parliament on two occasions when I was Treasurer, over a period of five years, legislation which had retrospective operation. But the circumstances of those two measures differed entirely from those of this legislation. On both occasions, particularly in respect of the legislation passed last year, we were speaking not of creating a new taxation liability but rather of collecting taxation that always had been due and payable. It was due and payable at the time the legislation was brought before the Parliament but, because an illegal act had been perpetrated by some, the company against which the tax assessment was outstanding was unable to meet its liability and we quite reasonably looked to the people who had benefited from the evasion to collect the tax owing. I put it to honourable members that the legislation that is before us goes far beyond the scope of that provision.

Every item in this legislation-the abolition of the 12-month period, the removal of the tight definition, the trigger of fraud described by many people in the Government at the time; indeed all the other provisions of the legislation-was carefully examined by the former Government. The amendments to the original Act, which it is now proposed should be struck out, were proposed by the former Government because we believed that they were necessary properly to limit the scope of the legislation. Similarly, we rejected the amendments then sponsored by the then Opposition because in our view they went much too far .

Surely even those Government supporters whose views will differ from the arguments that I have put forward, surely even the most rabid supporters of wholesale retrospective legislation in regard to anything that has a remote connection with tax avoidance, would concede that some kind of burden should be borne by those who argue that this Parliament should legislate retrospectively. I put it to then that the circumstances of the company I have just described are hardly so blameworthy, nefarious, delinquent or immoral as to warrant visiting upon it the consequences I have outlined, not only for its own operating structure, commercial viability and existence but also for the future well-being , employment and existence of its 400 employees when we have 10 1/2 per cent unemployment in the Australian community. Surely that company has not behaved so badly, immorally and nefariously that that kind of treatment should be meted out to it.

Therefore, the Opposition will vote against this legislation. It does not believe that the Government has any kind of a mandate to introduce it. So far from having a mandate, the introduction of the legislation breaks a clear promise given by the Prime Minister that no capital gains tax would be introduced by a Hawke Labor Government, let alone a retrospective capital gains tax. If this legislation is passed the Parliament will not only be sending many companies and businesses into liquidation, it will also be disemploying many thousands of Australians. In passing this legislation the Parliament would, in my view, and I believe in the view of the great majority of the Australian community, and I think also in the view of many government supporters in their more rational moments, be entering very dangerous, uncharted waters. It is one thing to recoup retrospectively unpaid company tax that should have been paid in the first place. It is entirely another to impose retrospectively a capital gains tax, particularly in respect of accumulations of capital that could go back as far as 50 to 100 years, as would be the situation with some of the companies that would be affected by the legislation. Finally, the Opposition will be behaving consistently with the stance and attitude that it took last year. Our attitude on each of these issues was then explained in virtually the same terms.

In the moments remaining to me I would like briefly to state the Opposition's position in regard to the cash payments legislation. Some features of the legislation disturb us and will be the subject of more detailed comment by the honourable member for Mitchell (Mr Cadman) and others. I refer particularly to the absence of assurances that subcontractors and the subcontracting system, which provides a fine example of independent small business operation in Australia, will be protected. In the absence of such assurances, we are concerned. We would also like some explanation concerning why the Minister for Finance has gone soft and has raised the threshold from $3,000 to $10,000. He is the great anti-tax avoidance crusader, but when it comes to a little cash, he buckles at the knees on the first test. The Minister said that $7,000m was sloshing around out there; that all that was needed was to apply the great sponge that would be provided by a Labor Government and soak it all up. What is his first offering? It is a pretty miserable compromise, having in mind the original announcement by the former Government.

I know a little about this legislation. I had a little bit of dicussion concerning it when I was the Treasurer with not only officers of the Government but also the business community. I would like to know why the Minister for Finance has lifted the threshold from $3,000 to $10,000. Why is he going so soft in this area? Why has this great crusader suddenly gone soft on this issue? The Opposition will move a second reading amendment which will relate to contractors . We will follow the course of the legislation very carefully. The Minister knows as well as I do that many people in the building and construction industries are concerned about this proposal. Let me say in fairness-I wish to state the position truthfully-that the Opposition supports the principle of the legislation. It was embraced in the last Budget. I know that it is unpopular with such bodies as the Housing Industry Association, which has genuinely held concerns. I did not fully accept them when I was the Treasurer, indicating that the legislation would go ahead and that we did not support a reporting system. To that extent I am on common ground with the Government and will not pretend to oppose the substance of this legislation. Indeed, I support it. However, if we in this Parliament are to become really serious about the cash economy certain action must be taken. I believe that it costs the revenue literally thousands of millions of dollars more now than do sophisticated tax avoidance arrangements which, as most experts realise, are completely and utterly dead. The best evidence of that is that we have seen no legislation designed to kill it off come forward from the new Government. If we are to become really serious about the cash economy in Australia we will have to consider changing our taxation base and place a much greater reliance on indirect taxation.

TALK.START.PARA: —No, that is no solution.

—Government supporters want to have it both ways. My views on the subject are well known to the Parliament and to the Australian community. I believe in indirect taxation and believe that there should be a greater reliance on it. Overall, that is the kind of change that we must move towards if we are to become really serious about the problem. The Opposition will monitor very carefully this legislation and its operation. At a later stage I will move that the motion for the second reading of the Income Tax Assessment Bill be amended in these terms:

SPEECH.PARA: That all words after 'That' be omitted with a view to substituting the following words:
whilst not declining to give the Bill a second reading, the House is of the opinion that it contains inadequate provision to protect the independence and continued survival of sub-contractors.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before calling the honourable member for Bendigo, could I suggest to honourable members who have difficulty in knowing how to address a woman in the chair that Mr Speaker suggests that 'Madam Deputy Speaker' would be quite acceptable.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brumby Mr J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to join this debate and speak in support of the wide range of new and amending taxation legislation which is now before the House. The Taxation (Unpaid Company Tax) Assessment Amendment Bill and the Taxation (Unpaid Income Tax-Dividends) Bill give effect to the Government's election undertaking to recover personal tax avoidance by former owners of companies which were the subject of bottom-of-the-harbour schemes. The legislation provides that persons who benefited from the sale of shares in companies that were stripped of pre-tax profits should not be limited only to the tax that should have been paid by the company concerned but should also pay the tax that, as shareholders or other former owners, they escaped through receipt in a non-taxable capital form of accumulated after tax profits that, if the companies had continued to operate as going concerns, would have been taxable as dividends in their hands. The revenue implications of these two Bills is significant and I shall comment on that matter and others related to this Bill in a short time.

SPEECH.PARA: The Income Tax Assessment Amendment Bill 1983 gives effect to a range of taxation measures which were announced by the previous Government but which had not been implemented by the time of the election. Four Bills, the Income Tax ( Rates) Amendment Bill, the Income Tax (Individuals) Amendment Bill, the Income Tax (Companies) Corporate Unit Trusts and Superannuation Funds) Amendment Bill and the Income Tax (Payments for Work) (Consequential Amendments) Bill 1983 provide either consequential amendments or complementary legislation supporting the major Bill. The major features of the substantive Bill provide for the introduction of a system of deductions at source from payments for works and services, for a new system of accelerated depreciation allowances for new and second hand plant and for a modification of the scheme of tax incentives for investment in the production of qualifying Australian films. The remaining Bill before the House, the Income Tax Assessment Amendment Bill (No. 2) gives effect to a number of the taxation proposals arising from last Thursday's economic statement delivered by the Treasurer (Mr Keating). In the limited time available , I propose to concentrate my remarks on the two substantive aspects of the legislation before the House, that is the witholding tax provisions of the Income Tax Assessment Amendment Bill and the Taxation (Unpaid Company Tax) Assessment Amendment Bill.

The need for a system of deductions of tax at source for payments for works and services is clear and has been well documented over many years. The Asprey Taxation Review Committee considered this matter in some detail in its report dated 31 January 1975. The Committee recognised that the tax instalment deduction system applied to payments of income made in circumstances where a relationship of employer and employee existed. However, in the absence of such a relationship, the Committee recommended that all payments substantially for the labour of one person or a small group of persons should be subject to a flat rate tax at source. The system envisaged by the Committee was similar to those which have been in operation in the United Kingdom and in New Zealand for several years. They advocated that an exemption, wholly or partially, from the flat rate deductions at source should be made available in certain circumstances . In its report the Committee suggested:

The areas of activity to be covered by extending tax deductions at source might include the building and construction industry; primary production, including forest operations and fishing; the entertainment industry, including professional sport; and freelance writing.

Following that report in 1975, the previous Federal Government, in its Budget of 15 August 1978, foreshadowed a number of measures designed to curtail avoidance of tax liabilities by persons paid in cash without deductions of tax for various forms of labour and services. The then Treasurer, in foreshadowing these measures, said that the amendments had become necessary because persons who had traditionally stood in the relationship of employer and employee were, to an increasing extent, entering into arrangements under which former employees assumed the role of independent contractors, thereby being entitled to payment in cash without deduction of tax at the source. Despite those announcements in 1978, it was not until the 1982-83 Budget that the former Government announced its decision to introduce a system of deducting at source an amount on account of tax in respect of certain payments for labour and services. The necessary legislation had not been introduced by the time of the recent Federal election and the Bill proposing these deductions at source is now before the House.

The proposals in that Bill have important revenue implications. A number of overseas studies on the cash economy estimate that cash transactions constitute somewhere between four per cent and 30 per cent of the size of the total income economy. Australian estimates calculated this year indicate that as much as 36 per cent of all transactions might occur in the cash economy. Indeed, as one Australian study has suggested, between $2,000m and $2,700m of income tax is not paid because of the cash economy which represents slightly more than 10 per cent of total income tax receipts for the previous financial year. It should also be emphasised that this proposal to deduct tax at source and thereby minimise evaded tax liabilities is entirely consistent with the spirit of discussions at the recent National Economic Summit Conference. Clause 29 of the joint communique, released after the Summit, stated:

All parties believe that there is a special obligation in the current environment to ensure that artificial tax avoidance and evasion is removed, including in the cash economy, and for the further development of the general understanding to this effect.

This income tax amendment Bill also honours an important election commitment made by the Australian Labor Party in respect of the Australian film industry. I comment briefly on that. In the policy speech of 16 February this year, the now Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) in respect of the Australian film industry stated:
Our main priorities in government will be to closely monitor, and adjust where necessary, film industry tax incentives to ensure the stability and expansion of quality Australian film production.

Under existing legislation, film organisers have been obliged to produce scripts , raise funds, complete production and exhibit, all within an effective 12-month period. This has led to a definite bunching of films into an effective six- months production timetable. In the circumstances, production costs have been forced upward and the quality of films has been forced downward. The proposed amendments overcome this situation by allowing an effective maximum of up to three years and, through other measures, provide for overall increased support of the Australian film industry.

I turn now to examine details of the recoupment provisions detailed in the Taxation (Unpaid Company Tax) Assessment Amendment Bill and the Taxation (Unpaid Income Tax-Dividends) Bill. The (Unpaid Company Tax) Bill and (Unpaid Income Tax -Dividends) Bill, as I have said, honour election commitments to recover personal tax avoided by former owners of companies which were the subject of bottom-of-the-harbour taxation schemes. These Bills also have important revenue implications for the Australan people and this Government. Under the existing recoupment legislation, it is anticipated that some $590m of previously avoided tax liabilities will be collected by the end of the 1984-85 financial year. The adoption by the House of this Bill, which incorporates additional measures to recover personal tax liabilities, will result in the collection of an additional $350m in the 1983-84 financial year and an estimated $220m in the 1984-85 financial year. It should be pointed out very clearly that the combined total of existing and proposed recoupment measures will therefore facilitate the collection of almost $1,200m of taxation revenue over the next three to four years. Such a sum, of course, represents almost $200 per head for each Australian taxpayer.

Liberal and National Party opposition to the provisions proposed in this Bill will effectively cost $100 a head for each of Australia's six million taxpayers and will also ensure that future expenditure programs which might be undertaken by this Government will necessarily have to be raised from taxpayers who have already contributed their fair share of the tax revenue while those who have avoided their tax liability over a period of years would remain untaxed. Arguments advanced in opposition to this Bill are specious, and I intend to examine several of the supposedly contentious aspects of the Bill raised by the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard).

Our opponents have argued that there has been no avoidance of personal tax in relation to the capital profits component of accumulated profits on the grounds that, if the vendors had liquidated the stripped company, that part of the liquidators' distribution would represent capital profits which would not be subject to personal tax. The reality is that the profits were stripped while the target companies were, in a practical sense, going concerns, and the existing legislation requires that both revenue and capital profits distributed by an ongoing company should be taxed in full. This approach is consistent with the operation of Part IVA which treats both capital and revenue profits as part of the tax benefit which a vendor-shareholder receives from the dividend stripping scheme to which that Part applies.

Another matter of apparent contention relates to the rate of tax payable on deemed dividends. It is argued that if shareholders are to be taxed on deemed dividends at their marginal rate of personal tax for the year of income in which the shares were sold, certain high rate taxpayers will pay a higher marginal rate than the normal 50 per cent rate which applies to the undistributed profits of private companies. The Government believes it is appropriate that former owners be taxed according to their marginal rate of personal tax, because this rate is the correct measure of the tax they avoided by receiving the profits of the stripped company as a capital sum rather than as a dividend.

It should be noted that the rate of Division 7 undistributed profits tax does not represent the full tax payable on undistributed profits. If undistributed profits tax is paid, the balance of the profits after payment of that tax will be subject to tax when ultimately distributed to shareholders. Upon sale of the shares the vendor-shareholders have, in fact, received the balance of profits in the form of the sale price of the shares.

The final matter relates to the whole question of avoided tax on accumulated profits. It was argued previously by the honourable member for Bennelong that there has been no avoidance of personal income tax in relation to accumulated profits on the grounds that, if the shares in the stripped company had not been sold, the accumulated profits would have been retained in the company indefinitely; that is, until its eventual liquidation. The fact of the matter is that the vendor-shareholders received all the accumulated profits of the stripped company in the form of the sale price of their shares, with some reduction for promoters fees, and the existing income tax law applies. So distributions of profits to shareholders by a company that is a going concern are, indeed, taxed as dividends.

It is my firm view that the Government has been generous in the provisions of this recoupment legislation. In my mind, there is no question that tax has been avoided. There is equally no question that that tax so avoided should rightfully be collected. It is absurd to suggest that this Bill represents a retrospective capital gains tax. If it did, the expected revenue gain over the next four years would be considerably greater than the $570m or $590m which has been estimated. Much of the tax avoided occured between 1975 and 1978. Many people would argue strongly that the Government ought to demand not just the amount avoided at that time but also an additional amount representing the opportunity cost of the interest on those tax liabilities between that time and the present. Clearly, any individual who avoided $1m in 1975 has not only avoided payment of that tax at that time, but also has received the benefit of interest free finance to the value of $1m over some eight years.

Even if that liability to the Government is discharged next financial year, the loss in real terms to Government revenues is in the order of $600,000 and the effective gain in money terms to the tax avoider over that period is equally $ 600,000. As I indicated, I believe the Government has been generous in that respect. Had this Bill provided for the payment of additional interest or penalties, the total revenue yield would increase by some $270m to $280m. In conclusion, I commend all taxation Bills before the House to honourable members. I reject the proposition that the recoupment tax is, in effect, a retrospective capital gains tax. I particularly commend the latter Bills, the recoupment Bills , on which I have spoken at some length.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rocher Mr A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to speak on two of the taxation Bills now before the House. Firstly, I will address some remarks to the Taxation (Unpaid Company Tax) Assessment Amendment Bill 1983. Hitherto, the Act which it is proposed to amend by these measures raised a retrospective tax that required assessment of the tax liability equivalent to that which would have applied in the normal course of events-normal, that is, if companies and their current year profits had not been dealt with fraudulently by purchasers, sub-purchasers and/ or their associates.

SPEECH.PARA: The Act, as it stands, imposes no tax obligations on vendor-shareholders where they, the purchasers and the subject companies, all acted at all times entirely within the law and pursuant to written law and decisions of the High Court of Australia. The amendments proposed to change all that in an unprecedented way. If these mindlessly vengeful, vindictive changes are passed by the Parliament, the consequences for the wealth-creating private sector and employment within it will be very serious indeed.

The amendments envisage, among other things, removal of the trigger of fraud as a necessary pre-condition for recoupment taxes; the raising of taxes and penalty taxes on lawfully accumulated, undistributed profits on which company, possibly Division 7, taxes have already been paid; and raising of taxes and penalty taxes on capital reserves, capital gains and even goodwill. I point out that some of those capital reserves are non-cash items, as is the case with goodwill. Profits accumulated over many years, after distribution of mandatory dividends and payment of undistributed profits tax, become taxable under these proposals. It should be acknowledged that if those accumulated profits had been distributed by way of dividend or on liquidation if the winding up process had left a surplus in shareholder's funds, shareholders would have been taxed for funds distributed , but at marginal rates ranging from about 30c to 60c in the dollar.

However, I want to assure the House that that did not happen in many cases which are the subject of these measures. Many companies were sold in a manner which the High Court of Australia ruled completely legal. Despite the legality of transactions and the once legal tax benefits that accrued, a liability to pay a new tax is now to be created. The given reasons for this legislation are faulty in that certain sets of circumstances are likely to have happened which make them faulty. I will now read an account from a constituent of those likely circumstances. I do so even though it is a long passage because I think it expresses the view adequately. It reads:

Many of the companies in which the shares were sold had been carrying on a business. The purchasers were not interested in carrying on the business of the company and the shareholders still wished to carry on the business of the company. Accordingly, the business of the company was sold to another company in which those vendor shareholders also held shares, perhaps a new company formed to take over the transferred business.

The new company did not have sufficient funds with which to purchase the business from the company whose shares were being sold by the vendor shareholders. What happened is that the vendor shareholders, from their proceeds of sale, loaned those funds to the new company, so as to enable it to pay the old company for the business. In this type of case, the consideration received by the vendor shareholders for their shares was not able to be retained in the pockets of the vendors but was immediately re-injected into the business, which was now owned by the new company. In fact, it was also necessary for the new company to obtain further funds to enable it to purchase the business, as funds were needed to replace that part of the assets of the old company which went to the promotors by way of fee on the transaction.

Thus the situation was that, on the one hand, the new company had assets in its business represented by trading stock, debtors and cash, whereas on the other side it had a loan owing to its shareholders of the amount injected into the company. Although the tax on the current year profit may have been able to be met from the company's liquid assets, that was not so with accumulated profits which had been converted into non-cash assets. The Bill now seeks to tax amounts which have been re-injected into the company and are still tied up in the form of working capital within the business. Payment of the dividend recoupment tax could only be made by liquidating the company's assets and, in a great number of cases, this will mean the closing down of the business with consequential unemployment of literally hundreds of employees.

I heard the Deputy Leader of the Opposition, Mr Howard, make that point starkly. This amending legislation requires vendor shareholders to be treated as if they had received a dividend from the company, and that is plainly not the case. It may be all right if the shareholders had received the proceeds in cash and were free to spend them, but in cases in which proceeds from sales were used to ensure that businesses were able to continue uninterrupted, gross inequities arise. It is patently unreasonable for those vendors who were not free to spend the proceeds of a sale to have to find funds to pay tax on accumulated profits which, for all intents and purposes, are still locked up in a continuing business.
The Minister for Finance (Mr Dawkins), in his second reading speech, said that vendors:

. . . escaped through receipt in a non-capital form of accumulated after-tax profits, that, if the companies had continued to operate as going concerns, would have been taxable as dividends in their hands.

The plain truth is that if the company had continued in business as a going concern, those accumulated after tax profits would not have been distributed. In the cases I have outlined, the vendors have continued the previous businesses as new companies without interruption and with all the funds of the old fully utilised in the new. Remembering that the transactions I have outlined were legal and at the time had the imprimatur of the High Court of Australia, these new taxes should not be imposed in the cases described.

The Australian Labor Party in its 1983 policy speech professed an appreciation of the importance of profits and the ability of companies to retain them. On 16 February 1983 the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) said:
We shall legislate to allow up to 100 per cent retention of profits by small businesses where these funds are to be used for genuine business operations.

If that remains one of the few promises to be kept, this legislation should reflect that commitment. These amendments should not attack, by new retrospective taxes, accumulated profits which were immediately reinvested in a business taking over the business of a former entity. The only exception to that general proposition may, perhaps, be vendor shareholders whose reinvested funds were subsequently distributed to shareholders by the new company.

This Bill proposes, among other things, to repeal sub-section 3 (12) of the present Act. This sub-section provides exemption from the provisions of the principal Act to vendor shareholders of companies which were not part of a stripping arrangement, and for other specified reasons. The Minister for Finance has claimed that the provision 'defies logic'. The logic offered by the previous Government for including sub-section 3 (12) in the principal Act may defy only the Minister's logic, which seems to be clouded by his lust for vengeance.

TALK.START.PARA: —I got you your pre-selection, Allan. What are you talking about? Were it not for me, you would not be here.
—The honourable member will ignore the interjection and continue.

—I am sure that the Minister is numbered among that whole number of back bench left wing crows that comprises a large part of the back bench and a great deal of the Government, but he may yet have the perverse satisfaction of cawing over and picking over the bones of the Australian economy if he does not come to his senses. Examined unemotionally, the previous Government's logic called for vendor shareholders who benefited financially from the subsequent and fraudulent activities of purchasers or their associates to recompense the Revenue. Vendor shareholders were deemed to be innocent of any prior knowledge of the fraudulent intent of the purchasers, and rightly so. Indeed, where fraud did not occur subsequently, the previous Government's rationale for its legislation was not present. It is as simple as that. I might add that that should be perfectly clear and logical, even to the Minister for Finance. His amendments, including the repeal of sub-section 3 (12), adopt the simple if preposterous concept of retrospectively taxing what were at the time they took place perfectly legal transactions, not distinguishable by the presence of fraud . There are other reasons that I should like to advance for my opposition to the Bill, but I estimate that time will not permit that. I simply observe that the title of one of the Acts becomes a little inappropriate because it is no longer dealing solely with unpaid company tax.

SPEECH.PARA: I turn now to another of the Bills being cognately debated, which is to provide for what is rather quaintly called collection of tax at source. It is a new system of collection restricted in its application to certain industries and occupations. In effect, the reputable in certain areas of endeavour are to become tax collectors and policemen in the unpaid service of the Australian Taxation Office and this Government. The paperwork and bureaucratic procedures to be imposed on business are not only onerous in terms of legal obligations; they will also be enormously costly to those charged with the responsibility of reporting, deducting and remitting payments which are of a certain kind. What that kind is has yet to be prescribed but we are told that it will be prescribed in future regulation; I repeat-in future regulation.

So incompetent is this Government that Parliament is being asked to debate the merits of legislation without knowing the essential ingredient-that is, what kind of payments are to be considered source payments. Are deductions to be made or reported only by the payer who is the first in a chain of transactions, for instance? Is a payment by a building contractor to a sub-contractor the beginning and the end, or are subsequent payments by the sub-contractor to his sub-contractor also to be caught in the net? What about payments by the sub-sub- contractor to his sub-contractor? Those chains of events occur. Because it is extensive and sophisticated beyond the capabilities of this Government apparently to understand, the contracting system which is integral to the building industry could well be among the first casualties of this legislation. By the time that the first dollar paid by the prime contractor finds its way to the end of the line, it could be worth much less than 50c. That would be so in very many cases.

This legislation has the earmarks of an attempt to meet calls to come to grips with tax evasion possibly in what is loosely called-often very loosely called- the cash economy. However, limited as it is to the building industry and associated industries-road transport, vehicle repairs and cleaning-I believe that it will not even scratch the surface. By dint of sheer weight and volume, the big money in the cash economy is to be found in areas such as cash payments made by householders to pensioner and other cleaning ladies, to lawnmowing contractors, to odd job men, and to gardeners and the like. Are Ministers of the Government, in their anxiety to come to grips with tax evasion in the cash economy reporting payments they make to their cleaning ladies for household help to the Taxation Office or the Department of Social Security? I bet they are not, but for spurious and ill-considered reasons they are prepared to single out part of industry for attention. I suspect they are content to inflict in industry and commerce obligations to report payments, to deduct and remit tax deductions which they cannot discipline themselves to do in their private lives. This latest example of double standards will be at great cost and inconvenience to those affected.

In the building industry it will become necessary for the smallest company to report payments to the largest corporations in the land, even though the latter, the large corporations, will be exempt from deduction requirements. What possible justification can there be for a small contractor or even a householder to have to fill in a form each month to report to the Taxation Office payments that he, she or they make in the ordinary course of business to a subsidiary of the Broken Hill Proprietary Co Ltd or even to Monier Ltd? What possible justification can there be for that? That is what is required by this legislation. It is bureaucracy gone mad. Even putting that aside, and we should not, the Government gives us no idea of the level of increased collections as distinct from advanced collections it expects to get from this measure. If it is based on some unsupported notion that tax evasion is rife in the target industries and businesses, we should also have some idea of the cost benefits. The additional costs to be inflicted on the private sector should be justifiable on a cost benefit basis. The benefits to revenue should not be largely or unreasonably offset by the cost of collection-the cost, I might add, to the private sector. We have no way of judging the efficacy of this measure because of an absence of basic fact and information.

As far as exemptions for those who will be entitled to continue to receive deduction free payments are concerned, it seems that another unnecessary imposition to require most to apply for that exemption is to be made. Qualification for exemption could surely be simple. For instance, any employer business which satisfies criteria already in place for qualifying for group employer status in relation to pay-as-you-earn deductions must surely be a business of substance. Why cannot group employer status automatically confer exemption? The same group employer number could be quotable by future payers in their monthly reports on advice from the payees.

These measures have not been thought through. There are implications for affected industries, in the nature of paper work, which cannot be gauged because of the paucity of information from the Government. I am afraid that the insensibility of this Government and its pre-occupation with tax raising measures indicates more to come, perhaps in the next Budget. I caution industry to watch events over the next few months. I sincerely suggest to members of industry that they get on their bikes and lobby this Government hard because we do not want further deterioration of business in this country with all that that means for the wealth creation process which only the private sector can create and be responsible for.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown Mr R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The legislation which the House is considering at this time represents a very significant list of Bills, all of which are important in connection with the general structure of the taxation system in Australia. The particular Bills out of that set to which I will restrict my comments are the Taxation (Unpaid Company Tax) Assessment Amendment Bill 1983 and the Taxation (Unpaid Income Tax-Dividends) Bill 1983. Most of the contribution towards the debate that I have heard so far appears to have been concentrated in that area.

SPEECH.PARA: The passage of this legislation will take the Hawke Government further down the track to meeting its major commitments to the Australian people. In particular I refer to this Government's commitment to questions of equity and justice. I refer to its commitment to ensure that the taxation system as a whole operates fairly with equity and justice to all people in the Australian community, and its commitment to the ordinary wage and salary earners who for too long have been carrying the burden for the tax sharks in the Australian community. It was made perfectly clear during the period that the present Government was in opposition that, given the opportunity to put into place equitable and just taxation measures, as the Government of Australia, the Australian Labor Party would be certain to do those things. I congratulate the Minister for Finance (Mr Dawkins) for the rapidity with which these measures have been brought forward.

The present Government's intentions in relation to this legislation have been made clear on at least two occasions, so it does not make very much sense for the former Treasurer, the honourable member for Bennelong, (Mr Howard) and other people in the community at large who have canvassed this matter to suggest that in some way aspects of this legislation have been sprung on the community. The nonsense references to a capital gains tax being applied retrospectively I would put into that category. As I said, notice was served by the present Government on at least two occasions to indicate the direction it would take in relation to the original legislation which was passed last year. The first occasion on which notice was served was when the original Bill, was being considered by the Parliament last year; and secondly, our intentions were also indicated during the election campaign. There is no doubt that this Government has sought and has been granted a very clear mandate to proceed along the lines along which it is proceeding at present.

The recoupment legislation of last year will be substantially strengthened by this legislation. In effect it picks up all of those deficiencies, which we identified during the debate last year in order to make that legislation much more effective-with one exception. We might well call this the present Government's own hardship clause. That one exception relates to our earlier proposal to index the recouped tax to a current value, equal in real terms to the tax which was not paid at the time it was avoided. In other words, if the tax we are about to pick up, as a result of this legislation, was avoided in 1974, the tax that would be applied to those people who avoided it in 1974 would be, in real terms, equal to the amount in that year. In other words it would have been indexed from 1974 until 1983. We have indicated that we will not proceed with that proposition. I emphasise the generosity with which the Government has approached those tax avoiders as a result of that decision. The Minister in his second reading speech said:
The measures contained in this Bill are estimated to yield $570m in total, and $350m in 1983-84.
He continued:
If the Government had required payment not only of tax owing but also of an additional amount for the period of delay in payment, the total revenue yield would have been $840m.

So it appears that something like $300m in real terms, as a result of this legislation, will not be picked up from those people who initially avoided those amounts of tax. The honourable member for Bendigo, Mr Brumby, who spoke a short time ago, indicated that, in effect, what this means is that those people who engaged knowingly in tax avoidance practices have had the use of Commonwealth funds interest free from the time they engaged in those practices. Now, I think that is a remarkably generous concession for this Government to make towards tax avoiders. Let it not be said that this Government is unsympathetic to the types of situations in which these sharks, these crooks and these shysters might find themselves. We are extremely generous. This provision makes that perfectly clear .

There is one matter to which I want to give special mention. The question has been canvassed both here in the Parliament, and particularly by the former Treasurer, the present Opposition spokesman on Treasury matters, the honourable member for Bennelong, and more widely in the community, as to whether or not these provisions represent or include in some way a tax on capital gains. The honourable member for Bennelong, in an earlier contribution in this debate, went so far as to say that we were introducing a retrospective capital gains tax.

TALK.START.PARA: —Quite so.

—The honourable member for Hume, who is sitting at the table, interjected. He said: 'Quite so'. I am glad he said that. Obviously he has some responsibility for the Opposition in this debate, just as the honourable member for Bennelong has some responsibility. I want to nail this matter and nail it once and for all. I hope those who are not listening to the debate at the present time at least take the opportunity to read what I have to say and that they will not repeat that claim again. It has been argued that there has been no avoidance of personal tax in relation to the capital profits component of accumulated profits on the grounds that if the vendor has liquidated the stripped company, that part of the liquidator's distribution which represented capital profits would not be subject to personal tax. That has been the claim by those people who have suggested that this legislation represents, in some way, a tax on capital gains.
—That is not all.

—That is the essence of the point that has been made. Let me nail it. The question of whether or not personal tax was escaped in relation to the accumulated capital profits of a stripped company depends on what, in substance, actually happened as a result of the scheme carried out to strip the company rather than on what might have happened had the vendors not sold their shares but instead retained control of the company.
—You are barking up the wrong tree.

—I will not be sidetracked from the point I want to make. I understand the embarrassment which has been caused to the honourable member for Hume (Mr Lusher). I understand the embarrassment that will be experienced by the honourable member for Bennelong as soon as he takes advantage of the opportunity to read what I have to say. I will not be sidetracked again in relation to the explanation I want to make.

SPEECH.PARA: Two features of the bottom-of-the-harbour schemes are significant. First, the vendors, in fact, received the profits, both capital and revenue, of the target company at a time when the company was not in the course of liquidation. Indeed, even today, many of the target companies are still in existence even though many years have passed since the profits were liberated to the vendor shareholders. Secondly, the schemes did not involve the discontinuation of the business of the target company. On the contrary the business was almost invariably transferred to another entity, either a company or a trust, controlled by the former owners of the target company. These two features of the scheme led the Government to conclude that the former owners should be taxed as though they received the profits of the target company while it was a going concern.

The existing income tax legislation requires that both revenue and capital profits distributed by an ongoing company not in liquidation should be taxed in full. Accordingly, personal tax has been escaped in relation to both revenue and capital profits of the target company. This approach is consistent-I emphasise that-with the operation of Part 4A which treats both capital and revenue profits stripped from a company as the tax benefit which vendor shareholders receive from a dividend stripping scheme to which that Part applies. That is particularly significant because the honourable member for Bennelong, who was making the claim that this represented in some way a new type of retrospective tax on capital gains, was the person who introduced that legislation. Now apparent to me is the honourable member for Bennelong's deficiency in understanding just exactly what the new Part 4A meant. He introduced it into this Parliament, when Treasurer, but he did not understand the significance of it, to a very large extent. The honourable member for Bennelong said that there was nothing new in this legislation which had not been canvassed during the debate last year. That is true. There is nothing new in this legislation which was not canvassed during the debate last year.

One of the points made at that time was that there was a possibility-we had considered it-that in order to achieve the objectives of this legislation all we needed to do was to extend back the provisions of the former Treasurer's Part 4A to 1972. We could have done it that way. We choose not to. In fact, we have chosen to introduce amending legislation to achieve the same objectives. But there was a possibility that we could have done it that way. Why was it possible that we could have done it that way? Because the provisions in this legislation are provisions of essentially the same kind which are contained in Part 4A for which the legislation was introduced by the honourable member for Bennelong. I think we need to be reasonable. I think the honourable member for Bennelong needs to be reasonable. He cannot have it both ways. He introduced Part 4A. If that Part 4A contains exactly the same sort of provisions that are contained in the legislation he cannot, on the one hand, support his own legislation and, on the other hand, condemn this legislation. As a result of that very serious inconsistency into which the honourable member for Bennelong has fallen, that is the position in which he finds himself.

The original legislation was introduced into this Parliament by the former Treasurer on 23 September last year. It was then reintroduced in a changed form on 21 October 1982 after what was referred to at that time as 10 days of protracted negotiations with the back bench. Why were these protracted negotiations with the back bench required? They were required because members of the back bench at that time were responding to the pressures being exerted on them by powerful financial and crook interest in the Australian community. They were then, in turn, applying pressure on the Treasurer and, indirectly then, through the Treasurer--

TALK.START.PARA: —I take a point of order, Mr Deputy Speaker. The use of the expression 'crook' in the context of this debate and in the context in which the honourable member for Hunter, for whom I have a very healthy respect as a lusty debater, uses it goes beyond all the bounds of reason and truth.

—Order! The honourable gentleman has made his point of order. The point of order is not upheld. The honourable member for Hunter was talking about crook influences being exerted. I think that was the term he used. It is not a reflection on the honourable member. There is no point of order.
—I am not suggesting it was. It is a reflection on him.
—I am not the crook. We know who the crooks are. We know the Denis Horgans, Brian Mahers and all of those people who have been given some protection.
—Order! The honourable member will be out of order if he proceeds along those lines.
—With respect to you, Mr Deputy Speaker--

—Mr Deputy Speaker, I raise a point of order. The reference to Mr Horgan is most unfair, particularly as the Attorney-General in the Labor Government certified to this Parliament that there was nothing out of order in relation to that gentleman. The honourable member ought to have the decency to withdraw his comments.

—I will not withdraw any statement I have made. I will not call Denis Horgan a crook again; that is already in the Hansard. As all honourable members know, Denis Horgan was up to his eyes in the dry Slutzkin schemes. I will not be intimidated by these people who suggest that in some way I have to restrain the references that I use in connection with people such as that. As I have said, the legislation was reintroduced into the Parliament on 21 October. It came back after 10 days of protracted negotiations with the back bench. We all understand the factors, forces and pressures that lie behind that. The Opposition shadow Treasurer at that time, the honourable member for Gellibrand ( Mr Willis) who is now the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations, responded at the second reading stage of the debate. In the limited time available to me I want to have his comments recorded in Hansard because I think they sum up more than adequately our general concern about this legislation and about the lack of genuineness on the part of the previous Government in connection with its appraoch to questions of this kind. The honourable member said:

SPEECH.PARA: The Taxation (Unpaid Company Tax) Assessment Bill (No. 2) and associated Bills now before the House, far from being the triumph over tax dodgers which the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) has so proudly proclaimed, represent only the latest chapter in the greatest tax scandal which this nation has ever known, a chapter which again demonstrates the Government's weakness in dealing with tax dodgers. It is a scandal which has encompassed negligence and culpability on the part of senior Ministers, inexcusable government delay, bureaucratic bungling and incompetence, protection of tax dodgers in the Liberal Party's own ranks, irreparable government splits and prime ministerial hypocrisy and inconsistency. The smell of this scandal has tainted not only the entire government but also has reached far into some of the previously most exclusive sections of the Australian establishment. Most of all, however, this scandal has encompassed a massive rip-off of the vast majority of honest Australian taxpayers.

How dare honourable members on the opposite side of the House suggest that there may have been some offence in terms that I use within this Parliament? The obscene offence has been committed by people outside this building-people in the financial establishment, in the commercial world and within the legal fraternity . It has been committed by the accountants and all the people who promoted, devised, implemented, encouraged and enticed shareholders in private companies and other companies to do what they could to avoid their tax responsibility so that, as we know, the total area of tax avoidance and tax evasion in Australia represented something in excess of $30 every week for taxpaying families.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lusher Mr S.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is a certain deja vu about this debate. Earlier this afternoon I looked at Hansard from October 1982 when I made a contribution to the debate on the principal Act. The Taxation (Unpaid Company Tax) Assessment Bill was being debated at that time and it is the subject of amendment today. I noticed that in the debate I preceded the honourable member for Hunter (Mr Robert Brown). He was still in the chamber and was interjecting on me during that debate. Here we are again. We might have changed the side of the House on which we sit, but probably little else has changed. A package of Bills is before the House. The Taxation (Unpaid Company Tax) Assessment Amendment Bill and the Taxation (Unpaid Income Tax-Dividends) Bill undeniably are the most important aspects of the package before us. I think the payments for work section of the Income Tax Assessment Amendment Bill is fairly significant also, particularly as it is Labor's first attempt, maybe its only attempt, to come to grips with the problems of the cash economy in our society.

SPEECH.PARA: The Opposition intends to oppose the retrospective legislation that is before us. That attitude, as my colleague the Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) pointed out, is consistent with the attitude that we took last year when we were in Government. The provisions of the Bills which we will oppose are the reverse of the legislation that we passed or, alternatively, are proposing change that was considered by the Government and rejected in October last year when the legislation was before the House. Principally, my opposition to this legislation is that it creates a new liability and creates that liability in a retrospective fashion. The Taxation (Unpaid Company Tax) Assessment Amendment Bill opens up the whole sorry debate about retrospectivity and recoupment that led to so much bitterness and genuine concern last year.

Let us be clear about a few things right from the start. Last year's legislation was recoupment legislation. This legislation is retrospective legislation. Last year's legislation recovered a benefit which was in the hands of beneficiary vendor-shareholders. The Bill creates new liabilities that did not exist before, and imposes a penalty rate of tax on that new liability.
