Last year's legislation dealt with outstanding assessments, uncollected but assessed company tax. This Bill will require new assessments to be issued in most cases, I suspect, going back to before 1980 when the schemes were effectively stopped after Part IV of the Crimes Act was introduced by the former Treasurer.

There is no precedent for legislation of this nature. I believe it will make thinking Australians sick to the stomach. It goes against all principles of fairness and equity and all because of the Australian Labor Party's ideological hatred of free enterprise and the ability of the private sector to order its financial affairs according to the law of the land. I believe it is essential that this legislation at least be delayed. There must be further debate on the matters that have been put before the House by the Minister for Finance (Mr Dawkins). There must be further consideration not only in this Parliament but also outside of the matters raised in this legislation. I think there has been indecent haste about the proposals that we are being asked to consider.

This legislation was introduced into the Parliament on 18 May, a week ago. It is being debated today. As I understand it, the Government expects that it will go through the House today. It is being debated, as far as the outside world is concerned-I think that is important in matters of high taxation policy, as this undoubtedly is-in an atmosphere of ignorance. I do not think anybody yet understands what is in this legislation and what the Government is seeking to do . Those of us who were here at the time will recall the extent of discussion and debate, the extent to which people were able to put views-and ultimately the consideration given by the then Treasurer to that debate and those views-and the amendments that were made in last year's recoupment legislation. This legislation is far more significant than last year's legislation ever was and I believe it deserves at least a similar amount of time for consideration by the community.

I am concerned that the Minister for Finance in his second reading speech creates a series of hypothetical situations and then seeks to apply tax to those situations. His second reading speech is riddled with phrases such as 'if', 'on the basis that', 'imputed dividend', 'deemed to have been paid' and a range of others which are, if nothing else, totally lacking in certainty. Phrases in the Bill include 'if the companies had continued to operate as going concerns', 'on the basis that the company had paid a dividend to the former owner', 'this imputed dividend', et cetera, and 'the dividend will be deemed to have been paid '. They are totally hypothetical situations. This is not satisfactory.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is Dawkinsspeak.
—It is Dawkinsspeak as opposed to Hawkespeak.

—Order! I take the opportunity to mention that there has been a tendency of late for honourable members to refer to other honourable members by their names rather than by the names of their electorates. I think it is far better that we arrest that trend as early as possible.

—This legislation is of vital concern because people will be faced with taxation assessments which would not previously have been issued. They cannot be issued until this legislation is passed. It needs to be made clear that the Government has no mandate for this legislation. The Commonwealth has never been entitled to collect tax on company reserves at a penalty rate of 60 per cent. I do not believe that the Government put that to the electorate at any stage and it absolutely improper to claim a mandate for that provision. Two things need to be understood: There is no suggestion of revenue lost to the Commonwealth under anything that the Government is seeking to change by this legislation; and distributions for capital reserves never have been taxable on liquidation. As anybody who knows anything about business would know, which eliminates most people on the Government side of the House by definition-I defer to the honourable member for Robertson (Mr Cohen) who obviously knows a great deal about business-nobody would distribute reserves if a company was to be of an ongoing nature.

SPEECH.PARA: The Bill, if enacted, will impose a dividend recoupment tax. It will assume that a dividend may have been paid and that that dividend would have been taxable in the hands of the recipient. It will then proceed to collect that tax. In legitimate non-bottom-of-the-harbour situations the income that will in reality be taxed was a capital payment on the sale of shares. Because of that, the Bill will impose tax on capital gains retrospectively.

I listened to what the honourable member for Hunter (Mr Robert Brown) had to say when he preceded me on this matter, especially the remarks that he made toward the end of his speech. He was not dealing with the real issue. I pointed out to him that he was barking up the wrong tree. What the Opposition and I are concerned about, as far as the retrospective capital taxing aspects of this legislation are concerned, is simply that what the Government seeks to do is to redefine capital as income and then tax that income retrospectively. That has the effect of taxing retrospectively, capital gains. There goes just another of the Hawke Labor Government's election promises. The Government is effectively legislating to overturn the High Court's decision in the Slutzkin case and is seeking to make that legislation retrospective. The existing Act, the former Treasurer's Act, fully provides for recoupment of taxes which were not collected . This Bill proposes penalty taxes that were never lost to revenue. There was no assessable income to be taxed and there still is not. This Bill has to create that revenue before it can tax it. This Bill retrospectively creates assessable income and then turns around and taxes it at 60 per cent. That is pretty insidious legislation.

The Slutzkin case established the principle that the purchase price received on the sale of shares in a company with accumulated profits was not taxable. If in fact a company is to be wound up for whatever reason the distribution of capital profits and reserves is not taxable although, to the extent that the distribution is from revenue, profits would be taxable. What would people who had to dispose of companies do? Obviously they would take the advice of their accountants-for all sorts of honourable reasons; there is no suggestion of scheming-and, having the requirement to dispose of companies because of the change in the nature of business, they would take the Slutzkin track and sell the shares in the company to people who were prepared to pay for them rather than wind up the company, distribute the proceeds and run the risk of having to pay tax unnecessarily under the legal framework at that time on that part of the distribution that may have been from revenue profit. That is perfectly proper. There is nothing illegal or wrong about that. But this Government wants to redefine that and say: 'Well, that is all income; that is not capital and we are going to change it retrospectively and impose a penalty rate of tax of 60 per cent on it'. There was nothing wrong with Slutzkin. What was wrong was that purchasers or promoters, who in some cases were rogues, paid a premium for companies that were subsequently rendered incapable of paying the company tax that had been assessed on the profits that the companies had made.

The existing Act introduced by the then Treasurer, now Deputy Leader of the Opposition, recovers that unpaid tax from the beneficiary vendor. This Bill not only reverses the Slutzkin decision but also extends the tax liability to capital profits and exempt income that were never liable to tax. I regard that as iniquitous. This Bill removes the earlier requirement that there must have been an arrangement as a result of which the company was rendered unable to pay its company tax. That was provided in clause 5 (1) (h) of the Taxation (Unpaid Company Tax) Assessment Bill 1982. This Bill seeks to have application in any case where the shares have been sold and company tax has not been paid. There is no requirement that there be an arrangement, no requirement that there be some scheme, some fraud or something improper. There is no protection whatsoever for honest, legitimate and decent people who for all sorts of reasons, as part of the restructuring and structuring of their affairs, have to take decisions of that nature. The net of taxation is unfairly widened to include all manner of transactions that may have had proper and justifiable motivation.

But this Bill strikes further at an individual's rights and protection. It removes section 3 (12), the so-called innocents section, that was designed to protect vendor shareholders where the purchaser, who may have been a promoter, and the company acted legally at all times. These were not bottom-of-the-harbour situations and deserved some protection. They were given some protection in the 1982 legislation. This Bill seeks to withdraw that protection. It exposes people who acted legally and who had no taxation liability to a retrospectively created liability which is to be calculated at a penalty rate. If that is not iniquitous , I do not know what is.

I want in the few minutes remaining to make a few comments on other aspects of the package of Bills before the House. Provisions have been put before the Parliament in relation to the cash economy and aspects of payment to contractors for work. As far as I am concerned the Government and the Minister for Finance have squibbed it. They have walked away from any real attempt to deal with the cash economy that operates right through our society and have raised from $3,000 to $10,000 the threshold on the amout that will be considered. Anybody who knows anything about the reality of our society and the cash economy knows it is way below that level that revenue is being lost. It is being lost in hundreds of dollars here and there of taxation that is not being paid.

What is happening is that the Government is imposing further on business. It is asking the business community to collect its taxation for it. There is far too much impost on business. It collects our sales tax and all sorts of other taxes for us but this Government wants it also to collect this withholding tax. In addition to that, it will create a totally bureaucratic situation; it will add significantly to the bureaucracy in this country. As I understand it, the Government will be monitoring all local government approvals for work over $10, 000, for all the 700 or 900 local councils across Australia, so that it can have taxation collected on those amounts.

Before I close I want to draw attention to the further series of slugs on the rural sector. It is absolutely unbelievable that in one week we have seen Bills introduced which, amongst other things, provide for depreciation to be extended from 20 per cent to 30 per cent and then, within days of that, the Treasurer in his mini-Budget reversed that decision before it had even gone through Parliament. The bush is in a bad enough position without having to take slugs of that nature, let alone cope with measures like that being introduced in such an absurd way. It points out that the decision making process of the Government is out of control. I reiterate that I will not have a bar of the retrospective legislation. I will not support it and I know my colleagues in the National Party will not either.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cohen The Hon B.

TALKER.NAME: Mr COHEN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Home Affairs and Environment)

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight in this cognate debate I want to make my remarks on tax changes regarding the film industry. I hope that I will make a slightly more measured contribution than the honourable member for Hume (Mr Lusher) did.

SPEECH.PARA: No industry has excited the Australian public more than the film industry since its renaissance in the early 1970s. No government has yet found the magic formula that will achieve the much desired yet elusive stability the industry so badly needs. The proposed changes to section 10BA of the Income Tax Assessment Act are an attempt to achieve this. They have the support of both sides of the House-though at the moment only the honourable member for Berowra (Dr Harry Edwards) sits on the opposite side of the House-as the industry itself has always had such support. Wherever one goes in Australia, from the clubs and pubs to the boardrooms of business and right here to Parliament House, there is unanimous pride in the achievements of the industry. Picnic at Hanging Rock, Breaker Morant, Gallipoli and The Man From Snowy River, to name but a few, are films that not only have warmed and entertained Australians but also have had world wide success, even in the highly competitive American market. Today, five of the top 50 films screening in the United States are Australian. It would be an exaggeration to suggest that Australian films are sweeping the world but it is true to say that our films are amongst the most exciting developments in the film world during the past decade.

Australia is no longer an unknown, largely boring land mass somewhere in the southern hemisphere. Jack Thompson, Mel Gibson and Judy Davis are almost as well known as our piddling koalas. Fred Schepsi, Bruce Beresford and Peter Weir are in constant demand in the United States to produce and direct films. The new Aussie wave of film making is not a fortunate accident; it happended because a few people had vision and determination. They were called dreamers, living in fantasyland. Australia once had a thriving film industry credited with producing one of the first full length feature movies, Soldiers of the Cross. Until recently, however, the efforts of pioneers such as Ken Hall, Charles Chauvel, Frank King Sr and Raymond Longford had been largely in vain. Despite a few attempts after World War II with films such as The Overlanders, Eureka Stockade, Bitter Springs and Bush Christmas, by the 1950s the Australian film industry had virtually ceased to exist. For the next 20 years films about Australia were made here by British and American producers and actors. Much as I admire John Mills and Ernest Borgnine, it was absurd to see them play a couple of Australian cane cutters in Summer of the Seventeenth Doll. Occassionally an Australian actor such as Rod Taylor or Peter Finch made it overseas but he did so without having been part of a local industry and without being identifiably Australian.

The critical year for the industry was 1970. People like Phillip Adams, Tony Buckley and our colleagues the Minister for Science and Technology (Mr Barry Jones) and the President of the Senate lobbied the government of the day to revive our film industry. The then Prime Minister, John Gorton, responded by appointing Phillip Adams, Barry Jones and the present honourable member for Wentworth (Mr Coleman) to an interim film committee that visited such countries as France, Poland, Canada and Sweden, the governments of which financially supported the establishment of indigenous film industries. The committee recommended that Australia have a film school, an experimental film fund and a film bank. But then John Gorton was sacked and the new Prime Minister, Sir William McMahon, appointed Peter Howson, not exactly the most visionary of members of parliament, to be the Minister responsible for implementing the committee's recommendations. When Howson failed to take any action Phillip Adams publicly resigned. The following day he received one of the famous McMahon telephone calls with the promise that the committee's recommendations would be accepted. The Australian Film Development Corporation started operating in 1970. I am delighted to say that the Minister for Science and Technology is now in the House. He is one of the very few pioneers of the renaissance of this industry, and Australia can be proud of the role he played. The Australian Film and Television School had to wait until the Whitlam Government took office in 1972.

Though the film industry has enjoyed bipartisan support it has not been without its critics. Fortunately, parliamentarians have been active supporters of the industry and these current amendments to the Income Tax Asessment Act are a further indication of the support the industry receives from the Parliament of Australia. There are critics who believe that the present tax incentives are too generous. I think they fail to understand fully how the film industry differs from other commercial activities.

Until 1977, the cost of a film was written off over 22 years. The Taxation Office regarded the costs of film production as being the same as for the establishment of any other business. Thus, the wages paid to producers, directors, actors and film crew were treated in the same way as wages paid to those who built a factory. These expenses are the capital investment and, as in other enterprise, are not tax deductible-they are part of capital formation. Most successful films continue to earn money for a number of years. After cinema release, there are re-releases, television sales and video cassette sales. That was the major reason for depreciation being allowed over 22 years.

If the purchase of land, buying of shares, building of a factory, setting up of a shop, is not commercially successful, the asset will normally have some resale value. In some cases it is even possible to lose money on the operation and still sell the asset for more than the purchase price. However, if a film is a financial flop, and there are significant numbers in that category, the only thing that can be done with it is to throw it in the waste bin. The product is not an 'asset' but a can of celluloid. Herein is the key difference between film making and most other forms of investment-the very high failure rate of films in commercial terms.

In the United States of America the success rate is one in 10. In Australia it is about one in five or one in six. Since 1970 some 29 films out of 139 made in Australia returned profit. Only very few have provided very large returns to the investors, namely Mad Max, Mad Max II and The Man from Snowy River, which, I might add, is breaking all records. The revival of the industry was the result not of investment but of the involvement of the Australian Film Development Corporation and other State film bodies. In 1977, to reduce direct government involvement and allow market forces to operate, the Federal Government permitted films to be written off over two years-50 per cent in each successive year. At long last the Government had recognised that producing a film was different from building a factory. It accepted that the 80 per cent production costs of a film that consist of wages should be treated as a normal business overhead and granted tax deductibility. The deduction ought to have been allowable within one year. This decision initially was presented as a major concession. I think that the former Treasurer, the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard), who is now in the House, introduced legislation on this matter. As I said, the decision was presented as a major concession. It was not. It was merely the correction of a previous misconception.

However, this apparently generous concession failed to attract investors in significant numbers. Investment in the film industry was still a considerable risk because if a film failed to reach the break-even point it was no great satisfaction to investors to have 60c in the dollar written off in tax if 40c in the dollar was going to be lost in four out of five films. Under this arrangement 100 per cent could be written off over two years. Government had still failed to acknowledge that investment in films was much akin to oil exploration-if one does not strike oil, all one has is a hole in the ground.

I make the point that two different types of people are involved in the film industry today. One group consists of writers, directors, producers, actors and the film crew. They are the people who, no matter what the price, want to remain in the industry because they love it and they would even starve to stay in it. The other group consists of investors who want to invest money. The bottom line for them is profit. There is nothing wrong with that. The Government offers an incentive and the investors pick it up. They are entitled to make a profit. But they will stay in the industry only if there is a bottom line, which is profit.

TALK.START.PARA: —Or a good chance of it.
—Or a good chance of it. When the point is reached where the investment is not attractive with tax write-offs the investors will simply withdraw en masse.

SPEECH.PARA: In late 1980 the Government announced that it would provide a 150 per cent tax write-off plus a tax exemption on 50 per cent of the investment. Thus, on an investment of $1m an investor on the 60c marginal rate would receive a $900,000 tax write-off. Additionally, if the film netted $1m, he would not pay tax on the first $500,000. The initial reaction of most people, myself included, was to regard this as an unbelievably generous incentive, especially attractive to tax avoiders. On closer examination the concession was not nearly as generous as it seemed. First of all, the first 100 per cent, as I said earlier, should always have been deductible. Secondly, a number of expenses such as prospectuses, legal fees, brokerage and marketing costs were not allowable. Marketing costs were permitted as deductions only when income from the film was forthcoming. These expenses amounted to approximately 15 per cent of the total costs, thus only 85 per cent was brought into calculation. The effective tax benefit was 128 per cent, not 150 per cent. If honourable members accept my proposition about capital formation, the net real tax write-off was 28 per cent.

To make matters worse, the Government decided that the film had to be completed in one year. The resulting combination of an apparently generous tax write off-I am not saying that it was not generous but it was not as generous as it appeared to be--

TALK.START.PARA: —You made a mistake about the year.

—Yes. The resulting combination of an apparently generous tax write-off with the requirements for the film to be completed within one year led to chaos. Everyone rushed to take advantage of the benefits. The number of Australian films produced in 1981-82 leaped to an all-time high, stretching resources to the limit. Not surprisingly, costs sky-rocketed. When the dust had settled, a lot of shoddy films had been made and many investors had been left with their fingers burnt. It was true that if an investor put $1m into a film with an effective tax write-off of 128 per cent, he needed a return of approximately only $240,000 to break even. However, three out of five films did not return $ 240,000. This is the most important point that people must remember. One out of five broke even and the fifth went into profit. In the 1982-83 financial year investors gave the film industry a wide berth with only about a dozen feature films being made. The Fraser Government then promised investors the present amendments. These would allow the films to be made in two years and prevent the bunching-up that had occurred previously.

SPEECH.PARA: I believe that it is important to restate the objectives of those who fought so valiantly for the re-establishment of the film industry. They wanted an industry that would foster our unique cultural identity. They hoped that by employing Australian producers, directors, actors and technicians, they would create a strong, viable industry that in time would stand on its own feet. They expected that this would project abroad the desired image of Australia with the concomitant spin-off for trade and tourism. It was envisaged that when this objective was reached, those employed in the industry and the tax revenues they gained by it would repay the Australian taxpayer for his initial investment. Obviously, we have not yet reached that point. Although Australia is producing some excellent films, many are still of inferior quality although I realise that quality requires a subjective judgment. This year, it is anticipated that approximately $40m will be invested in Australian films. The cost to the taxpayer will be approximately $6.5m. This assumes that investors on the marginal tax rate otherwise would have invested their money in projects returning a minimum of 60c in the dollar in tax deductions. This takes no account of the tax and social service clawback that would be evident were the 2, 000 to 3,000 people employed in the industry not working. I believe that we must now assess the industry honestly to ensure that it continues to work towards those original objectives at an acceptable cost to the Australian taxpayer.

During the past 10 weeks I have spent many hours discussing the future of the industry with the dedicated people who work in it. I am very proud to be the responsible Minister. However, I am aware that the industry has its problems. It has its rogues interested only in taking advantage of the tax benefits. It has its incompetents who are never likely to make a quality film. It has those who believe that the film industry has an unchallengeable right to limitless amounts of taxpayers' money. I am sure that everyone in the Parliament wants the present amendments to achieve the objectives I outlined earlier, namely to have an industry that is viable, stable, competent and, above all, Australian. I want the market to be as free as possible. Earlier, the various Federal and State government film bodies, in determining which films should be made, in some cases chose well and funded superb films. In other cases, subjective and value judgments impaired the right decision being made. That will always happen when someone has to make a judgment about which films should or should not be made. It is a matter for concern that there is no way of regulating the number of films made, nor their cost and therefore the limit of the Government's contribution. The present system is too open-ended. I hope that the industry will regulate itself, to ensure that Australia makes high quality films that are both an expression of our cultural and national identity and a commercial success.
In concluding, I would like to quote from David Stratton's excellent book, The Last New Wave, in which he states:

. . . the men and women who work in the Australian film industry make up as fine a group of people as anyone would wish to know. Collectively, they are achieving something unique and very special. Thankfully, our film archives will be able to preserve their achievements for posterity. Their work will last forever and in generations to come, Australians will look back with gratitude to the people who brought about the Renaissance of the Australian cinema while capturing the Seventies on film.
I agree with those sentiments entirely.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cadman Mr A.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —The House is engaged in a debate on a number of tax measures that have been introduced by the new Government. In many ways they represent an excursion by it into the unknown. Some of their aspects that are unknown and difficult have been outlined very capably by the Deputy Leader of the Opposition, the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard). I wish to refer to only a narrow aspect of the measures that have been proposed by the Minister for Finance (Mr Dawkins), those relating to the deduction of tax at source from payments for work and services rendered.

SPEECH.PARA: These provisions have arisen as a result of discussions in the community over a long period and as a result of concern expressed about the level of cash payments, designed to avoid the obligation of the recipient to pay taxation. Various estimates are available of the size of the cash economy. The most reliable appear to indicate that it involves an amount of $1,500m to $2,000m. It represents the most significant part of tax avoidance that has not yet been tackled by the nation. No Government supporter who has spoken has given the previous Government credit for being the first in Australia's history effectively to tackle tax avoidance issues. It moved strongly in that direction by means of successive measures, which caused much concern within the community at times, but were nevertheless needed to stamp out tax avoidance. The last remaining aspect of tax avoidance that warrants serious attention by this House, by the Parliament and by those who have a concern for the revenue and the reduction of the amount of income tax that must otherwise be imposed on individuals, is that concerned with the cash economy.

Tax avoidance by the receipt of cash is prevalent in the Australian community and the Government has moved to tackle a sector in which it feels that cash payments present difficulties of tax collection. It has selected persons and firms operating within the building and construction, architectural, consulting engineering, surveying and other technical building services, joinery and cabinet making, road transport, motor vehicle repair and cleaning industries. They represent a wide spread of industries in which are found a large number of small businesses that are operated by self-employed individuals.

My concern about these measures is based on three aspects. The Government has come forward with legislation that I believe contains some very objectionable features. It hopes to gain 90 per cent compliance so that cash payments which will not attract taxation will amount to only 10 per cent. Time will tell whether the Government will be successful in its endeavour to attain that objective. The legislation proposes a complicated series of procedures involving applications and form filling and seeks to place on the payee the obligation for the payment of taxes. That is appropriate but the legislation contains no indication of an understanding of the complicated nature of what is being attempted.

My first objection is to the proposal that there be an across the board tax at a certain level. I believe that an across the board tax which is to be applied to both materials and labour, to both design and work done, and to both non- taxable items and taxable items is most objectionable. I support strongly the suggested movement to indirect taxes and believe that by that technique taxes can be applied to both materials and services. But to apply an income tax measure across a wide range of goods and services is a most objectionable feature.

I would like to provide the House with some details concerning the way in which what is proposed can affect individuals. I am obliged to a firm of accountants for anonymous details concerning the work of some of its clients. I take first the case of a Melbourne metropolitan trading company, a roofing subcontractor. It is a large company with a gross income of $305,000. The net profit of a company of that size, making allowance for all proper payments, in the year under examination was $11,600. If withholding tax were imposed the company would be forced to provide $30,561 for that purpose. It is interesting to look through the accounts of the company and note that only a third of its activity involves wages. The rest involves deductible items of service, including electricity, hire of plant, insurance and those other factors which are properly deductible items, yet such items are to be taxed by this tax at source proposal. It is completely improper to impose a tax on such items. Even though the money is perhaps withheld for a temporary period only, it is improper to impose a tax on such items for that period.

If we take what I believe to be more like the average situation, a subcontracting carpenter, a husband and wife partnership with a gross income of $53,000 a year-not a large income for husband and wife-from which all their expenses and overheads need to be deducted, that family business, those self- employed people, made a basic net profit of $11,000. This is a family with four children with a net profit of $11,000. If this tax goes forward, as it will, and if a withholding tax or a tax at source, as it is now known, is applied to that family business, there is required from that business an additional $5,300. More than half of its net profit in fact goes to pay this tax at source and this tax at source is applied not only to the net profit but also to all other factors. The net profit in this instance is the means by which the operators, the husband and wife, furnish a living for their family. So they are taxed not only on their $11,000 profit but also on all aspects of the costs of running their business. In an instance such as this, the $5,000 that they are required to pay in the form of a tax at source imposes on them an increase of 50 per cent in their calculable profits for tax purposes.

Businesses of various types have various overhead costs and components in their production. One moves from the building industry, from which the examples I have given come, to the trucking industry, the road transport industry. If one looks at the cost of purchase of very expensive equipment, the running costs of which are massive, one will find that the labour component, the return or the net profit to the operator, may be 25 per cent of his total cost. His accredited wages, shall we say, are 25 per cent of the total cost of the business and 75 per cent of his costs will be taxed by this process. There are other organisations, other businesses, where labour is the main content of their activity and materials and goods comprise only a small part of their total cost. In that instance, we are applying a 10 per cent tax to that business by these measures and that organisation will pay close to a 10 per cent tax on what will be its taxable income. But in the first example that I gave, that of the road transport industry, the tax on what becomes, under today's conditions, the taxable part of its operations, increases to a tax not of 10 per cent but of 40 per cent. I believe that these measures have not been properly thought through. They are extremely difficult for the type of people who are operatives in the building and construction industry, the design industries, the technical support industries, and the road transport and motor vehicle industries. The Government has decided to move into that area.

The other aspect of the 10 per cent tax paid monthly to which I object is the discrimination that it imposes against these types of business, the ones designated by the Government as compared with other sorts of self-employed family operated businesses where the tax is paid at the end of the year after normal accounting processes. This proposal takes 10 per cent consistently, on a monthly basis, right throughout the year. Now where is the fairness of a system which, in some circumstances, imposes a monthly requirement on a family business , when there is another family business down the street or across the road which pays tax under another type of system? I believe it is highly discriminatory. The Government has selected these areas, as it well could, but it has chosen to apply to those industries a type of tax that I believe is discriminatory and disadvantageous to those particular industries and businesses.

Another factor to which I object in this legislation concerns the cost of collection that will apply to this process. I do not believe that accurate figures have been provided for the cost of collection. I draw to the attention of the House the multiple form filling in processes that must take place, the extra computing services that will have to be applied by finance officers, the matching process of a myriad of returns coming from all over an area in which a company does business, matching the information against the name of the person performing the subcontracting service and, finally, the multiple banking processes. I believe that these areas are complex and that they impose a cost that has not been calculated on the provisions under discussion. I suppose the most significant factor, however, is the prospect of the unionisation of both the road transport industry and the home building and construction industry. I wish to draw to the attention of the House a report prepared for the Government of New South Wales by Commissioner G. A. Burns, entitled 'Commission of Inquiry into the Nature and Terms of Employment in the New South Wales Housing Industry' . I quote from the final passages of that report. It is an extensive report carried out by a knowledgeable individual with the support of the Labor Government of New South Wales, and promoted by both the Building Workers Industrial Union of Australia and the Builders Labourers Federation. Commissioner Burns says:
I think that anyone who has read the Report so far will have arrived at the conclusion that I am deeply distrustful of what is proposed by Mr McDonald--
That is the spokesman for the Building Workers Industrial Union--

and of what, I believe, would flow from those proposals. This is so. A lot of my distrust flows from my conviction that must is hidden so far as intentions are concerned. This makes for suspicion. I am left in an area of conjecture . . . This industry--
That is the building industry--

is far too important to society and to the economy to be placed at risk by allowing it to be interfered with in a manner which is not openly and faithfully specified. I have only suspicions. I cannot prove that the BWIU intends to move the industry over to day labour. I have doubts about the assurance given-which assurance was repeated many times. I think that in all of the circumstances these doubts must be accepted as reasonable-particularly in view of the heavy responsibility which I carry in writing this report.

These measures in fact provide that interference that Commissioner Burns talks about. They in fact move a category of people away from what has been regarded as self-employed individuals to an area in which they can be deemed employees. The previous Treasurer was concerned about this and in a Press statement to the Australian Financial Review on 3 March, he gave assurances concerning this tax, and intimated that positive legislation would be provided in the Conciliation and Arbitration Act to prevent such an occurrence. No such assurances have come from this Government. It has not provided any assurances that Commissioner Burns expressed is reflected in reports that have been provided in Western Australia relating to carpenters, and a wages board inquiry in Victoria into piece-work rates for bricklayers.

Around the nation concern has been expressed in this area. With this measure, the Government is changing the process completely. I think that the limit of $10 ,000 for reporting is far too high. If one looks at the home building industry, without moving into the trucking and other industries that are affected, one must know that alterations and additions above $2,000 and owner-building together account for about 40 per cent of the recorded private home building industry. So, although 40 per cent of the activity in the building industry is above $2,000, the Government provides a limit of $10,000 before reporting must commence under these sources tax provisions. I believe that the Government has proved to be inadequate in its handling of this difficult area. It has walked away from its responsibility in the area where there is the greatest avoidance. It has not seen fit to tackle it effectively. Therefore, I will move amendments seeking to take up those areas of my concern in the Committee stage.

I conclude by outlining the difficulties that I have had with this proposal. Firstly, it will increase costs in the building industry. The 10 per cent that will be charged will be added on to costs. Australia has the most efficient home building industry in the world; we are now moving to make it less efficient. This tax measure will add 10 per cent to the cost of all factors. The clerical costs will be greatly increased. There are discriminating factors within the legislation concerning one type of business or another. The level of compliance that will be achieved by this measure will be only slightly more, and at a greater cost than compliance which could be brought about by different techniques-ones that do not impose such heavy demands on these important industries and self-employed people within our community.
Debate (on motion by Mr Kent) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: SOCIAL SECURITY AND REPATRIATION LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1983

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Dr Blewett, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Blewett The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

This Bill gives effect to the Government's proposal, announced by the Treasurer (Mr Keating) in his economic statement of 19 May 1983, to introduce an income test on those age and service pensions for persons aged 70 and over which are currently paid free of an income test. The provisions of the Bill cover both age pensions paid under the Social Security Act 1947 and service pensions paid under the Repatriation Act 1920. Since November 1978, age and service pensions have been determined free of an income test in respect of persons aged 70 years or more at the May 1978 rates. The single rate is $51.45 a week and the combined married rate is $85.80 a week, or $42.90 a week each. However, pensioners have been eligible for a higher indexed rate subject to normal income test.

The Bill amends these arrangements by introducing an income test which will apply to those pensions which are currently paid free of an income test. Where a single person's income is $200 a week or below, and a married couple's combined income is $333 a week or below, pension will continue to be paid at current rates. However, the rate of pension will be reduced by a dollar for each two dollars of income in excess of those limits. Pension ceases to be payable to a single person when income reaches $302.90 a week, and in the case of a married couple when combined income reaches $504.60 a week. In the case where a married person is being paid the single rate of pension by reason of separation due to illness, pension ceases to be payable when combined income reaches $538.80 a week. In any other case where a married person is being paid the single rate of pension, the pension ceases to be payable when combined income reaches $504.60 a week.

In the case of a married pensioner couple, where one is under 70 years and the other is 70 years or over, the rate of pension for the person over 70 years will be calculated in accordance with the new income test, and the rate payable to the person under 70 years will be calculated in accordance with current income test arrangements for persons under 70 years. Blind pensioners will continue to be paid age or service pension free of an income test. It is estimated that these changes will bring savings of approximately $167m in 1983-84. This figure is based upon an estimate that about half of some 220,000 current income test free age and service pensioners will have their existing entitlement reduced or terminated. In particular, $7m will be saved in 1983-84 in connection with service pensions whereby an estimated 6,000 people will be affected by the new arrangements-4,000 will have entitlement reduced and 2,000 will cease to be eligible for pension.

The proposed amendments will apply on and from the first pension pay day after 1 November 1983, which will be 3 November in the case of age pensions and 10 November in the case of service pensions. Arrangements are being made to contact all age and service pensioners affected by these changes before the amendments take effect in order to ensure as smooth a transition as possible. Mr Deputy Speaker, these measures arise from the Government's commitment to the development of a fair system of retirement incomes based on an awareness of those in greatest need. I commend the Bill to the House.
Debate (on motion by Mr Steele Hall) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: TAXATION (UNPAID COMPANY TAX) ASSESSMENT AMENDMENT BILL 1983

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kent Mr L.

TALK.START.PARA: —There are a number of tax measures being debated by the House tonight. Yet the speakers who preceded me dealt mainly with the Taxation ( Unpaid Company Tax) Assessment Amendment Bill and the Taxation (Unpaid Income Tax-Dividends) Bill. I except the honourable member for Robertson (Mr Cohen), who dealt with those parts of the Bills which will assist the great Australian film industry. The honourable member for Mitchell (Mr Cadman), who preceded me, took all his 20 minutes talking about the Income Tax (Payments for Work) ( Consequential Amendments) Bill. He was, of course, sorry for the building industry, which suffered greatly under the hands of the former Government which he supported here for seven years. The measures that we have introduced to impose taxes at the rate of 10 per cent on payments for work are, of course, measures which his own mates were proposing in the last Parliament. If honourable members cast their minds back, they will remember that the then Government members were complaining about the cash economy. When we raised the matter of the tax avoidance which was so freely allowed by the Fraser-Howard Government, Government members came back and said: 'What about the cash economy? '. The honourable member for Mitchell had his answer today, and he was not very happy about it.

SPEECH.PARA: Earlier this afternoon we saw the former Treasurer, the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard), shedding crocodile tears for tax avoiders. Actually, he was saying that we were introducing a measure which, in a way, is a capital gains tax, and a retrospective one, and he argued that those people who managed to evade the tax to be paid on dividends or to evade their fair share of income tax by various schemes such as dry Slutzkins, wet Slutzkins, slippery Slutzkins, or whatever Slutzkin one cares to call it, were doing so quite legally. The honourable member referred to the High Court decision, Sir Garfield Barwick's decision, that certain avoidance and evasion of taxes practised by shifty lawyers, accountants and crooked businessmen were quite legal. It might very well have been so in that decision, but let us not forget that Sir Garfield Barwick was quite good himself at using trusts for his little kids to minimise his own taxes. I would say that he was somewhat partial in that judgment.

However, we are debating today the Taxation (Unpaid Company Tax) Assessment Amendment Bill 1983. This was introduced by the Minister for Finance (Mr Dawkins ) to correct the halfway measures introduced last year, half-heartedly, by the former Treasurer, now the Deputy Leader of the Opposition. If those members of the Opposition who are still here with us-those who managed to escape the anger of the Australian people-cast their minds back, they will recall the difficulty with which the former Treasurer introduced the unpaid company tax legislation last year. We had two goes at it before he managed to come forward somehow with some compromise foisted on him by the Western Australia Branch of the Liberal Party of Australia.

Honourable members will recall that the former Liberal-National Party Government acted only after the revelations in the report of the Costigan Royal Commission into the Activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union, and even then only after enormous pressure from the people of Australia, who suddenly realised that they had to pay $15 to $20 more tax per week because the Fraser-Howard Government failed to combat tax evasion and tax avoidance. Honourable members will recall how the Liberal Party agonised for weeks over the question of whether to cast the net to catch the tax avoiders. I do not blame the former Treasurer for being so hesitant in introducing the Taxation (Unpaid Company Tax) Bill, better known as the bottom-of-the-harbour legislation, as he was, quite rightly, afraid that he might catch in the net an assortment of names from the Queen's Birthday Honours List and some well known members of his own political party.

Honourable members will recall that we, in opposition, had to urge and prod the former Treasurer to take steps against the tax avoiders and that we, the then Opposition, supported the Bill that he so belatedly and so half-heartedly introduced. Indeed, without our support, the former Treasurer would have been defeated, because many in his own party opposed that Bill. I wonder, Mr Deputy Speaker, whether this would be a convenient time for the House to adjourn. If so , I should like to continue my remarks later.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —I agree with the honourable member.

INTERJECT.PARA: Sitting suspended from 6.30 to 8.30 p.m.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before the suspension of the sittings for dinner, I was saying how reluctant the former Treasurer was to introduce the Income Tax Bill last year into the Parliament. When the Bill was finally passed, with our support, we stated that we would act to strengthen the legislation and remove the escape clause that the Liberal Party inserted into the Bill for the use of its rich friends. I wish to congratulate the Minister for Finance for his prompt action in introducing this Bill. No one can accuse us of not carrying out our election promises. During the election we campaigned on the issue of tax avoidance and evasion. It took us only a few weeks to introduce this Bill, which is an addition to our arsenal to fight large scale tax avoidance. Compare this with the miserable performance of the Fraser-Howard-Peacock mob.

SPEECH.PARA: During the seven years they were in government the tax avoidance industry mushroomed. Indeed, it was the only industry that was not hit by the economic depression that the former conservative Government created. Tax avoidance schemes were frequently advertised as freely as massage parlours, yet the former Government failed to act to stamp out the tax avoidance industry. The Commissioner of Taxation bombarded the former Treasurer with letters warning him about the loss of revenue caused by tax avoidance. He wrote so many letters to the former Treasurer that when he was forced to table them in the Parliament it looked as though he was tabling a telephone book. The point I make is that it was easier to move a mountain than to get the former Treasurer to take steps against his tax cheating mates.

Finally, as I said, public indignation forced the former Treasurer to act. But even then his legislation was only a partial response. This is the reason why we had to bring the Taxation (Unpaid Company Tax) Assessment Amendment Bill before the House. This Bill aims to recover tax on profits made by shareholders from the dividends which they would have had to pay had those companies not been sold and sent to the bottom of the harbour just prior to dividends being declared. Another part of this Bill has the effect of closing the escape hatch, to do away with the so-called innocence clause for those smart operators who, according to the Liberal Party, were unknowingly benefiting from tax avoidance. Honourable members opposite want us and the Australian people to believe that there are some innocent millionaires, some innocent owners of companies, who received hundreds of thousands or, indeed, millions of dollars more from the sale of their companies than their real value. They want us to believe that poor innocent shareholders were not aware that their companies were being sold and sunk to the bottom of the harbour. According to honourable members opposite the shareholders are still wondering why their bank balances suddenly increased by millions of dollars. However, these shareholders were not so naive and innocent as to offer the tax man his share, but gratefully accepted the God-sent profit and greedily tucked it in their large pockets. Be that as it may, it is only appropriate that such poor, innocent shareholders pay their share in tax and therefore contribute, even if somewhat unwillingly, to the welfare of the Australian people.

Tax evasion costs the Australian people $7,000m annually. This Bill will ensure the collection of an extra $570m of tax evaded in addition to the $590m that the former Treasurer targeted for. In itself it is only a small measure, but it is a great improvement on the inaction of the previous Government. It goes a long way by giving notice to the tax avoiders that this Government intends to recover the full amount that they evaded. There is something wrong, not only with the former Government which tacitly approved tax avoidance and evasion, but also with a tax system that allows evasion and avoidance. There is something wrong with a system under which we send people to gaol for stealing $5 while we allow white collar crooks freely to advertise their shady business. In last week's issue of the Australian Financial Review the following advertisement appeared:
Tax Avoidance is Alive and Well in Australia!!!

A complete four-cassette recording (six hours) is now available of what was said at my recent TAX SURVIVAL CONGRESS . . . hard-core, practical methods . . . how to delay your tax claim for AT LEAST FIVE YEARS . . . how to salvage your assets in the meanwhile . . . TWELVE NEW, PROVEN, HAWKE-PROOF WAYS TO EARN A TAX -FREE INCOME, HOW TO KILL A TAX INVESTIGATION.
Cheques ($250) to Dr Peter Clyne, 23 Elizabeth Bay Road, Sydney 2001. Tel. 358 3244. Telex AA-20067 WELCOME!

Besides his address Mr Clyne even put his photograph into the advertisement so that our tax investigators do not need an identity kit. Such advertisements are not aimed to offer a service to wage and salary earners but to assist the rich to evade their obligations. It would not do any good to my former mates on the railways, or in the metal trades where I worked before, to go to Mr Clyne to do their tax returns as the pay-as-you-earn system is such that the tax from the wage and salary earners is deducted before they even see their pay envelopes. The ordinary wage and salary earner does not know what a dry Slutzkin, a wet Slutzkin or a slippery Slutzkin is or how a bottom-of-the-harbour scheme operates. But they understand the words of Professor Mathews who, when remarking on the tax burden of the poor and the wage and salary earners, said that it is not a question of whether the rich pay enough taxes but that they can please themselves whether they pay any at all. While no one likes to pay taxes, the working people of Australia accept the burden but they demand that it be imposed with equity and be used to conform with our accepted standards of social justice . Unfortunately, the rich have a different idea. They avoid contributing but at the same time they are the first to dip their greedy fingers into the public purse. I see that members of the National Party are not in the chamber.

Since Federation the conservatives, the servants of the establishment, enacted taxation laws full of loopholes for the unscrupulous rich to use, while they made damn sure that the rest of the community coughed up. Since Federation the conservatives, the representatives of the landed gentry and the rich, made sure that the laws, especially the taxation laws, favoured the rich and discriminated against the poor. Even though the objective of our progressive taxation is to finance government spending and to divert resources to the public sector, as well as to redistribute wealth, the property classes and their shifty lawyers managed to make a mockery of the tax system. With impunity they used every illegal means to evade and every possible legal means to avoid paying taxes. For many years the ordinary Australian taxpayer was unaware that the rich had shifted the tax burden on to their shoulders. Let us see what Professor Mathews had to say about this in a somewhat more scholarly way. He said:

But while the existence of tax evasion (fraud) and avoidance (use of legal loopholes to avoid tax liability) has been widely recognised, and while attempts have been made to quantify the loss of revenue resulting from some avoidance techniques, it is usually naively assumed that the nominal effects of taxation policies are the same as their real effects. In terms of equity effects, the advantage claimed for progressive personal income taxes over other forms of taxation depends on the premise that all persons actually pay the taxes they are intended to pay. If this is not so, and if some persons have greater opportunities to evade or avoid taxes than others, the advantage is illusory and the progressive rate structure is irrelevant to the question of an equitable distribution of the tax burden.
That is interesting. Let us look now at what Professor Mathews had to say further about our taxation system. He said:

While the total extent of tax avoidance and evasion in Australia must remain somewhat speculative, it may be concluded thay they are significant in absolute terms; they are increasing; and they are undermining both the stability and the equity of the tax system. Attempts have been made to close tax loop-holes, but these have served to complicate the system without achieving any lasting results . As soon as one device is blocked another emerges in its place. Apart from its effects on equity and the threat it poses for the continued acceptability of the tax system as a whole, tax avoidance is associated with a substantial waste of resources as accountants, lawyers and businessmen have combined to establish a whole new industry devoted to manipulating and exploiting weaknesses in the system.

Ordinary wage and salary earners do not usually read publications like Russell Mathews's 'The Structure of Taxation' from which I quoted. But the information was available to the former Treasurer who is a shifty lawyer himself. He knew quite well what his rich friends were doing.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member should withdraw the term that he used with regard to the former Treasurer. It is unparliamentary and it is an offensive term.

—I withdraw. He knew quite well what his rich friends were doing. Yet he failed to act. He closed his eyes and ears and did not want to stop tax avoidance. He was advised by the Commissisioner of Taxation about the tax avoidance on a massive scale that the Fraser Government had tolerated. When Mr Howard, finally forced to act, introduced the Taxation (Unpaid Company Tax) Bill , it aimed to recover only a small proportion of taxes avoided, in total $570m.

SPEECH.PARA: The Bill that we are discussing today will have the effect of recovering almost double that amount. But even that is far from the $7,000m lost to revenue annually. There is something fundamentally wrong with our whole tax system when it allows the rich to avoid illegally and evade legally their obligations. Because of that the community suffers. I illustrate the point I am making. Only last week a number of under 18-year-old unemployed youths came to me to describe their plight. They have to live on $40 a week, pay board from that miserly pittance and spend money to go job hunting, dress and so on. I told them that I was ashamed that politicians like myself who receive $80 a day expenses when in Canberra expect them to live on $40 a week. I promised that I would bring their plight to the notice of the Parliament and the nation, as I am doing now. However, I could not promise them immediate relief knowing that the previous Government left an empty kitty. There is just simply not enough tax revenue until the rich fulfil their obligations to improve the plight of those kids who are forced to live on $40 a week.

There is something fundamentally wrong with our taxation system, there is something fundamentally wrong with our nation which allows rich individuals and companies to evade their taxes to the tune of $7,000m a year while teenage kids are forced to sleep in parks and eat dog food. I finish by again quoting Professor Mathews. He said:
Indeed, it is plausible to argue that the taxation system has become a major instrument for redistributing incomes and wealth in favour of the rich.
I hope that this Government will act swiftly to review our whole taxation system to prevent this from going further.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Connolly Mr D.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think the observations made by the honourable member for Hotham (Mr Kent) require some response from the Opposition. Firstly, his final observation was that we needed to see a fundamentally changed system of taxation. That is a view which was shared by the former Treasurer, the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard), and is certainly a view which is shared by many members of the Opposition. There is a tendency, however, for members such as the honourable member for Hotham to work on the premise that taxation avoidance is something which is unique to those who vote Liberal and is not something found with people across the main stream of the Australian community. Perhaps he made the fundamental error of confusing evasion with avoidance. This whole issue was argued very substantially last year. The former Treasurer, the honourable member for Bennelong, has made a greater contribution towards stopping taxation loopholes in the Australian taxation system than any other Treasurer since Federation. I make that point for a very strong reason because I was in Opposition in the days of the Whitlam Government. I do not recall that any of the three or four Treasurers who went through this House during those years made any significant change whatsoever in the whole area of taxation evasion and avoidance about which they were obviously well aware. This point needs to be emphasised because tonight we see a proposal to make further amendments to legislation which was brought in by the Liberal-National Party coalition when it was in power. There is always a tendency in this area to say that too little is done too late. But the simple fact is that the honourable member for Bennelong, when Treasurer of this country, brought in more taxation legislation than any other Treasurer since Federation. That is on the record. Any honourable member of this House, regardless of whether he wishes to know the facts or not, can find that out for himself.

SPEECH.PARA: This cognate debate tonight relates to a package of taxation proposals. The principal one relates to the extension of the recoupment provisions of the Taxation (Unpaid Company Tax) Assessment Amendment Act which, as I said, was introduced by the previous Government. In addition there is also a series of other problems which have been created by the Government in relation to the introduction of taxation deduction systems on subcontractors. This is a first sample of taxation reform from the new Labor Government. Like so much before it, it regrettably represents another broken promise. The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) promised the Australian people that the Australian Labor Party would not introduce a capital gains tax. Yet these amendments not only effectively introduce a capital gains tax but they have gone further than that-they have introduced it retrospectively. The proposals are therefore grossly unfair and vindictive. They will put into question the Labor Party's rationale for equitable taxation policy and give the private sector very good reason to fear what is yet to come in the total area of taxation reform from this Government.

During the debate in this Parliament in September-October 1982, the then Opposition told us on numerous occasions-the current Minister for Finance (Mr Dawkins) made the point-that the loopholes as they then saw them in the Government's Bill would allow at least $7,000m to escape the net. Again, tonight , the honourable member for Hotham used that figure. We have been told in the second reading speech of the Minister for Finance that these draconian amendments will produce the miserable amount of $500m to $600m. I ask the question: What of the other $6.5m odd which we were told we were losing last year? Am I not right in therefore concluding that if these amendments, which are the sum total of the Government's major reform of taxation to date, are only demonstrating the Government's capacity to obtain this amount of money, one therefore has no alternative but to conclude, as the former Treasurer said last year and repeated in this House again tonight, that we had already effectively closed off all the major loopholes such as the Slutzkin schemes, bottom-of-the- harbour schemes and so forth. This does not mean that, in the future, other schemes will not be found. Of course, the government of the day has the fundamental responsibility, when that evidence is brought forward, to take the necessary legislative or administrative action to close them off. But the key question is that the basis of the claim for this legislation was that the Government would find ways of stopping some $7,000m escaping the net. That is a figure which the Government drew up; we did not draw it up. Yet, when this Government had the opportunity in this legislation to demonstrate some capacity in this area it has had to admit that the best it can do is to recoup $500m or $ 600m. On that basis one is right to assume that the Government is not genuine in trying to amend legislation which, in fact, has been demonstrated to be completely effective in stopping the problems for which it was originally introduced. Evidence clearly shows that the previous Government's legislation has worked and that the changes proposed by the Labor Government are simply vindictive and examples of the small-minded approach which a doctrinaire socialist government will take regardless of the evidence before it. The charges made against the previous Government that we were soft on tax avoiders have been proved groundless. The Bills before us bear little resemblance with the taxation avoidance legislation of the previous Government. Consequently, we will not support proposals which impose a retrospective capital gains tax, and in addition a new tax on revenue which was never subject to illegal evasion which was the basis of our recoupment legislation.

We oppose the Bills because they either reverse the decisions made in last year 's legislation, or contain amendments which were moved by the Labor Party in opposition and were rejected by the then Government because they were unfair and unnecessarily draconian in their impact. These are not normal Budget Bills, nor normal revenue raising legislation. The Government has had to face the choice which all governments have to face, between cutting expenditure or increasing taxation. On the basis of the Government's mini-Budget last Thursday it has made a minimal impact on cutting costs and has chosen a surreptitious approach towards taxation which will give every Australian taxpayer ample reason to believe that it is on the verge of breaking yet another promise, and that income tax will rise substantially in the next Budget. I ask any member of the Government sitting opposite tonight to challenge what I have just said on the evidence which has been put before the House.

The road to increasing taxes is always easier than reducing costs, but the easy answers are not necessarily the right ones. In this Bill, the Government has retrospectively created a liability for taxation which had not previously existed. If companies had continued trading, the liability would not have arisen . The Government has artificially created a situation where it can tax despite the fact that there has been no illegal act in the past. In Government, we did not seek to create a new tax liability, only to redeem an existing liability-to redeem tax due from an illegal act. The tax imposed by this legislation is a new tax and in no way can be related to a prior taxation liability.

These amendments will not only tax accumulated profits but also accumulated reserves held by companies. In addition to the 50 per cent tax rate, victims of this legislation face an added tax of 60c in the dollar. This is indisputably a capital gains tax which could have a disastrous impact on the confidence and the ability of the very people on whom this Government must depend to help create the jobs in the private sector and inject the capital which is the engine of our national development and is so essential for our national recovery. This legislation will artificially render illegal, acts done by companies years ago and will render liable for taxation the accumulated reserves which were legitimately set aside often for development purposes.

As I said before, the original recoupment legislation was based on the premise that a tax liability had existed and that it had been evaded by illegal means, but here we see that a company which paid its due company tax, plus Division 7 tax on retained profits, will now find itself due to pay further tax at the rate of 60c in the dollar on its accumulated reserves. If this is an example of the Labor Party's belief in taxation equity we can legitimately ask: Where will it all end? As an example of the Government's vindictive approach, those who have fallen foul of its new taxation net are given only a paltry 30 days in which to meet their liabilities. This is not only unrealistic; it is patently absurd. Companies and individuals are deemed to have incurred tax in an area of legitimate operations. They did not break the law. Consequently to remove the 12 -month grace period in the original Act is nothing more than sheer spite.

Under current economic circumstances there is no point in forcing individuals into bankruptcy and companies into liquidation with the result in loss in jobs and creating at this time a genuine commercial concern as to the future direction of taxation policy under this Government. These amendments to the Taxation (Unpaid Company Tax) Assessment Amendment Bill retrospectively reverse the High Court of Australia decision in the Slutzkin's case that if as little as $250 of company tax has not been paid following the sale of shares, regardless of reason, there will be no distinction between the inability to pay tax because of some fraudulent transaction as distinct from a non-fraudulent transaction. Consequently, the shareholders who have sold their shares will now be taxed not only on the revenue profits of the company which have already been subject to tax, but on other profits including capital reserves which have never been liable to taxation in the past under existing Australian company law. The Act does not pay any regard as to whether the dividends, if paid to a vendor by a company, would have been taxable in whole or in part.

However, if a shareholder did not sell shares but stripped the company and left it unable to pay its income tax, whether by fraud or otherwise, the shareholder will not be deemed to have derived such a dividend, but will continue to enjoy both the accumulated revenue and capital profits of the stripped company free of taxation. The fact that the Government has failed to stop this loophole demonstrates one of the weaknesses of this Bill. Again this shows that in its urge to change the law at any cost it has not done sufficient basic work to see what areas are worthy of reform as distinct from those which demonstrate merely a callous and vindictive approach to people, many of whom have not broken the law.

This amending legislation greatly extends the scope of retrospective tax into new areas and introduces grossly unjust, extreme and punitive measures. The amendments are directed at further victimising vendor-shareholders who are already required to pay all taxes under the existing legislation. The Bill introduces a new dimension into Australian tax law. It seeks to deem a prescribed amount of the consideration received from the sale of shares as a taxable dividend. It establishes a precedent which could eventually lead the Government to applying it to all share dealings in both public and private companies. It establishes a new capital gains tax which will be selectively imposed on a broad group of taxpayers. It imposes tax on capital profits, whether realised or not, and it does not permit the adjustment of such profits which may have arisen solely due to the sale of assets, including business good will, which is totally ignored in this Bill. Furthermore, the Bill also taxes illusory gains which are generally mere book entries transferring the value of assets from one company to another.

The Bill will impose tax on capital profits and accumulated revenue reserves in a company even after taxes have been paid and the vendor-shareholders having left adequate cash reserves in the company to enable it to meet company tax on the current year's profit at the time of sale. It does not take into account the fact that the purchaser of the company may have misappropriated those cash reserves and failed to ensure that the company could meet its Division 7 distribution requirement. The full liability falls on the previous shareholders, regardless as to whether they are responsible. The amendments totally ignore the fact that such circumstances would be beyond the control of the vendor- shareholder who took every prudent means of ensuring that due taxes would be paid at the time of sale.

Clause 8 of the Bill will impose a new tax liability on a deemed dividend comprising the undistributed tax paid on revenue and previously non-taxable capital profits of the company, regardless of when those profits were derived. The result will be that vendor-shareholders will be liable to recoupment tax and personal tax aggregating in excess of 81 per cent of the companies revenue profit in the year of sale, irrespective of the fact that any illegal act by the new owner or promoter of the company was beyond the control of the vendor- shareholder at that time.

Clause 6 involves changes in the disclosure provisions. It removes the need for the Commissioner of Taxation to advise all shareholders of the company's liabilities and requires that the Commissioner inform only the major shareholder . Probably, the people in the Australian Taxation Office naturally want legislation which requires the minimum possible involvement of their officers. But the simple fact is that in this House we are meant to be passing legislation which is fair and reasonable, especially to those people who will be on the receiving end of the effects of these particular amendments to the legislation. One therefore has to ask a serious question. Where we are dealing with private companies in particular, and where there has been a spread of share owners, is it satisfactory that the Commissioner of Taxation regards it as his responsibility to advise only the major shareholder? What about the minor shareholders? Will they be able to use that as the excuse when the Commissioner of Taxation, a mere 30 days later, goes to those people and says: 'You have not paid your tax and because of that I will now apply to you a further punitive tax rate of an additional 20 per cent because of your failure to pay'? In many cases these people may not even have been advised of the fact that they have a responsibility under this Bill to pay tax. But as the provision stands at the moment there is no onus on the Commissioner of Taxation to inform anybody of his liability except the major shareholder. In addition, the abolition in clause 21 of the 12 months time to pay provision and its replacement by a mere 30 days, as well as a 20 per cent late payment penalty to which I referred, totally ignore the economic reality facing both individuals and companies in Australia today, as well as the problems this could well cause to their employees in finding sufficient funds to meet these requirements. For example, clause 5 removes what was previously known as the innocence clause and thus vendor-shareholders will have no recourse to equity in cases where the promotor did not act illegally and sought to limit the company's income tax liability by legal means.

These amendments indicate the Government's desire to confiscate the largest possible amount of tax from a group of vendor-shareholders, the majority of whom have not been guilty of any illegality in relation to their shares. The existing law was passed through the Parliament during the last session of the last Liberal Government. It was the handiwork of the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard) who, as I said earlier, put more legislation on the statute book of this Commonwealth directed at combating the real problems of tax avoidance in Australia than any other Treasurer. In these amendments we have simply seen a small-minded approach, particularly by the Minister for Finance (Mr Dawkins), who has taken the view that one should pursue people at all costs, regardless of the concepts of fairness or reasonableness and who sees that as his role in society. I respectfuly suggest that in the years which have yet to pass by, the people in this Parliament and the people of Australia will expect of the present Government a more systematic approach to the real problems of taxation in this nation.

The fact is that the levels of taxation are too high and that is one of the reasons why in recent years we have seen a tendency for more and more people to look for forms of avoidance. But, as I said earlier to the honourable member for Hotham (Mr Kent), there is a fundamental difference betwen evasion and tax avoidance. It is the primary responsibility of the Commonwealth and of the Parliament to do all we can to stop people from evading tax. But we are deluding ourselves if we seriously suggest that one section of society alone is responsible for tax avoidance. The simple fact is, as the honourable member for Bennelong has said in the House tonight, that unless we are prepared to restructure our taxation system and have a better balance between direct and indirect taxation we will not get to the primary problem of Australia's taxation arrangements as they currently stand. That is a challenge I leave with the current Government and I ask honourable members opposite what they will do about it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Theophanous Dr A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to make a few brief comments in view of the fact that we want to pass through all stages of these taxation Bills tonight. I begin by replying to the remarks of the previous speaker, the honourable member for Bradfield (Mr Connolly), who gave us a peculiar rationalisation in trying to cloak the fact that certain people did not pay their due taxes, knew that they were not paying their due taxes and effectively escaped paying those taxes. We were told that this legislation is an imposition on the civil liberties of these people. We were also told in the same breath by the honourable member that in fact his Government did more than any other government and that the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard) did more than any other Treasurer to deal with the tax avoidance and evasion industry. Nothing could be further from the truth.

SPEECH.PARA: The fact is that for the seven years of the previous Government we had a mushrooming tax avoidance and evasion industry. Everyone knew about it to the point that how one could compile these various schemes to avoid tax was being advertised in the newspapers. Everyone knew that these schemes were in operation ; they were advertised.
