I remind the House that it was only in the last two years that the previous Government even attempted to do anything about these matters. What happened then? As soon as the honourable member for Bennelong brought in some measure, we saw advertisements appear in the newspapers stating: 'How to avoid Howard's new measures'. What did the former Treasurer do? Did he take up the recommendation which we made time and again while in Opposition to ensure by retrospective means that these measures were dealt with? Not until the very last few months of the previous Government did it finally come to this recognition, elatedly. Members of the Opposition try to tell us that they have been very vigilant on this matter. Their arguments are disgraceful arguments in support of tax avoidance and evasion promoters. Such people have been to this House to see various members of parliament. We know that they came to lobby especially the Australian Democrats senators on this matter. Who are they? They are the same tax sharks and the same people who put out the advertisements. They came to lobby the honourable members now in Opposition, and they fell for it.

TALK.START.PARA: —They are the benefactors.

—They are the benefactors, as the honourable member for Hunter said. Opposition members try to defend those people on the basis of some claim about civil liberties. Let us be clear about this: What was going on was a crooked scheme that involved companies that went to the bottom of the harbour. The people who benefited did not have to pay tax on the dividends that they should have received. Therefore, it is logical and correct--
—What about the tax deductible union dues when they are given to a political party? Is that tax avoidance?
—Order! The honourable member for O'Connor will be given the opportunity to speak, as I understand it, in the near future. I ask him to refrain from interjecting.

—He has a habit of interjecting when I speak. I will continue on that important point 'namely' that what we are doing with this legislation is completing the legislative process in the way in which it should have been completed by the previous Government to ensure that those people who benefit from those crooked schemes will be dealt with and will pay their due share of taxation. We heard a lot from the honourable member for Bradfield about how income tax has risen. Income tax, he says, has gone up and up and up. One would think that we rather than them had been in Government for seven years. Whose fault has it been that income tax has gone up? Which government promised cuts but in fact increased income taxes imposed on workers and their families? This is the group that did this, yet now they come here and say: 'Isn't that a terrible tragedy?'
—You tell the House that you are not going to increase taxes.

—The honourable member need not worry; I will come to that point. 'Is it not a terrible tragedy', the honourable member asks us, 'about all these increases in income tax?' Members of the Opposition are the ones who are responsible for these increases because they failed to implement other forms of taxation which would have been more equitable.
—What forms?

—Of course the honourable member's imagination would not stretch that far. I suggest to the Opposition that several forms of taxation are possible, but I will not announce them to the House now. To do so would give the Opposition delight but it would pre-empt the Federal Budget.
—Don't let that hold you back.
—Order! This is a very stimulating address but I ask the Opposition not to be so responsive.

—It is my fault for responding to interjections, Mr Deputy Speaker; I apologise. Let me continue with my theme about these severe increases in income tax. We will attempt to ensure that income taxes, at least those imposed on low income families, the poorer section and even the middle income section of the community, are not increased and, if possible, are reduced. That is what we are aiming at. But look at the fiscal situation that the Opposition has put us in. It has made it very difficult. We are in an incredible fiscal situation. The highly praised honourable member for Bennelong hides his head in shame every time this matter is mentioned. So he ought to, because he offered a most irresponsible Budget last year and behaved most irresponsibly in describing what was going to happen in relation to that Budget. He did not even understand his own economic theory. He said that unemployment would increase, but unfortunately he failed to take into account the extra cost of the unemployment benefit. That extra cost was forgotten. Consequently, as every member of the last Parliament knows, we suddenly had a revision of the Budget Estimates a few months after the Budget was brought down because the unemployment benefit was increased but no account had been taken of that. Yet these incompetents come here and try to tell us to run an economy and what is correct taxation procedure .

SPEECH.PARA: Let us proceed to consider other aspects which have been attacked by the Opposition in relation to the other tax measures embraced in the several taxation Bills before the House. One philosophical thread goes right through this matter; that is wherever possible, support the rich and damn the poor. That is the philosophy which honourable members opposite espoused for seven years and it is the philosophy they continue to espouse. They cry about the imposition of taxes on people who have been avoiding tax, such as those contractors in the cash economy who have not been paying their taxes. In not just one report but in several reports the Government has been asked to act on this matter. So, we take action and we are criticised by honourable members opposite. The fact is that many of these enterprises are substantial, in nature and can afford to pay their tax. There is absolutely no reason why they should not be required, as the Income Tax Assessment Amendment Bill requires them, to pay in this way.

The requirement is a reasonable one; it will not put undue pressures on business, as we have been told by honourable members opposite that it will do. As I have said, whenever a situation arises in which sombody who is rich is asked to pay tax, we are told immediately: 'Oh, this will be bad for business'. This is not only an absurdity but also a failure to comprehend the way in which money flows in an economy. That is something members of the Opposition do not understand because they still have not got beyond their monetarist lessons. These measures are being imposed in order to ensure that everyone in the community pays his due share of tax. In that respect the measures ought to be universally supported by this House.

Something very strange in relation to the Liberal Opposition is that one never knows what position its members will adopt on any measure because they are totally confused. An example of that is the speech made by the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Peacock) yesterday in response to the statement of the Treasurer (Mr Keating). One did not know whether he wanted, on the one hand, expansion or, on the other hand, contraction; whether he wanted more spending or less spending . One did not know whether he was arguing for more monetarism, which is the view of the honourable member for Bennelong, or whether he was arguing for a more sensible expansion, which is the view of some of his other colleagues, such as the honourable member for Boothby (Mr Steele Hall) to name one. The Opposition's economic approach is so totally incoherent at present that one just does not know what it is on about.

The new Leader of the Opposition said after the election was lost that it was time for the Liberal Party to reassess its philosophy. When will we get this reassessment? When will we know at least what its general approach is so that we can predict the view it will take on a particular measure? If we knew something of those principles at least we would have some idea of what honourable members opposite are on about and some idea of the viewpoint they will take on measures such as this. Had we known that at the time these Bills were presented, for example, then, perhaps we would have expected them to come into the House and disgracefully oppose the first two of these Bills to collect money which people gained from bottom-of-the-harbour schemes. What kind of liberalism is that? Is it liberalism to let people get away with this kind of robbery? Is this the new version of liberalism? I can say to you, Mr Deputy Speaker, that if this is the new version of liberalism the Australian Labor Party will be in government for a hell of a long time.

TALK.START.PARA: —John Stuart Mill would turn in his grave.

—As the honourable member for Hunter says, John Stuart Mill would turn in his grave if he heard about this. He would not understand their version of liberalism. As I recall, John Stuart Mill-we are talking about the father of liberalism-made it very clear that everyone should pay his due share of taxation . This is one principle that honourable members opposite have not been following . A series of amendments is to be moved by Mr Cadman which, as I have said, will basically-
—Order! To be consistent, I remind the honourable member to refer to other honourable members by their electorates rather than their names.

—The honourable member for Mitchell (Mr Cadman) proposes to move amendments that would result in the legislation losing all its force and power. What we are concerned with is this: Why is the Opposition proceeding along these lines and not assisting us in trying to collect the sort of revenue that has to be collected if we are to have a sensible Budget deficit and a sensible economic policy in the future? Honourable members who are listening to this debate know the answer, and that is that the benefactors of these people, the people who have lobbied in the last few days, are the ones who will benefit if the amendments are passed. But the amendments will not be passed. We will ensure that we fulfil the program for which we were elected according to the consistent principles for which we were elected and not the inconsistent principles that the Opposition has been following.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me say in conclusion that the tax debate has not ended-it is just beginning . There are, of course, other forms of tax that need to be considered and discussed, especially various forms of wealth taxes which we will consider. Those sorts of taxes will be considered in a rational fashion and we hope to see the Opposition adopt a responsible attitude in relation to these matters. The honourable member for Bradfield mentioned only one thing-indirect taxes. That is his answer to income tax. That is all his imagination extends to. His imagination cannot extend to anything beyond that. I ask him to study the forms of tax available in other countries. If he does, he might find out that there are many other forms of tax besides income taxes and indirect taxes.

TALK.START.PARA: —What do you suggest?

—As I said, honourable members will hear about them in the Budget . However, let me get back to indirect taxes. We were told by the honorable member for Bennelong and the honourable member for Bradfield that we have to go in for indirect taxes. Of course, that form of taxation would suit them a lot, would it not? Then the tax burden would fall more on the poor, the unemployed and low income earners. That is what they want in the tax debate. They want to shift the tax burden to those who can least afford it. That is their strategy. They refuse even to think about taxing the rich and those who can afford to pay.

SPEECH.PARA: Our taxation policy is redistributive. It is based on the principle that those who can pay will pay and those who cannot because they are unemployed or too poor need to be assisted. That is the principle which the Labor Party has propounded for the whole of its history. That principle will continue to be propounded in this Parliament. I urge the House to support the Bills.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Braithwaite Mr R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —In rising to speak on these taxation Bills I say that Government members who have spoken in this debate have provided us with a great example of inconsistency. The honourable member for Burke (Dr Theophanous) who has just spoken, while being entertaining also mentioned that there were new taxes to be considered. I suggest that if the Government were to impose a tax on logic, common sense and consistency the honourable member would be due for a massive refund. The honourable member for Hunter (Mr Robert Brown), who speaks with some logic on taxation matters, bears out what I feel is the position of members of the Government, namely, that many of them do not really know the full implication of these Bills. Others do not want to know them. They believe that the legislation amounts to a kick in the ribs for the capitalist society and that is the way they want to leave it.

SPEECH.PARA: However, other things are involved in the legilation. People are involved. These people include unionists-they could be members of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union-and investors. We are talking about people right across the whole spectrum. I believe that we should be concerned if people are involved. The civil liberties aspect of the legislation has been mentioned. I believe that we represent people and we should be making legislation in such a way that people can follow the law with a certain amount of consistency. Whilst we are not seeking to protect people with this legislation we should not attack them and destroy their civil rights and liberties. That is basically what the legislation before us is designed to do. It makes illegal today or tomorrow something that was legal yesterday.

I refer to the beginning of the legislation to deal with bottom-of-the-harbour schemes. One of the Bills before us, which is described as an Act to impose a tax in respect of certain unpaid income tax, goes right back to 1 July 1971. The Slutzkin scheme was known at that time yet for the three years Labor was in government between 1972 and 1975 not a thing was done in that regard. Now, 10 years later the Labor Party intends restrospectively to make illegal something that was legal the last time it was in government. I think that this very vital principle has been conveniently overlook by the Government in bringing this legislation forward with undue haste. The honourable member for Hume (Mr Lusher) mentioned earlier in this debate that the Government was proposing a retrospective capital gains tax. Such a tax offends in two ways. The Government has said quite categorically that there will be no capital gains tax. Yet, I can demonstrate--

TALK.START.PARA: —You can't believe them from one day to another.

—Well, it changes its position in many ways and it has done so over the last couple of months. I just want to explain the situation as far as companies are concerned. Most of the companies that will be involved under this legislation will come from the private sector, not the public sector. The legislation before us computes a dividend on which personal tax is to be paid. In that situation accumulated capital profits, whether they be from the sales of property, from the revaluation of assets of from the creation of goodwill, set aside not in a capital reserve but in accumulated profits, can now be assessed. The Government also overlooks the fact that the dividend is normally computed by allowing an 80 per cent retention of profit in a particular year. Again, that has been neglected and not taken into account. This is a further attack on the long established principle in respect of corporations in this country. In fact, this action infringes, if not common law, certainly corporate law as we have come to know it. In the past, capital profits could be passed on to shareholders in liquidation without being assessable. This Bill makes no attempt whatsoever to separate profits gained in an illegal manner and those gained in a correct manner. It overlooks altogether the innocents. Some shareholders in companies who might have been involved in such arrangements could be innocent in their own way. They could have been led into something quite unwittingly. This type of thing also has been overlooked in the legislation before us that seeks to tax the dividend component in bottom-of-the-harbour schemes.

SPEECH.PARA: Since 1977 I have consistently voted against retrospectivity because I believe that it infringes our civil liberties. We have an example of this in relation to a taxation commitment. How much further can governments go in regard to retrospectivity in other measures? I believe that restrospectivity is a critical part of the legislation before us. We have heard a lot of nonsense about the cheats and the bludgers who are involved in tax avoidance schemes. I agree with some of the things that have been said. But those schemes were operated legally. They were not legislated against by the Labor Government in 1972 to 1975. But now, 10 years later, the present Labor Government wants to try to correct that situation. In that respect I believe that we should give this legislation careful consideration. I suggest to Government supporters that perhaps it has been the subject of undue haste and that many of them would be quite ignorant of its actual provisions.

The other aspect of the Government's attack on the company structure is to be found in the Government's economic statement of last week, which announced that the rebate in respect of the first $1,000 of dividend income is to be rescinded.

TALK.START.PARA: —Not many pensioners are earning that.

—I am not worried about it in that respect. When we consider equity in taxation right across the board we must realise that the income of companies is being assessed twice and sometimes thrice. That is neither consistent nor equitable. So far as equity is concerned, when you do that you take a step backwards.

SPEECH.PARA: The legislation before us also covers quite a large range of other areas. The Income Tax Assessment Amendment Bill picks up, in respect of the current year, 1983, a lot of items that were mentioned in the Budget. The Government is now honouring those commitments. Insofar as payment for work and services is concerned, it could quite easily be said that the Government has gone soft in this area. The original proposal was that 30 per cent of contract gross income, in respect of work costing $4,000 or more, was to be withheld. The figure has now fallen to 10 per cent of the contract price in respect of amounts of $10,000 and above. It will be interesting to see what the monitoring system reveals. But the cash economy presents a still larger problem. I mentioned this subject in an address on taxation in this House two weeks ago. The cash economy of this country involves an amount of between $5 billion and $7 billion. That is the amount of actual tax lost, not income involved. Everybody should be concerned about that and there must be some commonality in this Parliament in supporting the effort to collect those taxes that have been illegally evaded.

So far as the taxation concession in respect of accelerated depreciation is concerned, although provision is made for it in the legislation, I note that it is to be rescinded from 1 July. Provision for accelerated depreciation is fair and reasonable and provides an incentive to business to invest in equipment that can be turned to production and profitable use. The permitted depreciation on non-residential buildings merely conforms to the arrangement already in place with regard to tourist accommodation.

Over the last few years the film industry has had the benefit of the opportunity to produce some great national films, of which I would just mention Breaker Morant, The Man from Snowy River and We of the Never Never. Also, the production of certain great documentaries has been possible only because of the tax incentives that have been offered. That part of the legislation which sets out to streamline such assistance will provide still further encouragement in this regard.

The removal of the tax incentive in respect of fuel storage and conservation is short-sighted. It was brought in to try to overcome a critical fuel shortage, not because of the purchasing arrangements with the Arab countries. It was designed to meet a situation in our own country. That assistance has meant that additional fuel storage has been provided on the farms and at the ports.

I would like to know when the Government intends to fulfil its promise, made in many areas, to remove the excise in respect of tourists' boats and power generation on islands. Its presence has had a detrimental effect upon the tourist industry and upon off-road vehicle users.

Other legislation, which heralds the introduction of Medicare, removes, as from 30 June 1983, the tax rebate in respect of basic medical and hospital cover. I am sure that the effect of that will not only be one of higher taxation. Its overall effect on the country will be great. As has been mentioned, the eventual costs of the proposed Medicare arrangements are likely to include the loss of up to 5,000 jobs under the accepted private schemes, increased medication and over- servicing and the denial of medical assistance and access to the poor because of the overcrowding of public facilities. I would have hoped that the Minister for Health (Dr Blewett), who is at the table, might have studied the English experience so far as such schemes are concerned.

I have been asked to curtail my comments in regard to this legislation in order to allow its passage tonight in, I hope, an amended form. I simply bring these matters to the attention of the Government in an effort to beseech at least its back benchers if the Cabinet and the Minister cannot understand the difficulties involved, to try to come to grips with some of the major problems presented and offer a real argument for the legislation instead of the rhetoric that we have heard here tonight.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kelly Mrs R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Throughout the speech of the honourable member for Dawson (Mr Braithwaite) I have listened intently in an effort to understand the points made by the Opposition in relation to this package of legislation but I became rather confused when the honourable member tried to explain how it was possible to cheat by not paying the appropriate tax and do so legally. It is all done legally and therefore it is okay!

SPEECH.PARA: I am really amazed that members of the Opposition should be surprised at what has emerged in this legislation. The Government has merely proceeded along the lines of which it gave notice last October in this very chamber and which it reiterated many times in the lead-up to the election. Suddenly, last week at the Opposition party meeting, a decision was made to oppose this legislation, though much of it had been introduced, although in a different and modifed form, by the previous Government last October. At that time a start had been made at long last on the road to trying to do something about tax evasion in this country. The new Labor Government has clearly demonstrated that it is sick of procrastination on this issue; that it intends not to talk about the matter but to get on and legislate. That is what is so significant. It represents the real difference between the position of the Opposition and that of the Government.

The Taxation (Unpaid Company Tax) Assessment Amendment Bill and the Taxation ( Unpaid Income Tax-Dividends) Bill are a direct result of promises made by the Government when in Opposition, the previous Government's legislation having been seen as defective in a number of ways in dealing with bottom-of-the-harbour schemes. First, no attempt had been made to recoup personal income tax avoided under the bottom-of-the-harbour schemes, tax which should have been paid when accumulated company profits were distributed as dividends to company shareholders. The second aspect that we criticised was that no effort had been made to recoup sales tax evaded through the use of the bottom-of-the-harbour types of sales tax schemes, which were also subject to the Crimes (Taxation Offences) Act of 1980. These sales tax schemes had exploded in recent years and we felt that existing legislation was not sufficient to overcome them. We believed, and stated quite clearly in this Parliament, that because of these deficiencies an amount of at least $600m in tax was being lost through straw company tax evasion schemes.

The first set of legislation in relation to these tax avoidance schemes, that which was introduced last October, was brought down by the previous Government only because, in electoral terms, it knew that it had no choice. If it had had such a political choice this Parliament would in no way have seen that legislation. It came to the fore only because of the Costigan Royal Commission report, which illustrated vividly a history of government inaction against the so-called bottom-of-the-harbour schemes. I suppose it is really not surprising to us, as members of the Government, that tonight the Opposition is now turning around and opposing the legislation that is before this House. Initially, the schemes were found to be operating in Perth in 1973. As the honourable member for Dawson (Mr Braithwaite) said, they were identified in 1973 when Labor was in government, and after a close examination of existing law, a decision was taken by the Australian Taxation Office in 1975 to prosecute the persons involved in one scheme. Prosecution was to be under the Crimes Act for conspiring to defraud the Commonwealth and liquidation proceedings were commenced to recover the tax owing. But these proceedings never got off the ground for reasons outlined in the Costigan report involving negligence in both the Crown Solicitor's Office and the Australian Taxation Office.

Several legal opinions were obtained from both within the bureaucracy and from private practitioners that prosecutions could successfully be launched against these schemes under existing law, but still the previous Government never attempted to do so. Instead, it relied on an eventual Crown Law Office opinion that prosecution would not be successful. That was its excuse for doing nothing until the end of 1980 when, as a result of the Costigan report, because of the electoral backlash, because it knew it had to face the people in a very short time, it then decided it would take some sort of action. But as we said, in October last year the members of the then Opposition made it very clear that we believed that the legislation was severely deficient. The legislation that we have before us tonight only reinforces the points that we raised last October and attempts to strengthen that legislation.

The previous Government was, supposedly, first made aware of the schemes at the beginning of 1978. A decision was made later that year to enact new legislation against these schemes. That legislation, the Crimes (Taxation Offences) Act, was not passed until the end of 1980. So the previous Government's five-year delay in taking action is totally inexcusable. During this period, bottom-of-the- harbour schemes mushroomed, causing huge revenue losses. The previous Government itself admits that up to $600m in lost taxes are involved, although other estimates involve figures many times larger than that amount. The previous Government should have either proceeded with prosecutions to test existing law or indicated, as soon as it was aware of these schemes, an intention to legislate against them back to the date of announcement. Although the schemes were virtually stopped in 1980, huge amounts of tax remained unpaid, and that is the issue that we are addressing in this legislation. Only after the revelations of the extent of tax evaded contained in the McCabe-Lafranchi and Costigan reports, was the previous Government forced by public pressure to act.

The Opposition argues that moneys should not be collected from vendors who had no knowledge that they were involved in tax avoidance schemes. However, they benefited from such schemes, even if they had no knowledge of the fraud. While they benefited, who lost? The people who lost were the pay-as-you-earn taxpayers . Taxation revenue does not appear from the sky. If it is not collected from one source, it has to be collected from another, and the simple solution for everyone was that the PAYE payers kept forking out of their pockets. It is impossible to assess accurately revenue losses due to tax evasions. However, it has been estimated that the black or underground economy, as it is referred to, accounts for as much as 10 per cent of the nation's economy. Not only does this represent a substantial loss of taxation revenue, but also, very significantly, it distorts the economy.

The annual Report of the Commissioner of Taxation and the 1981-82 Budget Estimates provide statistics on tax outstanding as a result of tax avoidance activities. They list, for example, in the period 1980-81, $973m. So well documented information has been provided which demonstrates quite clearly that, firstly, the Opposition, which was then the government of the day, acted only under forced electoral pressure when it had a number of independent reports presented which clearly demonstrated that tax evasion and avoidance schemes were rampant in the community. It then had to act. We, as the then Opposition members , pointed out that there were serious deficiencies in the recoupment of that money and now the present Opposition is surprised that the government of the day has gone along to keep its electoral commitments. We have not procrastinated. We have decided that we must proceed with this legislation on the grounds of equity . We believe that every taxpayer in this country should pay what is his due and it is the intention of this Labor Government that we will no longer tolerate the situation referred to by Professor Russell Mathews in 1980 when he said that tax avoidance flourished on such a scale as to make personal income tax a voluntary tax for the rich non-salary earner. Under the Labor Government, those days are over. What we want is a fair and equitable tax system. The Bills before us tonight will contribute substantially to that.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spender Mr J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the 10 minutes which I have to speak in this debate, let me start by putting certain propositions about this law to this chamber. First of all, there is the need for certainty in the law. Secondly, there is the need for adherence to the rule of law, and by adherence to the rule of law I do not mean the retrospective overturning of a decision of the High Court of Australia. That is quite contrary to the adherence of the rule of law. Thirdly, there is the principle which has to be considered in tax legislation, as it must in any other legislation, that within the law a citizen is entitled to order his affairs. For those who would say, on the part of the Government, that this is some recent creation of the High Court, let me remind them that in 1927 one of the leading justices in England said:

SPEECH.PARA: It is trite law that His Majesty's subjects are free, if they can, to make their own arrangements, so that their cases may fall outside the scope of the taxing Acts. They incur no legal penalties and, strictly speaking, no moral censure if, having considered the lines drawn by the Legislature, for the imposition of taxes, they make it their business to walk outside them.

The fourth point to bear in mind is this: There is a great distinction between what is legally permiss- ible and socially undesirable. We can all differ on the view as to what is desirable or undesirable but the question as to whether, a matter is legally permissible is one that should be left to the resolution of our courts. In this case, we have, in the Taxation (Unpaid Company Tax) Assessment Amendment Bill a proposition which is aimed at reversing, retrospectively, a decision of the High Court. After the decision of the High Court in Slutzkin's case, one had essentially three courses open to one.

TALK.START.PARA: —That was a shameful decision. That is the sort of decision you like.

—First of all, where there were accumulated profits in a company and where taxes had been paid on those profits, one could trade one and use those accumulated profits for the purposes of business; secondly, one could wind up the company and distribute the profits and the revenue profits and only the revenue profits would be subject to tax under section 47. Thirdly, one could sell on the basis of the decision in Slutzkin's case, and for those ignorant idiots such as the honourable member who interjected and said that it was a shameful decision, let me remind him that the High Court simply interprets the law. It lays down the law in accordance with the legislation passed by this Parliament and if this Parliament does not change the legislation, so be it.

SPEECH.PARA: The central vice of the proposal which is now before the Parliament is that it overturns retrospectively the decision in Slutzkin's case. I will give an example as to how it works. First, let us assume a case in which there is a company that has two shareholders. It has nil liabilities save tax and has paid all of its past tax. Let us assume that it has-I will use simple figures so that the Government can understand-$100,000 of accumulated revenue profits and $100, 000 of capital profits. That would add up, as any Government member could understand, to $200,000. Let us further assume that it has $250 in current unpaid company tax and a paid up capital of $20,000. Under the formula which is worked out in this Act the value of the company, minus its paid up capital, minus the unpaid company tax, is to be the deemed dividend. In the case that I gave, that is $179,750 which, for each of the two shareholders, would then be $ 89,875 on which they would pay 60 per cent tax. That tax would be paid in reference to profits, half of which would never have been taxable in the hands of the company or on a winding up.

To make the illustration even clearer, let us assume that the same company had no accumulated revenue profits; it simply had $200,000 in capital profits. The result is that under the operation of this legislation each of the shareholders would pay $56,925 or more. On what? They would pay it on a deemed dividend of a capital sum, which is a capital gains tax. This amounts to the retrospective reversal of Slutzkin's case. The formula is to be found in clause 8, proposed new section 5A (3), of the Taxation (Unpaid Company Tax) Assessment Amendment Bill. If that formula is not as I put it, the Government should amend it so as to make it perfectly clear in the legislation that under no circumstances is there ever to be a tax which is to be attributable to a capital element. But as matters now stand, that is how the legislation reads and that is how it will operate.

It will be irrelevant as to why the company tax-the sum of $250 that I mentioned-was not paid. It may have been unpaid as a result of fraud or commercial misfortune. The tax is imposed not only on profits on which taxes had already been paid, but also on profits that were never taxable in the hands of the company itself. No regard whatsoever is to be paid to whether the deemed dividends, if paid to the vendor on a winding up, would have been taxable in whole or in part. The effect is that everything is in under the ill-conceived and ill-drawn proposal, if it can be so described-or otherwise by the deliberate intent of this Government. The consequences of this kind of legislation are perfectly obvious, recalling that it overturns the decision made in 1976 and taxes retrospectively people who relied upon that decision. The consequences are , first, commercial dislocation; secondly, uncertainty; and thirdly, it is a perfectly plain incentive to fraud, because if a government cannot be trusted to accept a decision of a court and to amend legislation afterwards to overcome the decision, but not so as to overcome it retrospectively, many people will say that it is not worth playing the game by the system. They will say: 'Let's go all out for tax evasion'.

In the longer term there are some other consequences. First, we are looking to the establishment of a capital gains tax because that is what it plainly is. Secondly, there will be the enshrining of the principle of retrospectivity in the way in which this Government is to conduct its taxing operations.

TALK.START.PARA: —You started it.

—The honourable member for Canberra said that we started it. The distinction is that the legislation which was introduced fixed upon fraud and fraud alone. This legislation does not fix upon fraud and it deliberately overturns a decision which we did not touch. Nor did we seek to overturn any decision of the High Court by our legislation. Of course, this Government will embalm a principle in this precedent-that of contempt for the law. In the longer term it may also be said that this legislation has all the hallmarks of the Hawke Government-a lack of opportunity for public debate, brought in as it was last week and to be passed this week; no opportunity for the professional bodies to examine it or to consult or talk with the taxation officers, if they deign to see professional officers, or to talk with the Minister for Finance if he could find the time or if he deigned to see them.

SPEECH.PARA: Deliberately or accidentally, we have enshrined the proposition of deceit. Nowhere in the second reading speech is there to be found any reference to Slutzkin's case. Is that deliberate or accidental? Is it through incompetence or design? Whatever I might think of the capacities of the Minister who has the conduct of this legislation, I do not think that he is so incompetent as not to understand what was being done-that Slutzkin's case was being retospectively overturned and that a capital gains tax was being imposed on the Australian public in the guise of recoupment of tax. This is certainly one of the most dangerous pieces of legislation and one of the most deceitful attempts to pass legislation under a different guise that this House has ever seen.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dawkins The Hon J.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-I rise to respond in this debate. First, I thank honourable members who have contributed to it. I want to answer a couple of the major arguments which the Opposition has offered against the proposals which the Government has before the House tonight. Before doing so, I indicate that we are not talking tonight about something which has crept up by stealth on the Parliament or the people of Australia. It had been foreshadowed by the Australian Labor Party in Opposition months ago and during the election campaign. Anybody who tries to argue that there has not been adequate notice of what the Government is now doing is simply flying in the face of history. Indeed, the Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) in his contribution tonight indicated that there was nothing new in what was being proposed to the House. He said that the Government was either attempting to overturn amendments which had been made by the then Government after it introduced its original recoupment legislation last year, or had attempted to enforce amendments proposed by the then Opposition which had been rejected by the then Government.

SPEECH.PARA: I think the Deputy Leader of the Opposition was substantially right. The Government on this occasion is giving effect to the view which it expressed during the debates last year and again undertook to the people of Australia during the election campaign at the beginning of this year. So to pretend that we are engaged in an exercise in deceit is quite clearly a contradiction of the English language. We have made it perfectly clear-indeed, quite courageously we made it clear months ago, years ago-that we intended to act according to these particular principles. We have argued that we shall never deal with the tax avoidance industry in this country and conclusively wipe it out unless we embrace the principle of retrospectivity.

That is not a novel principle. It has been employed by governments in other countries and it has been found in those countries to be totally successful. What it means is that as soon as the Government indicates its preparedness- indeed, its determination-to act retrospectively against blatantly and unambiguously contrived tax avoidance schemes and will act retrospectively back to the time when they were first used, that is the most effective weapon, the weapon which is most feared by the tax avoiders in this and any other country. So, one of our first acts as a government was to indicate our preparedness to act in that way in respect of any artificially contrived schemes which appeared during the life of this Government.

I acknowledge that the Deputy Leader of the Opposition was right and that the tax avoidance industry in this country has faltered; in fact, it is staggering to a certain death. But the certainty of that death has been made absolute only by the fact that this Government has indicated its resolve to act retrospectively in respect of any artificially contrived schemes which come to light during the period of this Government. What we have said is that when such schemes arise we are prepared to act retrospectively back to the date of first known use of those schemes.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is not the end of it.

—The honourable member for McPherson says, 'This is not the end of it '. He confuses two quite separate issues. In the first instance, we said what our position was in relation to the bottom-of-the-harbour exercise-I shall come to that shortly. In respect of any new schemes the details of which we were not aware of prior to the election, we do not intend to act retrospectively. We are not trying to remake history or to right the manifest wrongs of seven years of Liberal neglect in relation to tax avoidance. We have made that perfectly clear. What we are saying, however, is that to the extent that artificially contrived schemes come to light during the period of this Government we are prepared to go back to the time of first known use. That is the weapon which the tax avoidance industry most fears. I confidently predict that we have really seen the end of tax avoidance in this country. I do not disparage the belated actions of the former Government in this regard, but what I am saying is that those actions would be for nought if that final step had not been taken by this Government and that final declaration had not been made by this Government in respect of these issues.

SPEECH.PARA: In relation to these schemes, we have taken the view of the former Government: That the bottom-of-the-harbour exercise was quite fraudulent; that it was entirely bereft of any justification. If it were not for the Labor Party last year the legislation proposed by the former Government would not only not have got through the Senate; it probably would not have got through this House, either. It was only because of our preparedness to embrace the views of the former Government in respect of the particular category of bottom-of-the-harbour schemes that the legislation, which the Deputy Leader of the Opposition quite rightly prides himself on having put on the statute books, would have made it to the statute books.

We were quite unambiguous about our support for those measures. However, we were also quite unambiguous and quite outspoken at the time about our views that the then Government was not going far enough in respect to these measures. As the Deputy Leader of the Opposition has said, we indicated that we wanted the measures to go further in a number of respects. We did not agree with the amendments which the then Government introduced after the introduction of the Bills. What we are doing on this occasion is to reverse the amendments which the then Government introduced, it having succumbed to pressure either from its back bench or from the tax avoidance industry at the time. We believe that the original intent of the then Government was correct and we are simply ensuring that the original views of the then Treasurer, now the Deputy Leader of the Opposition, in fact achieve what was his original ambition, and that is to appear on the statute book in their pristine form.

It cannot be argued that what we are proposing tonight is in any sense deceitful or unexpected. We said at the time that those moves by the then Government were wrong and that we believed they should not have occurred. We also indicated at the time that we believed that the Government should have proceeded to collect the personal income tax which would have been paid had the benefits of those schemes been received by the recipients in the form of dividends; that is, that we believed that the personal income tax involved should also have been collected. Indeed, I wrote to the then Treasurer during the process of that debate, on 1 October, and raised these questions with him. He responded to my colleague, the honourable member for Gellibrand (Mr Willis), the then shadow Minister responsible for economic matters, and indicated that substantial amounts of tax had been escaped in relation to these schemes.

It has been argued tonight that we have abandoned the acid test which the former Government employed to determine those areas in which retrospective legislation was justified; that is, it has been argued that it is only where there is an element of fraudulence, it is only in the sort of exercises which were involved in the colloquially termed bottom-of-the-harbour schemes, that which ought to have attracted the admittedly extreme opprobrium of retrospective tax, was justified. We have agreed with that. We agreed with the Government at the time. What we are doing on this occasion is to attack no scheme which was not at the same time involved with a bottom-of-the-harbour scheme; that is, there is no area which had not some fraudulent component in it in relation to the measures we are taking tonight.

The Deputy Leader of the Opposition has argued that we are inventing a new tax, that we are imposing a new liability. He has argued that we are introducing into the tax law a new tax which had not, before the passage of this legislation, previously existed. He is not that much of a fool. He knew what he was doing when be introduced and successfully passed through this Parliament Part IVA of the current income tax law. He knew what he was doing then, and he knows full well that if any company went to the bottom-of-the-harbour after Part IVA was in operation exactly the same kind of taxes would be collected as are intended to be collected as a result of this legislation. He knows that Part IVA goes beyond the collection of unpaid company tax and goes to the point of collecting the unpaid income tax which would have been paid had the benefits been received by the shareholders in the form of dividends and been taxed in the normal way.

Let us not be deceived by the belligerence or aggression of the Deputy Leader of the Opposition. He knew what he was doing when he introduced Part IVA. He knows what Part IVA now means. On this occasion we are simply extending the principles that he introduced quite properly in relation to Part IVA to the areas which he retrospectively acted against late last year. So let us not have any of this nonsense about a new capital gains tax. To the extent that what is happening tonight represents a tax on capital profits, that is exactly the same principle which is included in Part IVA.

Some magnificent argument has been elaborately constructed in recent times about how if these companies had been liquidated, rather than sent to the bottom of the harbour, the capital profits would not have been taxed. Of course that is true, but these companies were not liquidated. They continued in operation. If the designers of these schemes had been interested only in avoiding the tax on the capital profits of course they would have liquidated the companies. That would have been the sensible course, but they were not happy with that. They wanted to avoid not only the tax on the capital profits but also the lot. So they dumped the companies at the bottom of the harbour in a quite fraudulent manner and ensured that they avoided the tax not only on to the capital profits but also on the current year profits and the accumulated profits of those companies.

Very few other substantial matters have been raised by the Opposition. The Deputy Leader of the Opposition raised the issue that some penalty is involved in relation to the measures which we are proposing tonight. I have no idea what he is talking about, except that he may be saying that in some circumstances the tax which will be collected from these measures will be at the rate of 60c in the dollar rather than 46c in the dollar. I am not sure whether that is the point he is making, but if it is, let me answer it in this way: It would have been perfectly consistent with everything the Labor Party has said over the last year and more that we should have not only collected the tax in the then current dollar terms but also we should have added an amount to ensure that it was collected in real dollar terms. That is, we should have denied the benefit which the recipients or the tax avoiders had in relation to the use of those ill- gotten funds during the years in which they had the use of them. We decided against that course. Had we decided to collect the tax in real terms instead of historic dollar terms, the amount collected would not have been $570m, it would have been $840m. So let us not have any argument about penalties being applied to these matters.

If the Deputy Leader of the Opposition is pointing to the fact that in some circumstances the rate of tax will be higher than the company rate, that is perfectly sensible and logical because we are talking about collecting personal income tax. The rate at which we will collect it will be approprite to the level of income in the year in which these dividends would have been received, other than for the device which was employed to ensure that the dividends were not received but rather that the benefits were received in inflated share prices. Let us not have any nonsense about penalties being applied in this instance.

The Deputy Leader of the Opposition embarked on his crusade tonight saying that the Labor Party, when in opposition, had indicated that a vast bonanza of tax avoided was there ready for the taking. There was a rather quaint inconsistency in his argument. In the first instance he said that because we claimed in opposition that there was $7 billion out there to be collected and because, having got into government, we decided to collect what he described as a measly $507m, we were not to be trusted and that we were entirely hypocritical in our protestations before the election. But in his next breath he went on to say that what we were intending to do in collecting that $570m was far too much and that, indeed, we were embarked on a quite scurrilous exercise. Quite frankly, the Deputy Leader of the Opposition cannot have it both ways.

Let me indicate the veracity of the claims which we made. The figure of $7,000m related to tax avoidance and tax evasion. I have collected some statistics in relation to tax avoidance which occurred during the years 1975 to 1982. What is revealed is that on the basis of verifiable statistics an amount of $2.7 billion went uncollected as a result of the neglect of the former Government. That is in respect of tax avoidance itself. The Deputy Leader of the Opposition said tonight that in his view tax evasion was vastly more important than tax avoidance ever was or is ever likely to be.

TALK.START.PARA: —Now.

—Now. The former Opposition, the Labor Party, said that there was one amount relating to tax avoidance-the figure that has now been verified is $2.7 billion-and another amount relating to tax evasion. It does not take much imagination to inflate the figure of $2.7 billion to $7 billion, on the basis of the observations of the Deputy Leader of the Opposition about the magnitude of tax evasion, and to realise that the Labor Party was not far off the mark in making those sorts of claims. Indeed they were the claims not only of the then Opposition but also of independent authorities.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave -I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) Clause 65, page 61, line 36, proposed section 221YHA, paragraph 3 (c), omit '$10,000', substitute '$2,000'.
(2) Clause 65, pages 76-79, omit proposed section 221YHQ, substitute the following section:
Deduction exemption certificates

''221YHQ. (1) Subject to this section, on application in writing by a person, in a form approved by the Commissioner for the purposes of this section, the Commissioner shall issue a deduction exemption certificate under this section to the person in relation to a specified period.
'(2) The Commissioner may refuse to issue a deduction exemption certificate to a person (in this sub-section referred to as ''the applicant'') if-

(a) the applicant is, at the time of receipt by the Commissioner of the application for deduction exemption certificate, in default in his obligations under any Act administered by the Commissioner; or
(b) in the opinion of the Commissioner the issue of a deduction exemption certificate to the applicant may have the consequence of avoidance of tax on any prescribed payment to the applicant; or
(c) the applicant has not previously lodged an income tax return with the Commissioner.
'(3) Subject to section 221YHS, a deduction exemption certificate remains in force during the period specified in the certificate as the period during which the certificate remains in force.
'(4) Where a payee has properly furnished a deduction form to an eligible paying authority in relation to a prescribed payment and-
(a) if the payment is to be made to the payee in person-
(i) the payee has declared in the deduction form that a deduction exemption certificate has been issued to the payee in respect of the period specified in the declaration and has not been revoked,
(ii) the payee has produced to the eligible paying authority a deduction exemption certificate issued to the payee and applicable to the time when the payment is to be made, and
(iii) the eligible paying authority has no reasonable grounds for believing that the deduction exemption certificate has been revoked, or

(b) if the payment is not to be made to the payee in person the payee has declared in the deduction form that a deduction exemption certificate has been issued to the payee in respect of the period specified in the declaration and has not been revoked,
the eligible paying authority shall not make any deduction from the prescribed payment under paragraph 221YHD (1) (a).''.

The two amendments apply to two aspects of the legislation. The first amendment seeks to lower the exemption that is proposed by the Government. The Government' s proposal of $10,000 is far too high for the provisions of this legislation. I propose that the amount of $2,000 be substituted for an amount of $10,000. It is a fact that within the building industry 40 per cent of alterations and additions above $2,000, together with the owner-builders, constitute 40 per cent of the recorded private home building activity. It seems to me that under those circumstances major portions of the building industry are not caught within this proposed legislation. Under those circumstances I have no alternative but to put to the Government the proposition that it has gone weak on what it claimed was a tax avoidance measure and that it is not willing to go to the length that is needed to prevent cash payments being made. I further predict that unless the Government is prepared to accept the amendment to substitute the figure for $2, 000 then we will see massive processes of splitting payments whereby owner- builders and others will be positively encouraged to split their payments in such a way which avoids the provisions of the proposed Act.

The $10,000 limit will provide for owner-builders to seek to split their payments in such a way that they will be slightly under the $10,000 with successive payments, thereby avoiding the provisions of the proposed Act, to report the amount of the payments. Compliance will be reduced. Indeed, the capacity to collect tax from cash payments also will be reduced. We are talking of a major section of the area about which the Government claims it is concerned , that is, the cash payments area. What the Government has failed to realise is that a major proportion of building in Australia today is carried out by owner- builders. It is a simple process, both in Victoria and New South Wales, to apply for a licence. Owners are encouraged by builders to carry out this process on their behalf, thereby avoiding the responsibility that a builder may have under State legislation to carry through certain procedures. This legislation picks up that mistake. In fact, it will encourage builders to have owners apply for a licence to build. In that way the builders themselves will avoid their obligations under this legislation. The Minister must realise that it is a mistaken measure and that the only way in which it can be properly dealt with is to reduce the exemption from $10,000 to $2,000. I now move to the second amendment which is to proposed new sectio 221YHQ.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a very dangerous provision.

—It is a dangerous section of the proposed Act. What I propose in my amendment is to move the onus of issue of a deduction from the applicant to the Commissioner of Taxation but, by that process, to also insert provisions for protection against tax avoiders. In this way the Commissioner himself becomes the person who is liable for the onus to issue a deduction exemption certificate . The Commissioner can make an assessment as to whether the applicant is a proper person. The protection for the Commissioner and for the revenue is contained in this amendment. The applicant must provide details of his previous tax record. Also he must be able to assure the Commissioner that he is not involved in tax avoidance, nor will he seek provisions of cash payments as tax avoidance. The applicant must have previously lodged income tax returns with the Commissioner. Those are perfectly proper protections for the revenue in such a way that the Commissioner can be assured that there is no way in which an applicant is seeking to avoid payments and that the applicant has a sound and proper record over a long period. The amendment goes on to provide that should the Commissioner issue an exemption certificate he can call on the applicant at any time to produce evidence. He can say that the applicant is denied the process of a certificate. The whole protection that the Government seeks is put in place by the Commissioner being made aware of every applicant and every process in this area.

SPEECH.PARA: This legislation is absolutely deplorable. It strikes at the major business activity area of Australia, that is, the small self-employed businessman, the contractor and sub-contractor. The provisions of the legislation as proposed by the Minister will only encourage further avoidance and further techniques. I have outlined the way in which some of those avoidance measures which will be entered into and encouraged can be dealt with and which, at the same time, protect the status, well-being and continuing viability of the individual involved in subcontracting. The Minister will have on his head-I am sure he is aware of this-the bankruptcies that will follow through the introduction of this tax. An increase in the unemployment benefit will be necessary in industries which are under great pressure at the moment. The industries at which the Government is striking are under pressure. They need to be assured that the Government has a continuing interest in their well-being but, at the same time, the intention of both the Opposition and the Government must be that there shall be no avoidance of cash payments, that the cash economy and the $2,000m that is being used in the cash economy is properly dealt with. The proposed measures will cover that and, in fact, are a worthy addition to the Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dawkins The Hon J.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government does not accept the amendment. The amendment proposes that in relation to reporting provisions for householders the limit be decreased from $10,000 to $2,000 in respect of work contracted for by a householder. We have looked carefully at this. The honourable member for Mitchell (Mr Cadman) seems to be under a misapprehension that we are imposing a new tax. Of course, we are not imposing a new tax; we are simply imposing a new method of collecting a tax which has always been legally due. I further remind the honourable member for Mitchell that indeed this is a proposal of the former Government on which it did not get round to legislating.

—No, wait a minute. The proposals of the former Government were to set the limit at $3,000. We carefully examined that. We carefully discussed the matter with the industry. We carefully considered the consequences on householders. We carefully considered the revenue implications of the change from $3,000 to $10,000 as a limit and we discovered that the amount of revenue involved would decline only from $17m to $14m. Under those circumstances, particularly bearing in mind that these are new procedures-procedures which householders are not used to-it was not worth pursuing and battering householders in relation to smaller contracts which they might enter into involving alterations to their homes or whatever. I further indicate to the honourable member for Mitchell that we are actively pursuing the possibilities relating to the co-operation of State and local governments to ensure a greater level of compliance with these measures than would be possible if they were acting on their own.

SPEECH.PARA: I am confident that what we are proposing is a cautious approach. It is designed not to inconvenience householders but at the same time it is designed to strike at that aspect of the cash economy involved in this area. On the balance of issues that have to be considered, I think it is a reasonable approach. We have amended a number of other aspects of the former Government's proposals. I think that, given that we obviously have to keep this matter under review, the $10,000 is both equitable and appropriate in the circumstances.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tuckey Mr C.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —In regard to Division 3A of the Income Tax Assessment Act, we have heard a lot of talk this evening about the villains of the piece in the area of tax avoidance. I am trying to identify the villains in this particular piece of legislation. I have an idea it might be the fellow who unfortunately mistakenly fails to deduct tax from somebody who carries out some work for him.
—Why don't you go back and read it. That is not what it is all about, you great twit.

—I know a lot about it. If I am great I have something over the Minister for Finance (Mr Dawkins). It appears that this piece of legislation states that if one has a contract one is a tax risk yet if one handles numerous small cash transactions one is not. This shows the paranoia of the Minister at the table. He will go for anything that he thinks he can plan. The honourable member for Melbourne Ports (Mr Holding), who is seeking to interject, need not worry. We will talk about his royal commission at some time. We should look at proposed new section 221YHH. It provides for deductions from prescribed payments . It states:

SPEECH.PARA: Where an eligible paying authority other than a government body fails, at the time of making a prescribed payment to a payee, to deduct from the payment the amount required to be deducted under this Division--

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise a point of order, Mr Deputy Chairman. The erudite speech of the honourable member for O'Connor might be more appropriate when we get to the amendment to which he is speaking. It has not yet been moved.
—I will take a point of order in reverse, Mr Deputy Chairman. My understanding of the agreement is that we are dealing with the Bill as a whole.
—That is not for the amendment that we are discussing now.
—Just ask the gentleman in the chair, Mr Minister. What is his ruling?
—There is no point of order. We are dealing with the Bill as a whole.

—The next time the Minister uses the word 'erudite' he should use his brains. He is singularly short of them, which is why he could not pass his university exams. He is a failure but he is pretty smart with his mouth. He is not denying that. The point I am making is that this Bill has as many penalties in it for the people who just happen to employ someone as it has in it penalties for tax avoiders. It is time that some of the people who sit behind the Minister asked themselves how this will affect some of their constituents. I will read proposed new section 221YHH again. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: Where an eligible paying authority other than a government body fails, at the time of making a prescribed payment to a payee, to deduct from the payment the amount required to be deducted under this Division, the eligible paying authority is liable to pay to the Commissioner by way of penalty-
This relates to the person who made the payment; not the person who received it. It continues:
(a) An amount (in this section referred to--

TALK.START.PARA: —Have you declared your personal interest in this legislation?
—I am quite happy about my position at any time. I have not yet been accused of taking bribes. It has been very close to your--
—Order! The honourable member will address his remarks through the Chair.
—The proposed section continues:

SPEECH.PARA: (a) an amount (in this section referred to as the 'undeducted amount') equal to the amount that the eligible paying authority failed to deduct; and

(b) an amount equal to 20 per cent per annum of so much of the undeducted amount . . .I am not sure what that means but I get the feeling that it relates to a householder who involves himself in a contract relating to the building of a house. But, of course, if one is a householder or any other person in Australia who employs some person and that person advises that he has an exemption or a variation and one unfortunately believes him when he does not have such exemption, one is liable. One has only to look at that proposed section to find what rights the Commissioner has to give an exemption. Firstly, one has to be in business for three years. That mitigates against anybody who wants to go into a new business. The fact is that anybody going into a new business needs every penny he has but will now have to forgo 10 per cent of his revenue. That is a wonderful arrangement for encouraging investment and encouraging people to go out and give it a try! I give the example of a truck driver who might aspire to be a truck owner. In the first three years that he drives his truck he has massive repayments--

TALK.START.PARA: —Oh!

—The honourable member is not worried about such people. He does not believe in people owning anything. He does not want them to own anything because they escape his net. When they own something his party will not have them any more and that is what he is worried about. This Bill mitigates against anybody getting into business. There is no way that they would be able to afford to have 10 per cent deducted from their revenue. In the Bill the Commissioner of Taxation is not advised that he may give certain variations on certain exemptions; he is advised that he will not give exemptions or variations unless very stringent rules are met. The Commissioner is a man who is known for his conservatism and he and his employees will not give those variations or those exemptions.

SPEECH.PARA: I know a great deal about the trucking industry and I know that the average subcontractor and the average small businessman does not have the revenue to be able to afford to have 10 per cent of it removed from him. He will have one choice and that will be to increase his revenue, which means that some poor housewife will have to pay more for her freight. Freight is the highest component of costs in Australia. If he does not do that he will go broke, and we know the consequences of that. There is no middle ground for the average subcontractor. Government members should not laugh about this because some of them probably received a lot of votes from such people. Above all, 50 per cent of the penalties-they range up to $25,000 in this provision-are aimed at people who have committed no more offence than to pay somebody and mistakenly not withhold the required amount of tax. I am wondering how the average John Citizen will be able to deal with the 22 pages of this provision to find out whether he has to make deductions on behalf of the Government. When he does that he will be confronted by people who say: 'I have an exemption, I just failed to bring it with me but I want my money now; I'm in a hurry, I'm desperate'.

TALK.START.PARA: —Oh!

—It has never happened to the Minister; he has lived in another echelon. He is one of the Labor people who have never worked for a living. There is a yard full of them over there; they do not know the reality of life.
—They are champagne socialists.

—That is right, they are champagne socialists-the great workers. We asked about this the other day and one bloke on the other side got up and said: 'I have worked for a living, I am a tradesman'. How many of them can say that tonight? The question we have to confront is: Who does this legislation hurt most? It will not gain the Government a lot of revenue. It will get some in the beginning because it is moving forward the requirement to pay tax. That is all it is doing; it is making a forward tax claim on a lot of people who are paying taxes. They were paying taxes because they had contracts. The next stage involves the people who do not have contracts.

SPEECH.PARA: I hope that tonight the Government might indicate that it will get really and truly into the tax business and put audit totals in everyone's cash registers. Is it prepared to promise that it will do that? If it did that it would really be getting into the tax area, into those little amounts of money. By admitting that $10,000 was a limit in terms of the real cash economy the Government has abrogated any real opportunity to attack the cash economy. It has purely and simply got into the contracts that are established and it has got into the people who are already paying taxes. The only thing it has achieved is to get the taxes 12 months in advance. It is also imposing huge penalties on the people it has now asked to collect the taxes on its behalf. The penalties go up to $25, 000. I hope the Australian public realises the method in the Government's madness. We have had plenty of that, particularly from the Minister for Finance (Mr Dawkins).

They are the issues I want to raise. I want to say again that, in relation to many small contractors, the suggestion is that if one has a $25,000 a year fuel bill and earns $100,000 he is no different from another contractor who has $10, 000 of outgoings and has $100,000 of revenue. I know that the Minister's second reading speech says that the Government will make arrangements for that, but look at the rules it has written for making those arrangements. They all start with the words 'The Commission will not'. The Commissioner will rely on those rules. They do not say 'The Commissioner may' or 'The Commissioner should'; it is all a case of 'The Commissioner will not'. Those provisions will not apply to the average small businessman. He will be stuck with a huge revenue drain that he cannot afford.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The DEPUTY CHAIRMAN

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dawkins The Hon J.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Clause 65, page 78, before proposed paragraph 221YHQ (3) (a) insert the following paragraph:

'(aa) a reference to the Commissioner being satisfied that there is no reasonable likelihood that tax will be payable in relation to a year of income by an applicant for a deduction exemption certificate shall, in the case of an applicant being a partnership or the trustee of a trust estate, be read as a reference to the Commissioner being satisfied that there is no reasonable likelihood that there will be any net income of the partnership or trust estate, as the case may be, in relation to the year of income;'.

This amendment which is of a purely technical nature is intended to clarify one of the conditions for issue of a deduction exemption certificate contained in proposed sub-section 221YHQ (2), which is to be inserted by clause 65 of the Bill. One situation in which an exemption certificate may be issued under the proposed sub-section is where the Commissioner of Taxation is satisfied that, in relation to a particular year of income, the person concerned will have no tax liability. As noted in the explanatory memorandum that has been circulated to honourable members in my name, an example of the kind of situation envisaged would be where the applicant has significant carry forward losses from previous years which, when set off against projected income of the year in question, would result in the person having no tax to pay for that year.

Because the term 'applicant' as used in proposed sub-section 221YHQ (2) includes a partnership or a trustee of a trust estate, could be argued that a partnership, or the trustee of a trust estate who has fully distributed trust income to the beneficiaries, would not technically have a tax liability in relation to the year of income. This is, of course, because it is the partners and the beneficiaries who would be liable to pay tax on partnership or trust income distributed to them.

It was never intended that a partnership, or a trust estate that distributed net income, would, by that circumstance, be liable to obtain an exemption certificate and there is some doubt that, when read in context, a court would interpret the provision in this way. Nevertheless, the Government has decided that the matter should be put beyond doubt by removing the possibility that such an applicant would be able to obtain an exemption certificate on the basis of the technical argument I have outlined.

The amendment will clarify that, in relation to this particular criterion for the issue of an exemption certificate in its application to a partnership or the trustee of a trust estate, it will be necessary for the Commissioner to be satisfied that there is no reasonable likelihood that, during the relevant year of income, there will be any net income of the partnership or the trust estate. I commend this amendment to the Committee.
Amendment agreed to.
Bill, as amended, agreed to.
Bill reported with an amendment; report-by leave-adopted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dawkins The Hon J.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the amendment be agreed to.

This request arises from a motion moved on behalf of the Government in the Senate as a result of its attention having been drawn to a problem that exists with clause 12 as originally proposed. As I pointed out in my second reading speech, the Bill provides that, where an amount paid under a so-called 50-50 arrangement-of the kind formerly entered into by the Commissioner of Taxation-is ultimately refunded, the refund is to be paid to the taxpayer free of interest. That is the effect of clause 12 of the Bill.

In its present form the clause provides that a taxpayer who entered into a 50- 50 arrangement with the Commissioner in respect of a particular amount of disputed tax is not to be eligible to receive interest in respect of any amount paid in accordance with the arrangement. On further examination the Government has decided that, where one of these old 50-50 arrangements has run its course, it is appropriate that any amount previously paid under the arrangement should carry interest, but only from the time when the arrangement comes to an end.

This means that taxpayers who paid disputed tax under such an arrangement and those who pay disputed amounts in the future without the benefit of a 50-50 arrangement will be on an equal footing as regards the receipt of interest on amounts ultimately refunded as a result of a successful objection or appeal. I commend to the Committee the amendment which will give effect to the Government' s decision.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —It appears on the face of it that the amendment requested by the Senate in fact gives effect to what the Minister for Finance ( Mr Dawkins) has set out in his statement. In those circumstances the Opposition will not offer any opposition to the request from another place.
