DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: South Australian Government-Nuclear Testing-Taxation on Lump Sum Superannuation- Passport Applications-Legal Representation for Aborigines-Community Employment Program

PROCTEXT.PARA: South Australian Government-Nuclear Testing-Taxation on Lump Sum Superannuation- Passport Applications-Legal Representation for Aborigines-Community Employment Program
Motion (by Mr Young) proposed:
That the House do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hall Mr R.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —This Parliament should be aware of the dark history that lies behind the continual harrassment of the South Australian Police Force by South Australian Labor Party politicians. Yesterday Mr Giles, the third South Australian commissioner since 1978, resigned. He has said that he is not leaving because of his relations with the South Australian Government. However, after he was told about the ending of the police interpreter services, he is reported as saying: 'We might have to accept it, but we do not necessarily agree with it'. Additionally, the President of the Police Association of South Australia said police were 'irate and disgusted' at the decision. Given the track record of the Labor Party antagonism to the police in South Australia, the public has a right to know whether Mr Giles has been subjected to undue pressures and pushed into early retirement.

SPEECH.PARA: Over the weekend the honourable member for Hindmarsh (Mr Scott) called for the South Australian Government to play a 'special role' before the royal commission set up to investigate the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation, and Combe affair. In this way the South Australian Labor Party is spreading its venom against those whose duty it is to maintain law and order and to collect information about potential terrorists and criminals.

If in fact the South Australian Government is going to get involved in the way the honourable member for Hindmarsh suggests we need to examine its record in the Salisbury affair. In 1977 a report by Mr Acting Justice White on the South Australian Special Branch's activities was used by the former Premier, Mr Dunstan, to hound the Police Commissioner, Mr Harold Salisbury, out of office. This was a vindictive and disgraceful action and it was based on a politically motivated report submitted by Mr Acting Justice White. The Acting Justice was given the task of examining the Special Branch files and if, in his assessment, they were improper or in disorder he was directed by his Commission to have Mr Salisbury correct any faults and errors. For reasons which have never been disclosed, he did not follow his terms of reference and reported to the Government without giving Commissioner Salisbury the right and duty which was set out in those terms of reference.

We certainly are, however, painfully aware of the result. The Premier, Mr Dunstan, reacted hysterically as if the report revealed new details about ASIO and the South Australian records, whereas in fact he had already been informed of them by Salisbury months before. This strange behaviour of the judge and the false indignation of the Premier produced one clear result-the sacking of Salisbury and the destruction of most of the files of the South Australian Special Branch. However, to the great credit of the South Australian people, this fabrication and the heaping of blame on Salisbury rebounded on the Labor Party and its leader. Premier Dunstan mysteriously resigned and his successor was thrashed at the next election. This vindictive sacking of Salisbury, which was contrived because certain members of the Labor Party were mentioned in Special Branch files, is no qualification for the South Australian Government to involve itself in the new ASIO inquiry.

The erratic behaviour of the Prime Minister in continuing to comment on the Combe affair outside of the House but refusing to answer questions inside, and the gradual leaking of the unfolding story of the rejection of the former Labor Party Secretary by his previously close friend and colleague, the Prime Minister , must be throughly examined by the Royal Commission. We can do without further attacks on prominent officers and on our security organisations by the South Australian Government. Harold Salisbury may now live in England but the injustice that he suffered is still vividly remembered in South Australia. The honourable member for Hindmarsh will do his party a service if he reverses the recommendation at the weekend that the South Australian Government involve itself in the Combe-ASIO affair and it keeps well away from a vindictive search for scapegoats for Labor Party antagonism to security organisations. I believe that if the South Australian Government does step out of the State field into the Federal field to pursue ASIO it will again get its answer at the polls. That answer will mean certain defeat.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McHugh Ms J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, you will have noticed yesterday that women in this Parliament displayed their solidarity with their sisters throughout the world who object to the arms race. I rise tonight to express my concern about the resumption of nuclear testing in the Pacific by France. I am appalled at the way in which the French Government is seeking military prestige and political power at the expense of the peoples of the Pacific. We have had the fifty-third explosion of a nuclear device at Mururoa since 1975. Prior to that date, the tests were conducted by France atmospherically, until world wide opposition stopped that particular form of testing. France then decided to go underground and conducted the tests on the coral atoll of Mururoa. Terrible blunders have occurred during testing. In 1979 a bomb detonated half way down the shaft. A part of the reef gave way, causing a giant tidal wave which killed two men and injured four others. I hope that honourable members opposite will continue to approve of the rest of the terrible things that I am going to tell them.

SPEECH.PARA: In the same year, two decontamination squad members were killed in a laboratory explosion while handling acetene gases during a cleaning job. In 1981 a violent storm tore open a flimsy plutonium storage facility and washed potentially lethal wastes into the sea. In all of these incidents official reports have been shrouded in secrecy. In fact, the story of nuclear testing in French Polynesia has been one of government intrigue and deception.

In defending the French Government's policy, the Defence Ministry claims that the test are 'clean'. Of course it makes that claim, but some admit that the long term effects of the blasts remain a scientific mystery. For instance, as a result of the underground testing since 1975 the atoll surrounding a five kilometre wide lagoon has sunk two metres, almost to sea level. There is also the huge garbage dump of radioactive waste-some of it covering 20,000 metres of Mururoa Atoll-which is a continuing source of danger for many years to come to the people living in this region, which ultimately includes Australia. In addition, there is the leakage from beneath the atoll of radioactive material. The seepage of this material into the sea over the years will be quite massive. My party supports the declaring of a nuclear free zone in the South Pacific. Our platform supports the South Pacific states, trade unions and other organisations in opposing the testing of nuclear weapons, nuclear devices and nuclear weapons systems in the region. Pacific states have become increasingly concerned and militant about the testing and are looking to Australia to show a lead on the issue.

Australia will have a chance in August, at the South Pacific Forum, to show some initiative. We will be able to press not just for an end to all testing but our complete opposition to any country with ideas of using the South Pacific region for the dumping of its nuclear waste, as our policy also states. Our government intends to support international efforts to end all such nuclear testing, for example, through a comprehensive nuclear test ban treaty.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: White Mr P.N.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to say a few words tonight about the Government's intention to tax lump sum superannuation. We can only put it down to yet another Hawke deception. The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), in his statement of 15 April, again misled the Australian people. Anyone who reads the newspaper report of the interview in question must come away with the impression, from what he said, that there would be no taxation of lump sum superannuation. Lots of people came to me, as I am sure constituents came to all honourable members about that time, because there was a great deal of concern. I said: 'There is the report. The Prime Minister prides himself on his honesty. There is what he said'. Lo and behold, just a little over a month later what do we have but a repudiation of his word-taxation on lump sum superannuation. We have come to expect, in the short space of about three months, that when the Prime Minister says something the opposite will happen. Ask any journalist in the gallery how much faith he still has in the Prime Minister's word. The superannuation situation is just a debacle. I think it is best summed up by this statement in the Courier-Mail of today:

SPEECH.PARA: In its efforts to stop 'double-dipping', the Federal Government has created confusion bordering on chaos among members of superannuation schemes.
. . . Clearly, it should have waited until all these details, and more, were settled before announcing its changes.
It did not. Instead it foisted a half-baked idea on an unsuspecting public ill- equipped to deal with the inevitable confusion its hasty actions have caused.

I want tonight to highlight the confusion and despair that it caused in one section of the community that least deserves it. I refer to Australian servicemen who, from now on, will suffer because of this decision of the Government. The fact is that servicemen, by the very nature of their calling, are forced to retire early. Most servicemen are retired before the age of 50. At that time they need some capital to start again in a second career. They need the capital with which to buy a house, to educate their children and to re- establish themselves in a normal, civilian life. Servicemen undergo constant turbulence. They do not have the advantage of living in one spot and accumulating property and capital. Therefore, when they retire they need a lump sum with which to re-establish themselves. In 20-odd years in the Army I lived in 25 different houses. The honourable member for Bass (Mr Newman) served about the same time and lived in I am not sure how many houses. We cannot expect these people, after giving that sort of service, to come out and start again without the aid of some capital.

Once it becomes widely known that servicemen are to be disadvantaged, any career counsellor in this country, any headmaster, will tell pupils or others who consult them: 'Do not go into the services because when you have finished you will get nothing out of it; you will be unable to start again'. Another thing that will happen-honourable members will be able to watch it happen-is that there will be a mass exodus from the services as a result of this decision. From now on, anyone with 20 years up will be penalised if he stays any longer. I urger the Government to think about this sector, which is vital to the defence of this country, before it pursues this matter any further.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Maher Mr M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —As from 1 May, solicitors and barristers throughout Australia are no longer authorised to witness Australian passport applications. This ruling came from the previous Government and was apparently announced in the House by the former Minister for Foreign Affairs in a speech on 8 December 1982. This decision of the previous Government, which emanated from a recommendation of the Stewart Royal Commission of Inquiry into Drug Trafficking concerns me greatly. Although I am no longer a practising solicitor, I have a great regard for the legal profession in our nation, the people who work in the law and the people who founded our Parliament and wrote our Constitution. I would point out to the House that they were all lawyers. Many lawyers have served honourably in this House. Some of them are still serving, mainly on the Government side, in a very honourable way. I would point out that there is no profession which is more regulated and restrained in relation to overcharging and dishonesty than the legal profession. Regular checks in all States are undertaken of solicitors' trust accounts and all bills of costs prepared by solicitors are subject to taxation. No such rules apply in relation to medical practitioners, dentists or any other professional group. The whole idea which came from the previous Government strikes me as being quite Gilbertian because a dentist can witness a passport application but a family solicitor cannot. A doctor or a public servant of 10 years standing can witness a passport application, but a barrister practising in the Supreme Court of a State or in the High Court of Australia cannot witness a passport application. Where the farce arises is in relation to members of parliament. Members of parliament, Federal or State, are the first groups specified on the new passport application . They can witness an application for an Australian passport, but if the member of parliament is a solicitor or a barrister, he has to ignore that. So I am bringing this matter to the attention of the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Hayden) hoping that a second look can be taken at this new ruling which applies from 1 May. Surely all passport applications are subsequently checked by the Australian Federal Police. We are told that there is a police check. The whole procedure is only a witnessing procedure. The fact that the family solicitor cannot witness an application, I believe, will put more work on to persons such as members of parliament because many people would be reluctant to go to the dentist to have a passport application witnessed. The whole idea is, to me, unfortunate because it tends to discriminate against solicitors and barristers. No fee is involved. There is no question that solicitors were charging to witness passport applications. The very application itself, the new application which I have scrutinised, says that no fee can be charged.

SPEECH.PARA: I am raising this matter tonight on the adjournment of the House because I believe that there has been a slur against the legal professions throughout our nation. Solicitors feel insulted and several who have spoken to me have felt that they have been classified as second class citizens. Having served in articles and having worked in solicitors' offices, both in the private and public sector, I feel that the Minister should re-examine this decision in relation to Australian passports and, if necessary, amend or regazette a regulation to allow solicitors and barristers to take their place with the other professions in witnessing passport applications.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Porter Mr J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —In Western Australia, according to figures recently released by the Australian Institute of Criminology in relation to a census of Australian prisoners, 32.6 per cent of prisoners are Aborigines, while the Aborigines constitute only about 2.4 per cent of that State's population. If nothing else, these figures indicate the need for legal representation of Aborigines in the courts similar to that available to the non-Aboriginal population. I want to draw to the attention of this House a matter which I have raised with the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Holding) and I do so because of the urgency of the situation. The Ngoonjuwah Council Inc. in the Halls Creek area in Western Australia has approached me because it fears that it is about to lose the services of its Aboriginal legal aid field officer, a Mr Martin Stevens . According to the Council, Mr Stevens is required to service a large area in the Kimberleys covering some 20 communities. He has to service these widely spread communities as well as attend meetings with mining companies and, of course, he attends the Halls Creek court where, I am told, he sees some 15 to 25 people a day.

SPEECH.PARA: The problem which Mr Stevens has in carrying out those duties is that he is not provided with transport. Mr Stevens has therefore had to borrow cars or hitch a ride with departmental officers or friends. It appears that he has now become so frustrated by the situation that he has threatened to resign if he is not given access to transport. Mrs Kathy Yarrik, in a letter to me dated 18 May, said:

I have spoken to Mr Stevens today and unfortunately he considers he has no alternative but to resign as Field Officer, during our lengthy conversation he mentioned the areas in Perth he has contacted and I spoke to the Executive Officer Mr Culbung this morning without any results whatsoever. Therefore I can understand his and sympathise his decision.

Mr Culbung is the executive officer of the Aboriginal Legal Service of Western Australia. I am informed that the reason the request from Mr Stevens has not been met is that no funds are available. I think it would be appropriate to remind the Minister of the Australian Labor Party's policy on Aboriginal affairs announced before the election. On page 23 of its policy it stated:
Labor would immediately increase support for Aboriginal legal aid services so that they could provide full and adequate legal services for their Aboriginal clients.

Bearing in mind the fact that the nearest Aboriginal legal aid is some 550 road miles away at Kununurra, I believe that as a matter of priority the Minister should investigate the claims made and sympathetically consider this application . The Minster has, as he says, replied to me today. Part of that letter states:
. . . I am faced with the prospect of having to wait until the next Budget allocations to have the appropriate funds available.

TALK.START.PARA: —Read out what I said before I said that.

—I understand the Minister's perhaps embarrassment because if he had read the Senate Estimates in which his Department appeared, at page 136 of the Hansard of Senate Estimates Committee D he would see that Mr Toohey indicated that $25,000 which had been allocated to a project in Alice Springs would not, in all likelihood, be used. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . by the time the architects get in and the technical people are advised on the renovations and repairs that are needed, we will probably not spend any cash this year, . . .
Those are the words of a departmental officer from the Department of Aboriginal Affairs. So there is $25,000 for starters.

TALK.START.PARA: —Not for legal aid.

—Ah, not for legal aid. I suggest that the Minister read the Senate Estimates Hansard. Mr Toohey said that out of $75,000 going to the Alice Springs legal aid, $25,000 would not be used. Prima facie, on the evidence given to me, I believe that this case is worthy of the Minister's urgent attention. There is no doubt that the legal service provided is meeting an undeniable need in the area and it should not be allowed to collapse through Government inattention or inactivity.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Punch Mr G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I should like to take this opportunity to draw to the attention of the House and in particular the Government the very suitably targeted objectives and provisions of the Community Employment Program as it relates to my seat of Barton. In the 18 months up to November 1982, my seat of Barton has the distinguished ranking in the grand Liberal-National Party strategy of dislocation, destruction and disorientation of the national economy, of having the third fastest rate of growth in unemployment in Australia. With the wholsesale collapse of the manufacturing sector, the downturn in the building and construction industries and consumer purchasing power decaying, the task in my seat, before greatly improving employment statistics, is indeed to reverse the momentum of unemployment at this time.

SPEECH.PARA: This Government has a mandate to do this, specifically through job creation programs. The Community Employment Program is remarkably well-conceived for the purposes of my seat because it has as one of its fundamental strengths flexibility. This flexibility is present in its eligibility for funds provisions and in how much sponsors must contribute. A further point of flexibility is the type or work eligible for qualification, as well as the percentage of non-labour costs. Its structure of administration is also flexible in that it recognises the legitimate role of all three levels of government-local, State and Federal- as well as the voluntary groups across the community, in getting Australians back to work. But its major strength is its flexibility in that various disadvantaged groups in my electorate can now all have an opportunity to find work through this type of program.

Young people-that is, those under 24-are out of work in my electorate by a ratio of 13:1 for jobs available. For the unskilled amongst this group, this program offers under its guidelines the only real hope of employment at the moment. Indeed, for many the opportunity of six months work is important to their personal development. They will gain not only a sense of being socially useful but also a new dimension in life-getting up and going to work in the morning. This is a dimension of their lives they have been deprived of for the last seven years by those who sit opposite.

Very importantly for my electorate, this program adds an important opportunity for those over 45 years of age who are currently unemployed, many of whom see themselves as now being permanently on the scrap heap. An interesting statistical indication of the burden of unemployment is present in my electorate . I refer to the burden on the forgotten unemployed over the age of 45. The comparison of unemployed by age is as follows: In the 15 to 19 years age group, the unemployed represent 22.7 per cent of the total; in the 45 years and over age group they represent 16.3 per cent of the total. But of the 15 to 19 years group, 21.9 per cent have been unemployed for longer than six months; whereas of the post-45 years age group 49 per cent have been unemployed for longer than six months. Furthermore, the percentage of the 15 to 19 years group that has been unemployed for longer than six months represents 4.94 per cent of the total unemployed in my electorate; whereas the percentage of the over-45 years group that has been unemployed for longer than six months represents 8 per cent of the total. Clearly, the post-45 years age group is significant in the ranks of the unemployed in my electorate. It is therefore significant that our program has a central point local government and related local community works. Many of the 45 years and over group will find rewarding work in socially orientated works of lasting value to our local community-be they clerical, administrative, welfare orientated or manual.

In the last 12 months Hurstville council gained $118,000 in State Government grants for employment generating works, which employed 65 people in the Hurstville municipality. It received not one cent from the previous Federal Government. It is my hope that, in allocating the $86.3m provided for New South Wales under the Community Employment Bill, the Government will have my seat of Barton uppermost in its mind.
Motion (by Mr Young) agreed to:
That the question be now put.
Original question resolved in the affirmative.
